fields.headline: Isa mortgage
fields.trailText: Under this scheme you invest in an Individual savings account (Isa) and use the proceeds to pay off the loan at the end of the term.
fields.body:
Under this scheme you invest in an Individual savings account (Isa) and use the proceeds to pay off the loan at the end of the term.

The Isa holds shares, either in individual companies or in unit and investment trusts, and the proceeds are allowed to grow tax free.

If the Isa does particularly well then you'll have enough money to pay the mortgage off early.

The downside is that if the stock market crashes just before you want to pay off the loan, you will have to wait until share prices recover.

Most importantly, there is no guarantee your Isa will pay off your loan.

webTitle: Jon Temple: Why the Windsors should take DNA tests

fields.headline: Royals should prove their blood is blue
fields.standfirst:
DNA tests should be compulsory for anyone on the civil list
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The news that the BBC is appealing for volunteers to trace Viking ancestors among the British population through DNA testing shows how this rapidly developing technology is opening up a whole new world not only in medicine, where its effect is revolutionary, but also in the historical field.
fields.body:
The news that the BBC is appealing for volunteers to trace Viking ancestors among the British population through DNA testing shows how this rapidly developing technology is opening up a whole new world not only in medicine, where its effect is revolutionary, but also in the historical field.

It is also now standard procedure in criminal forensic investigations for those seeking to prove conclusively their identity to submit to a DNA test. And because such testing provides positive proof of family continuity, it has become indispensable in inheritance disputes and in cases of disputed paternity, for example when the child support agency needs to determine liability. Many men have been cleared of the onerous financial responsibility for supporting children originally believed to be theirs and have been grateful for the advance in medical science.

Though few other scenarios exist in our 21st-century society in which proof of bloodline continuity is necessary, one is still crucial - the British monarchy.

The House of Windsor depends upon the principle of heredity for its very existence as the provider of successive heads of state for this country. Using the latest advances in genetic science to provide the ultimate proof of the royal pudding would be a logical extension of the complex list of royal succession.

We rely upon one family alone to provide us with our head of state - and to assist it in this function we support its members generously, both directly and indirectly, through our taxes.

In the past, in less scientifically advanced times, the best verification of royal legitimacy was for a senior official to be present at a royal birth to ensure no sleight of hand with a warming pan to substitute a boy for a girl .

Science can do a better job these days. It can supply conclusive proof not only of entitlement to be head of state but also of membership of the royal family, with all the financial privilege and institutionalised influence that accompanies it.

To be a recipient of just a part of the £7.9m civil list is like being guaranteed one of the major prizes in the national lottery each birthday. The lucky jackpot winner gets the chance - among other valuable perks - to approve parliamentary legislation, to pick the prime minister after each general election and to be the country's principal ambassador.

To suggest the immediate DNA testing of all members of the royal family is no joke. It is deadly serious - and a matter of principle.

A DNA test before inclusion in the civil list should be as natural as the checks on identity the relevant authorities perform on all of us before they issue a passport or driving licence.

Why should the population of this country be denied positive proof of the legitimacy of their ruling family, which is constitutionally at the top of the pyramid and the recipient of millions of pounds of public money?

We have every right to know if they are who they claim they are - and if the Windsors don't agree, they should simply pack up and leave the palace. Why should we, as a nation, continue to support a clan that is not prepared to fulfil its side of a bargain with us, yet willingly reaps all the benefits?

After all, if the tests are all in order, the members of the royal family can resume their lives of privilege and luxury and we can rest assured that we are getting what we have paid, and continue to pay, for.

Until the day that the people of this country are able to elect their head of state, it is only right and proper that we should be able to see that those who act as our ruling family are truly who they claim to be.

Precedents already exist. One is Lord Moynihan, who succeeded to his position in the House of Lords as a result of a DNA test, which provided proof of his paternity in a court case.

Closer to the palace, the Duke of Edinburgh donated a DNA sample to help solve the mystery of Anastasia, alleged survivor of the Romanov family massacre in which Tsar Nicholas II died (the Duke is a surviving relative of the tsar). His sons could also have participated to provide proof: researchers normally look for markers on the Y chromosome, which is passed on virtually unchanged from father to son.

Current members of the Windsor family who receive public money should be required to submit for testing, as should any heir to the throne before his or her accession. Refusal to do so, or a test failure, would invalidate any entitlement to money or position and would incur liability for the return of monies provided in the past. If an institution is founded upon heredity, then it is only right that that heredity be proved.

Jon Temple is spokesperson for Republic

webTitle: Cocu wants to stay at Barca

fields.headline: Cocu wants to stay at Barca
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger last night played down reports linking Arsenal with a move for Barcelona's Dutch midfielder Philip Cocu.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger last night played down reports linking Arsenal with a move for Barcelona's Dutch midfielder Philip Cocu.

Speaking after his side's 2-1 defeat to the Catalan giants in the Amsterdam Tournament - in which Cocu ironically scored the wining goal six minutes before the break - Wenger admitted that the two clubs had talked about the possibility of a move, but stressed that was as far as it went.

"We talked about it, but he wants to stay at Barca and so that situation is quite clear," said Wenger.

The Gunners certainly have plenty of money to spend following the £30million-joint sale of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit to last night's opponents, but it is unlikely they will be rushed into making any panic buys.

Indeed, it was one of the trialists with the north London side who caught the eye, as 22-year-old Lithuanian Tomas Danilvicius hit a splendid equaliser in the 32nd minute after Josep Guardiola had put Barca ahead from the spot after just three minutes following a foul on Dani Garcia by Martin Keown.

"He had a good first half and caused trouble to the Barcelona defence," Wenger told Sky Sports Extra.

"He is great in the air and scored a good goal, but he needs a work permit and so we need to see about that first."

Despite the defeat, Wenger remained pleased with his side's performance - 15 days ahead of the start of their Premiership campaign away to Sunderland.

He said: "We went down with the early goal and came back into the game.

"We had a quite good half, with good movement, but in the second half the game became slower for both sides.

"However, I am quite happy with the performance - even if we lost."

fields.headline: Fifa to rotate World Cup
fields.trailText: Fifa agreed in principle yesterday to rotate future World Cups following the recent debacle which saw Germany narrowly beat South Africa in the competition to host the 2006 tournament.
fields.body:
Fifa agreed in principle yesterday to rotate future World Cups following the recent debacle which saw Germany narrowly beat South Africa in the competition to host the 2006 tournament.

The final details of rotating the World Cup will be worked out by the world governing body's strategic studies committee and the new system will be in place from 2010.

The director of England's failed 2006 campaign Alec McGivan said his reaction was "favourable" but warned: "I think the principle is some way removed from the detail."

"If we are still talking about a World Cup every four years, then each continent gets it every 24 years," McGivan said. "Which means in Europe a country like ourselves or Germany will host it once every 125 years."

The Fifa spokesman Keith Cooper last night suggested Europe might be given some form of "special status" because of its position at the forefront of the game. Cooper said: "Certain continents are very small and have very limited resources. For example, there would be little point in constantly going back to Australia just to uphold the principle of rotating."

The decision to rotate was taken by Fifa's executive committee which met in Zurich to discuss issues around the World Cup and the fallout from South Africa's failure to secure the 2006 tournament. Fifa's general secretary Michel Zen Ruffinen said yesterday that South Africa's request for arbitration had been des-cribed as "inappropriate" by the Fifa president Sepp Blatter, who said the decision was final.

Fifa's next World Club Championship is to take place in the summer of 2001 in Spain. The tournament will feature 12 teams, four more than this year's event in Brazil.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Yes, yes, another great success for the Diary. Honestly, I hate blowing my own trumpet, but please don't say we didn't warn you. As I wrote on May 24: "Any possibility of Gordon Brown launching a counterstrike against the enemy with a baby of his own appears to have evaporated. According to sources exceedingly close to the weirdo chancellor, Gordon and Sarah Macaulay, the woman Charlie Whelan assured us he would marry, have split up."
fields.body:
 Yes, yes, another great success for the Diary. Honestly, I hate blowing my own trumpet, but please don't say we didn't warn you. As I wrote on May 24: "Any possibility of Gordon Brown launching a counterstrike against the enemy with a baby of his own appears to have evaporated. According to sources exceedingly close to the weirdo chancellor, Gordon and Sarah Macaulay, the woman Charlie Whelan assured us he would marry, have split up."

How uncanny those words sound today - especially the quote from a close political ally that "they've just grown apart". Others might have left it there - but oh no, not us. Two days later we were back, dismissing denials of the story and calling for a polygraph to be sent to the Treasury. "This column has been wrong, often spectacularly, about almost everything for five years," I wrote. "Not this time (we think)." Marvellous work from the Diary You Know You Can Safely Ignore.

 In recent months, according to the Daily Mail, "a series of newspaper reports had suggested the relationship had gone off the boil. They may well have been part of a deliberate smokescreen.". Yes, that's it. We were manipulated by the sinister spin machine. It wasn't sloppiness and gross incompetence, just naivety. So that's all right, then.

 In the wake of this development, Diary pundit Steptoe asks for extra time to make his book on the "If Mr Tony Stopped A Bus" stakes. The world's leading canine soothsayer had Gordon as an odds-on chance at 8/11, but he will shorten when the West Highland terrier reforms his market. Also postponed is a racy extract for Paul Daniels's Under No Illusion - most inappropriate on so romantic a day.

 Equally inappropriate would be the nasty story of revenge taken by a dentist in Melbourne, Australia, against his wife. He tied her to a chair and performed eight hours of root canal work on her teeth - without anaesthetic. Brian Sutherland's case comes up in court next month. "She deserved every minute of it. I hope the judge sees it that way too," said Sutherland. I suspect not.

 It's no surprise that the Blairs were not in church yesterday - not because of the tensions between Mr T and Gordon, but because Cherie loathes the chancellor, blaming him for the emergence of the O'Mandy Mandelson home loan story. Then again, it might be because it was a private service for family and non-political friends. How the hell would I know?

 Moving on, lest the self-congratulation becomes cloying, we gather Channel 4 is looking for people for a special journalist series of Big Brother. So far Libby Purves, Richard Littlejohn, Janet Street-Porter, Lord Rees-Mogg, Dominic Mohan (the Sun's penis size obsessed showbiz man) and Melanie Phillips have all agreed to live in the east end house for 10 weeks, but four more volunteers are required. Applications may be sent to us in the first instance.

 Having allowed a meaningless one-day tournament to ruin the Test series with the West Indies, the England and Wales Cricket Board contrives its coup de grace for next July. For the first time it has scheduled the highlight of the cricketing summer, the Ashes Test at Lord's, directly against the British Open. Half the MCC members will be at the golf, while Australian network, Channel 9, which carries full Open coverage, is livid. Denying deliberate sabotage, EWCB corporate affairs director John Reid insists that the cricket will hold its own against Tigermania. Of course, of course. The only mistake, in fact, with the 2001 Open at Lytham, near Blackpool, is not swapping the Lord's and Manchester Tests.

 Finally, we wish Gordon and Sarah every happiness, and look forward to the arrival of the twins early next February. Just a little joke, to go with the P45.

fields.headline: Gough reigns between showers
fields.standfirst: West Indies 87 for 4 (close)
fields.trailText: If there were doubts existing as to whether England could recapture the adrenalin-charged cricket that swept them to victory in the second Test, they were dispelled here yesterday on a rain-interrupted first day of only 42 overs that left West Indires on 87-4.
fields.body:
If there were doubts existing as to whether England could recapture the adrenalin-charged cricket that swept them to victory in the second Test more than a month ago, they were dispelled here yesterday on a rain-interrupted first day of only 42 overs.

West Indies will resume today on 87 for four and in trouble as Darren Gough produced one of the finest spells of his international life, finally gaining reward for persistence, skill, planning and downright aggression by dismissing Brian Lara, the fulcrum of West Indies' batting. Only in the evening sunlight were the seeds of recovery sown with an unbroken fifth-wicket stand of 38 between Jimmy Adams and Ramnaresh Sarwan.

Gough's magnificent effort brought him two for 37 from his 15 overs. The support was forthright if less spectacular, with Andy Caddick catching Adrian Griffiths indeterminate in front of his stumps and firing the ball time after time across the left-handed Wavell Hinds and past his outside edge. Hinds, given out caught at the wicket off Dominic Cork's bowling, was, not for the first time this summer, a shade unlucky, if the television snickometer is to be believed.

The day had an unpromising beginning. Overnight rain had bounced high from the Manchester pavements, rendering the outfield unplayable until midday. No soggy run-ups nor leaden skies, however, could dampen the poignancy of the ceremony to recognise the achievement of Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart in reaching 100 Test matches. More may have been made of the Queen Mum's century but, give or take the odd magazine supplement, it has been a close-run thing. The presentation yesterday, in front of the pavilion, gave each a couple of pieces of engraved glassware and a special cap with "100" embossed beneath the England crest.

West Indies had announced their team on Wednesday evening, with Sarwan coming in for the injured Shivnarine Chanderpaul. England, though, had preferred to keep their cards closer to the chest, waiting until just before the toss before announcing that Robert Croft would be playing and that Graeme Hick was to be the man to stand down. The inclusion, therefore, of Marcus Trescothick and Graham Thorpe means that, notwithstanding the experiment of 12 central contracts, the number of England players in this summer stands at 18. Only seven of those on central contracts are in this match. Hick's international career once more seems in jeopardy.

Nasser Hussain would have thought he could not lose as he walked out to toss but the outcome produced its own shock. Bowling first is so much a part of the West Indian strategy that Hussain might well have thought he misheard when Adams called correctly and opted to do the opposite, something they tend to do only when the moon is blue and there is toboganning in the streets of Bridgetown.

Any thoughts of West Indies seizing back the initiative were dispelled in the hour's play before lunch. Caddick eased himself back into the series gingerly, mindful perhaps of some soft areas in his run-up, sawdusted so it looked as if his boots exploded as he landed in them, but Gough tore in from the opening ball and allowed no respite thereafter.

His second over brought an early result as Sherwin Campbell produced an angled bat and edged a catch low to the right of Thorpe, who took a difficult catch at third slip with aplomb. Griffiths followed three overs later, when he shuffled in front to Caddick.

The real theatre came as Gough confronted Lara, who was either jaundiced or wearing yellow light-enhancing shades beneath the grille of his batting helmet. Other bowlers have troubled Lara, most notably Glenn McGrath, who has dismissed him 10 times, and Angus Fraser, seven. But they have employed attrition. Gough, as at Edgbaston, rattled him, bounding in, bowling genuinely fast on a slowish surface, bouncing him so that Lara was forced to sway jerkily out of the way (strange how he does not hook), forcing him back and then pitching the ball full to invite the drive, slanting the ball across him or swinging it back for variety.

Lara survived for more than an hour and a half, twice swatting the ball away over gully to the boundary when given too much width. But his other 73 balls produced only five runs.

Lara had been shackled and worked over, and he was finally dismissed when a thickish outside edge was snaffled by Thorpe at third slip. Brilliant.

webTitle: Leader: Gordon Brown and Sarah Macaulay managed to marry in private.

fields.headline: A private romance
fields.standfirst: Gordon and Sarah did it their way
fields.trailText: You have to hand it to Gordon Brown and Sarah Macaulay. In this age of media omnipresence, where Big Brother spies on couples in the shower and where Hello! gawps at the bedrooms of the famous, they have managed to keep a private moment almost completely private. Not for them a Posh 'n' Becks tidal wave of advance publicity.
fields.body:
You have to hand it to Gordon Brown and Sarah Macaulay. In this age of media omnipresence, where Big Brother spies on couples in the shower and where Hello! gawps at the bedrooms of the famous, they have managed to keep a private moment almost completely private. Not for them a Posh 'n' Becks tidal wave of advance publicity.

Instead, the couple sought a wedding ceremony for nobody but themselves, their families and their closest friends. It was not just the newspapers they wanted to keep away: they noticeably refused to use their nuptials as the backdrop for a starry political media event. It could have been the party of the year, packed with cabinet bigwigs and celebrity chums. Instead they got married in Gordon's front room in Fife - and not even the Blairs were there.

In the event, the couple were denied the complete, budget-style purdah they had clearly sought. The parish announcement of the engagement had gone unnoticed for two weeks: one more day and the wedding would have been over before we had heard so much as a word about it. But the Daily Record got wind of it and so there were snappers and scribblers outside the Brown residence to demand a (slightly awkward) kiss from the newly weds. Still, that was a small concession to public interest in what was a refreshingly unshowy event.

What will the impact be for the groom, whose single status had been remarked upon, often unkindly, for so long? It may neuter the Tory charge that the chancellor is unable to budget for Britain's families because he has none of his own. It may also enable Mr Brown to shake off the austere, flinty image that has dogged him since taking on high office. Perhaps the public will now see in Gordon Brown what others have seen in private - a warm, witty man whose interest in life is not confined to expenditure rates and inflation targets. He and his bride make a fine couple - and we wish them the very best of luck.

webTitle: Blow for part-timers who missed deadline

fields.headline: Blow for part-timers who missed deadline
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Part-time workers could be in line for a £17bn backdated payout from employers who denied them a pension. But although at least 60,000 union-backed claimants will benefit, hundreds of thousands more face a near impossible struggle to claim a share of the bonanza.
fields.body:
Newspaper headlines screamed this week that part-time workers could be in line for a £17bn backdated payout from employers who denied them the right to a pension. But although at least 60,000 union-backed claimants will benefit, hundreds of thousands more who might have qualified face a near impossible struggle to claim a share of the bonanza.

Some pension advisers acting for big employers suggest that the payouts could be just a fraction of the £17bn claimed by the unions, with one suggesting that the final bill will be just £100m, or just a drop in the £850bn ocean of money invested in UK pensions.

The payouts follow a European Court of Justice ruling this week that settled a long-running dispute over part-time workers' rights. A 1994 case had given part-time workers the right to entry into a company pension scheme, but had left it unclear how far back they could date their claims. This week's ruling sets 1976 - the year when the relevant European legislation came into force in the UK - as the start date for claims.

Unions scored a victory in the Luxembourg court by claiming that pension schemes were guilty of sex discrimination, because the vast majority of part-timers refused entry into company pensions were women. TUC general secretary John Monks said: "Before this week's ruling, many of the part-time workers affected by past pensions discrimination - the majority of whom are women - faced a very uncertain future. Now, thanks to Europe, they can look forward to a much more comfortable and secure retirement."

The unions, through mailings to members, had put up 60,000 industrial tribunal claims and took 22 test cases to the European Court. But initial hopes after the judgment that hundreds of thousands more might benefit have been dashed.

The principal problem is that any part-time worker will only qualify if they have put in an industrial tribunal claim within six months of leaving employment. So someone who, say, worked from 1982-1988 part-time but did not put in a claim six months after 1988 cannot now make a claim.

A fightback by employers has also already started. The near impossibility of tracing many former employees and their pay records back to 1976 will cut out thousands of potential beneficiaries. William Mercer, one of the biggest advisers to employers on pension schemes, said employers are also likely to go to court to alter the European ruling to apply the British limitation period of just six years of backdating.

The broken employment patterns of the typical part-time worker will also limit the size of payouts. "Among Britain's six million part-timers, only one in 10 is likely to have five years' service due to high staff turnover. Probably only a quarter stay with the same employer for more than two years - the minimum usually needed to qualify for preserved benefits under UK occupational pension schemes," said David Marshland of William Mercer.

Relief at the end of a five-year rights battle

Midland Bank expected complete flexibility from part-time cashier Rachel Harrison at its Leamington Spa branch in the late 70s and early 80s, one week asking her to work two days, the next week five, writes Patrick Collinson. But at no time did they tell her that, unlike full-time colleagues, none of her hard work would count towards a pension.

Yesterday Mrs Harrison, 61, was celebrating the end of a five-year legal battle, waged by her union, Unifi, against Midland and other banks which banned part-time workers from joining their generous pension schemes until 1989, and which have fought tooth and nail to avoid back-dating payments.

"It's absolutely wonderful news for myself and other part-time workers. They expected me to be totally flexible, but were completely inflexible when it came to the pension. I was loyal, worked hard and knew I was popular with the customers. But it seemed to count for nothing," says Mrs Harrison, who was one of the test cases taken to the European Court of Justice.

Midland pays Mrs Harrison a £35 per week pension to cover the 11 years that she worked full-time before she was made redundant, but nothing for her seven years of part-time service. Money has been so tight that she has taken a £90 per week part-time job at Warwick Hospital to supplement the small pension paid to her husband, who cannot work through illness.

She is now waiting to hear how much extra she will gain - negotiations will take months - and hopes it will allow her to retire next year. But it will hardly pay for a rich retirement. "All our money is spent pretty quickly. I just hope this is going to help out a bit," says Mrs Harrison.

The history

1972 Equal Pay Act passed. Disappointment that Act failed to include pensions.

1976 Defene v Sabena establishes that equal pay for men and women is enforceable under EEC law, but no arrears of pay is required before April 1976.

1986 Bilka Kaufhaus case. Establishes that exclusion of part-time workers from pension schemes is discriminatory because majority of part-timers are women.

1986-89 UK employers gradually withdraw ban on pension scheme entry for part-timers.

1990 Barber v GRE. Pension benefits must be equal for men and women, but allows for no back-dating of claims for prior years.

1994 Coloroll case. Limits backdating of part-time pension claims to two years in UK.

1995 Unions take thousands of claims to industrial tribunals. Lose in Birmingham test case.

1996 Unions go to Court of Appeal. Defeated again. Appeal to House of Lords.

1997 European court rules favourably on Magorrian part-time pensions case in Ireland.

1998 House of Lords refers 22 union test cases, representing 60,000 workers, to European court to clarify Magorrian ruling.

2000 European Court rules that part-time pension benefits should be back-dated to 1976.

The helplines

Union members who believe they may qualify for an enhanced pension should contact their local union branch for guidance. The head offices and websites for the unions principally involved are:

 Unifi (bank, finance workers) www.unifi.org.uk, tel 020-8946-9151.

 National Union of Teachers www.teachers.org.uk, tel 020-7388-6191.

 Unison (public sector, health workers) www.unison.org.uk, tel 0800-707077.

fields.headline: Private medical insurance
fields.trailText: Being a gay man or a lesbian should make absolutely no difference when looking for private medical insurance.
fields.body:
Being a gay man or a lesbian should make absolutely no difference when looking for private medical insurance.

However, no company will offer cover for treatment as a result of you being or becoming HIV positive and developing Aids.

Currently, treatment for Aids is available on the NHS.

However, no company will offer cover for treatment as a result of you being or becoming HIV positive and developing Aids. Currently, treatment for Aids is available on the NHS.

fields.headline: Harvesting a heritage
fields.trailText: Mighty Mo Rodgers Jazz Café, London ***
fields.body:
Mighty Mo Rodgers Jazz Café, London ***

Blues pianist Mighty Mo Rodgers has a simple mission: "I began writing this album because I didn't like what I was hearing," he growled into his microphone to a sadly half-empty Jazz Café. Like Taj Mahal's work with Toumani Diabate, Rodgers explores the way that blues has a common heritage, from Africa to America. Tonight, dressed in a black-and-white chequered West African cloak, Rodgers wanted to make pretty damn sure we didn't forget the legacy. After browbeating us with a few quips about the state of music today, he settled into the groove of Heaven's Got the Blues, ably supported by a brilliant group of musicians.

His passionate stance is both a style and an ideal, celebratory and educational. But he urges us - singing in his gritty, expressive voice, peering over his sunglasses at the audience - not to forget that blues arose from terrible situations.

A fixture on the blues scene of Los Angeles, Rodgers was a former sideman of T-Bone Walker, Albert Collins and Bobby Blue Bland, and his musical cornerstone has always been honky-tonk blues. Surprisingly, it took him more than 30 years to record his own album. Self-produced, arranged and recorded, his debut, Blues Is My Wailing Wall, is blues with elements of southern soul, ballads and African jazz. Old-fashioned without being polite, the album earned him a WC Handy nomination for best new blues artist and this gig was our first taste of the Rodgers experience.

He pulled no punches, laying into materialism and racism ("You want a BMW, well I'm a black male worker"), while bashing out glorious piano solos. "This song is about the disgusting syphilis experiments on black men that began in the 30s in Tuskegee, Alabama," was his introduction to the gentle and affecting Tuskegee Blues. A languid mixture of fatal longings and supernatural forces, this wonderful song was hard to forget even as the band moved on to the upbeat Took Away the Drum.

Loose studio jams were turned into even looser, cyclical grooves, but it was never sloppy. Rodgers is the leader and his band were well rehearsed enough to know when to pull back.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Banks lead the way lower
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ever since the flurry of building society demutalisations in 1997, pundits have predicting consolidation in the mortgage bank industry.
fields.body:
Ever since the flurry of building society demutalisations in 1997, pundits have predicting consolidation in the mortgage bank industry.

Without the scale to churn out products at low cost, smaller players such as Alliance & Leicester - down 19p at 473p - and Northern Rock - 8.75p weaker at 360.25p - have long been cited as the most obvious contenders for the mating game.

But over recent days talk of an agreed deal for Woolwich - off 2.5p at 254.5p - has refused to go away. An interested bidder cannot go hostile because it is protected from such action for a further two years.

Although its shares closed lower yesterday this was against the background of a weak banking sector hit by unfounded fears of a government windfall tax, and turnover reached a chunky 4m thanks to what dealers were describing as educated buying.

Ever since unconfirmed merger discussions with Alliance & Leicester broke down, Woolwich has been regarded as an attractive target.

On Wednesday its chief executive, John Stewart, refused to close the door on future merger talks as he announced interim figures.

While Bank of Scotland - 23.5p lower at 547 - has often been touted as a potential partner, such talk appears to be wide of the mark.

The story doing the rounds yesterday afternoon had Barclays - 59p easier at £15.56 - as the interested partner.

This could make sense. Woolwich would give Barclays a much-needed boast in the mortgage market and bolster its claims to be a "big bank".

Leading shares generally had a tough day undermined by weakness in the technology and banking sectors.

The FTSE 100 index ended 74.2 points lower at 6,317.1 - representing a five-week low - with investors paying little attention to news that interest rates remain on hold.

Technology stocks were under pressure from the outset. Initially unsettled by the weak close on the Nasdaq, which followed rumours of a Cisco Systems profit warning, they were then hit by a profit warning from US chip firm Kulicke & Soffa and speculation that Motorola had changed its outlook for mobile handset shipments.

Predictably, ARM Holdings, which derives most its revenue from mobile telephony, was the worst affected, shedding 87p to 631p. Optical chip outfit Bookham Technology was also hit, falling 229p to £36 as was Marconi, 55p weaker at 972p. Meanwhile, Sage Group slipped 39.5p to 492.5p, CMG lost 82p to £10.90 and Sema retreated 66p to 942p.

Eidos, the FTSE 250 company behind Lara Croft, managed to buck the weaker trend. It shares closed 16p better at 396p and once again the rise was related to hopes of a takeover from French company Infogrames.

But the nightmare for Telewest Communications investors continued.

The share shed a further 19.25p lower at 155.75p, despite news with interim figures that a shortage of set-top boxes will only delay its digital service by three months.

Among the second liners, photo-booth operator Photo-Me International, down 49p to 120p, was the talk of the session after it issued the statement which all investors dread - an accountancy-related profit warning.

On a lighter note, one City trader was left with a red face after acquiring 56m shares in concrete company RMC - down 7p to 738p.

The trade was immediately cancelled by the stock exchange authorities after the dealer owned up and said he had actually been trying to buy 5,600 RMC shares but had entered the decimal point in the wrong place.

Elsewhere, Telework Group made a solid debut on the stock market yesterday. Shares in the group, which supplies and develops software to the computer telephony and human resources industries, closed at 208p, up 63.5p from their issue price.

fields.headline: Scandal of hidden fees
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Forget all you read about annual unit trust and open ended investment company (OEICs) expenses. For new research shows annual costs can be far greater than the published figures - in some cases by as much as a third. And that can have a major impact on returns.
fields.body:
Forget all you read about annual unit trust and open ended investment company (OEICs) expenses.

For new research shows annual costs can be far greater than the published figures - in some cases by as much as a third. And that can have a major impact on returns.

But the fund management company cited as Britain's most expensive has hit back, claiming its figures are inflated by one-off costs.

Figures from Fitzrovia International, a specialist in analysing the figures behind fund management, suggest that the actual costs are always greater than the published annual fund management expenses ratio. This is due to other operating charges such as administration, custody, trustee, legal and audit fees which come directly from the fund rather than from the yearly cost.

Adding all these figures together gives the total expense ratio, TER. The gap between the average TER for a fund group and the annual management charge varies enormously. It can be as little as 0.04% or as much as 0.69%.

As most of these extra charges are fixed, economies of scale should mean they have a greater percentage impact on groups with smaller funds rather than the giants of the industry.

But while the Fitzrovia figures show that tiny unit trust groups such as Morgan Stanley Dean Witter or Mayflower figure in the bottom 10 UK groups, the giant Jupiter is second from bottom with average net assets per fund at £350m. It has a 2.19% TER - more than four times the Equitable Life's chart topping 0.5% total. The average Equitable fund is worth £335m.

Fitzrovia chief executive Paul Moulton says he has taken all the figures from published annual accounts.

He says: "The information is there for fund owners but most throw the documentation away without reading it. But what the accounts do not give is a comparative figure so investors do not know whether they are getting a good deal or not."

Fitzrovia claims expenses are a vital part of the picture. Moulton says there is no correlation between high charges and good fund performance. But high charges are a "drag". A £5,000 stake in a trust growing 10% each year would be worth £12,969 in a no-charge fund after 10 years, £12,391 in a 0.5% fund but just £10,305 if annual charges hit 2.5%.

Premier Asset Management holds up the Fitzrovia table with total 2.22% costs. But Premier's Peter Atkins believes this is unfair: "We are a smaller management house so we don't get economies of scale. However, we inherited a fund with very high charges. We immediately cut them but the old fees were in the report as it was prepared under the previous owners. Many of the other funds they have chosen have special reasons why they were expensive over the past year such as the once and for all conversion to OEICs."

fields.headline: Isas
fields.trailText: Individual savings accounts (Isas) can bring tax relief on cash, stocks and shares and even insurance savings.
fields.body:
Individual savings accounts (Isas) can bring tax relief on cash, stocks and shares and even insurance savings.

The Isa replaced Personal equity plans (Peps) and Tax exempt special savings accounts (Tessas) which stopped being offered in April 1999.

All the interest and other gains on money earned within an Isa are tax free. This is particularly good news for people in the higher income 40% tax bracket.

Investors can put up to £7,000 worth of stocks and shares into a maxi Isa, or put £3,000 into a cash Isa and £1,000 into an insurance Isa.

Check out the Isas explained section in our Advice Bank for further details.

webTitle: Bank holds rates steady for sixth month in a row

fields.headline: Bank holds rates steady for sixth month in a row
fields.trailText: The Bank of England left interest rates on hold for the sixth month in a row yesterday, but City analysts said it was too soon to conclude that borrowing costs had peaked after new figures showed the service sector grew robustly last month.
fields.body:
The Bank of England left interest rates on hold for the sixth month in a row yesterday, but City analysts said it was too soon to conclude that borrowing costs had peaked after new figures showed the service sector grew robustly last month.

The decision to keep rates at 6% was greeted with widespread relief from industry and union groups.

"This will help soothe fears that manufacturing could slip back into a downturn," said Kate Barker, chief economist at the Confederation of British Industry.

"But companies across the economy will need longer term respite as they struggle to compete in tough foreign markets."

Manufacturing representatives blame high borrowing costs for forcing up the pound and pricing British exports out of foreign markets.

"We are pleased the MPC has listened to industry rather than the alarmist voices in the City," said Brendan Barber, deputy general secretary of the Trades Union Congress. "The MPC's decision is both responsible and realistic."

European firms and homeowners were also spared a rise in borrowing costs after the European Central Bank left rates unchanged yesterday at 4.25%.

Although a majority of analysts were expecting British rates to be held steady, conflicting signals about the direction of the economy made the outcome of yesterday's meeting particularly hard to call.

Since the Bank's monetary policy committee last met, official figures revealed robust growth in the second quarter of the year, and lower unemployment. But wage inflation has moderated and the housing market appears to be cooling down.

The latest snapshot of the services sector, released just ahead of the MPC's decision yesterday showed a further strong expansion.

The business activity index rose to 58 in July, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply. Readings above 50 indicate the sector is expanding and analysts said yesterday's figures was consistent with a quarterly growth rate of about 1%.

webTitle: FSa puts the Cat among the pigeons

fields.headline: FSa puts the Cat among the pigeons
fields.standfirst:
A new report from the financial services authority states that stocks and shares Isas can be a better bet, says Patrick Collinson
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A new report from the Financial Services Authority states that stocks and shares Isas can be a better bet.
fields.body:
It's official - don't lock your money away in a personal pension, buy a low-charge stocks and shares Isa instead. The government's financial watchdog, the Financial Services Authority shocked the pensions industry this week with a report which blows the lid off expensive personal pension plans.

Pensions have attractive tax breaks - the money you pay in is free of tax, worth 22% for a basic rate taxpayer - but that benefit is almost exactly wiped out by the charges levied by pension companies.

The picture is even worse if, like four out of 10 investors, you cancel your personal pension after five years. A £60 per month plan is worth £16,624 after five years if investments rise at 7%, but on average you lose £6,324 (38% of the total) in charges, leaving your fund worth just £10,300.

The figures come from a report issued by the Financial Services Authority's central policy unit and are, therefore, completely independent of the bias common among both pension and Isa sellers.

The authors, Malcolm Cook and Paul Johnson, conclude: "We find that, despite the slightly more generous tax treatment available to pensions, a basic rate taxpayer can expect a greater return from investing in a CAT-standard Isa than in a median charge personal pension if the underlying investment return is the same."

The report found that for every £100 of investment return produced by a CAT-standard Isa, the average personal pension produced £99. If the plans are cancelled after five years, the Isa gives £100 compared to the pension's £83. The balance is tilted even more in favour of Isas because they have greater flexibility than pensions.

The report says: "Any money one puts in an Isa can be accessed as and when required, with no restrictions on how it is then used or invested. By contrast, pension monies can be accessed only after age 50 and then three-quarters of them have to be converted into an annuity.

"So faced with a choice between an Isa and a pension, each of which promised a return of 100, one would have a clear incentive to choose an Isa," the authors say.

But before the unit trust industry starts crowing about their low charges compared to pensions, the report contains some important caveats.

The only Isas to beat average personal pensions are those which are CAT-marked - the ones which meet the government's cost, access and terms standards - and only a few do. Indeed, the average unit trust comes out worse in the survey than the average pension.

Higher rate taxpayers, who enjoy 40% tax relief on their pension contributions, also do better than Isa holders over the longer term.

The pensions which are slated are personal pensions, not occupational pensions, which are almost guaranteed to outstrip Isas by a wide margin because of the impact of employers' contributions. Additional voluntary contributions on company pensions are also far more attractive that taking out an Isa.

Axa Sun Life, a major pension seller, adds that the figures should be treated cautiously. Head of pensions development Paul Smith says: "It will not always be right in each and every case that an Isa is better. It depends on the terms and conditions of each policy, the company that runs it, the actual investment performance and so on.

"And while Isas are flexible, that can work both ways. With an Isa you may be tempted to cash it in early to access the money, leaving you with no retirement income at all."

The authors of the FSA report stress that the picture will change dramatically when stakeholder pensions become available in April next year. Because stakeholder pensions will have a maximum annual charge of 1%, compared to 4%-5% on some high charge personal pensions, they will offer investors the best returns.

The FSA projects that a £60 per month stakeholder pension will pay out £40,392 after 25 years (assuming 7% investment growth), compared to £37,200 for the average personal pension.

"Introducing stakeholders with tightly defined charging criteria could potentially be an important step in increasing the relative attractiveness of pension saving. But whether stakeholder pensions will provide enough incentive for those who do not want to save remains open to question," conclude the authors.

webTitle: Fears over relaunch of lastminute.com dismissed

fields.headline: Fears over relaunch dismissed
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com's failure to update the market on the delayed relaunch of its website yesterday overshadowed otherwise solid set of results from the domestic internet sector's highest profile company.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com's failure to update the market on the delayed relaunch of its website yesterday overshadowed otherwise solid set of results from the domestic internet sector's highest profile company.

Gross transaction value, operating loss and customer numbers - the three yardsticks by which the stock market measured Lastminute's progress - were in line with analyst expectations.

However, some analysts were concerned about Lastminute's reluctance to update them on the launch of version 2 of its website.

Shares in Lastminute slipped 3.5p to 151p during a day when technology shares were hit hard by jitters on Nasdaq. Lastminute floated in March at 380p per share.

Chief executive Brent Hoberman said that the month-long delay did not mean Lastminute was experiencing technology problems. It just wanted to be "absolutely certain" the website was robust enough to cope with the 2m subscribers registered to use it.

"We won't put the site up until we are absolutely sure that it can take the phenomenal load of hits you would expect from what has become Europe's second most visited internet retail site," he said. "We don't want to be hostages to fortune."

Geoff Ruddell of Deutsche Bank said he was concerned by Mr Hoberman's reluctance to indicate if the launch was days, weeks or months away.

"The new website is crucial in converting site visitors into customers and making the whole user experience more effective," Mr Ruddell said. "If visitors can't get into the site or find it too slow they tend to go away and may not come back."

Lastminute says the new site will allow late deals to be targeted according to users' personal tastes. The current website, built in the early days of Lastminute.com, has been outgrown and some surfers experience difficulty using it.

In the three months to June 30, total transaction value increased 34% on the previous quarter to £9.6m. Turnover was £1.01m. Pre-tax losses narrowed from £11m to £9.2m. July sales had been "phenomenal", Mr Hoberman said. "We are not concerned about our cash burn rate, we have £117m in the bank and the City says that is more than enough to take us through to profitability."

Lastminute continues in its talks with BSkyB over access to the broadcaster's digital television platform but it is thought the two parties are disputing the level of margin BSkyB demands.

The satellite company is understood to take 8% of the value of all transactions made over its digital TV service.

fields.headline: Writing a will
fields.trailText: For gay people it is particularly important to ensure assets are distributed according to their wishes.
fields.body:
For gay people it is particularly important to ensure assets are distributed according to their wishes.

This is because only married couples are recognised in the eyes of the law. Gay partners, no matter how long they have been together, do not count.

Unless you write a will specifically pointing out how your estate should be shared, cash may automatically go to surviving members of your family.

Writing a will is not as difficult as you might imagine and can be done without the help of a solicitor.

Pick up a will form from a stationery shop as this helps as a guideline to format and the sort of details required.

Pitfalls to avoid include sharing assets equally among the family. Be specific - your idea of family may differ from that of the law's - and give a full breakdown of your assets.

You must then sign the document in front of two witnesses, neither of whom can benefit from the will.

fields.headline: E-crisis claims brokerage
fields.standfirst: Online mortgage firm fails in hunt for funding
fields.trailText: The bursting of the dot.com bubble claimed another casualty yesterday when the first online mortgage broker to set up in Britain closed after failing to secure funding it needed.
fields.body:
The bursting of the dot.com bubble claimed another casualty yesterday when the first online mortgage broker to set up in Britain closed after failing to secure funding it needed.

Independent Mortgage Brokers, which was founded in 1997, officially ceased trading yesterday. The Kent-based firm was started by managing director Anthony Webb in his spare bedroom and by December last year had grown into a company valued at more than £14m and employing 25 staff.

A spokesman said it had made approaches to venture capitalists and investment houses but the funding sought was not forthcoming.

The company had been operating profitably since 1997 and in terms of volume of sales it was "up there with the big boys", he said. Earlier this year it was arranging close to £5m worth of loans a month.

However, it was looking to raise funds to expand so it could move to larger premises and take on more staff. It had also been trying to secure a partnership with a new financial services provider. When this failed to materialise, the cost of delay proved unsustainable and Mr Webb made the decision to wind up the company.

The spokesman blamed the internet climate - the downturn in investors' sentiment which has seen tech stock prices plummet. He also highlighted the flood of online mortgage brokers on to the market recently.

The British launch in January of US-based E-Loan, the self-proclaimed global market leader in online mortgages, was swiftly followed by NetMortgage (the online service of broker Savills Private Finance), Creditweb and many others.

webTitle: Barclays rides storm and doubles its money

fields.headline: Barclays rides storm and doubles its money
fields.trailText: Barclays is selling more products to existing customers as well as winning new ones despite the storm over branch closures, cash machine charges, top pay and security breaches at its online bank.
fields.body:
Barclays is selling more products to existing customers as well as winning new ones despite the storm over branch closures, cash machine charges, top pay and security breaches at its online bank.

As the bank reported a doubling in pre-tax profits over the first six months to £1.8bn from its retail, corporate, investment banking and asset management operations, it set out a goal to expand its share of mortgages and life assurance. It did not rule out making acquisitions to achieve this.

The improvement in profits came the day before the Treasury was expected to announce the establishment of a new regulator in its response to the Don Cruickshank investigation into banking competition.

Matt Barrett, Barclays' chief executive, admitted that he would be "less than candid if I didn't say that I don't welcome the idea of another regulatory bureaucracy piled on top of what we already have". He insisted the bank had an "open mind" about the universal bank the government wants to establish in post offices. Rivals have criticised the plan. Barclays will also meet guidelines to set up basic accounts for the socially excluded by the October deadline.

However, the jump in profits prompted criticism from Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman Vince Cable, who said that it was "alarming that socially irresponsible banking, including the closure of a large part of the branch network, has been so generously rewarded".

Mr Barrett, who took over as chief executive in October, promised "more customer-friendly initiatives" as he claimed one in five current account customers now own three products or more, up from one in six last year.

Mr Barrett described the recent public relations mishaps as "bumps on the road". In the first half of the year, 4,000 people quit the bank - which is shedding staff to cut costs - including losses as a result of the sale of fleet car leasing arm Dial. This disposal led to a £178m one-off gain which helped boost the profit.

Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN Amro, said: "At the moment virtually every part of every one of its businesses showed growth. That's very impressive." Despite this, the bank's shares fell by 3.5% to £15.56. It will pay an interim dividend of 20p.

Matt Barrett, Barclays' chief executive, admitted that he would be "less than candid if I didn't say that I don't welcome the idea of another regulatory bureaucracy piled on top of what we already have". He insisted the bank had an "open mind" about the universal bank the government wants to establish in post offices. Rivals have criticised the plan. Barclays will also meet guidelines to set up basic accounts for the socially excluded by the October deadline. However, the jump in profits prompted criticism from Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman Vince Cable, who said that it was "alarming that socially irresponsible banking, including the closure of a large part of the branch network, has been so generously rewarded". Mr Barrett, who took over as chief executive in October, promised "more customer-friendly initiatives" as he claimed one in five current account customers now own three products or more, up from one in six last year. Mr Barrett described the recent public relations mishaps as "bumps on the road". In the first half of the year, 4,000 people quit the bank - which is shedding staff to cut costs - including losses as a result of the sale of fleet car leasing arm Dial. This disposal led to a £178m one-off gain which helped boost the profit. Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN Amro, said: "At the moment virtually every part of every one of its businesses showed growth. That's very impressive." Despite this, the bank's shares fell by 3.5% to £15.56. It will pay an interim dividend of 20p.

fields.headline: Many tricks, few kicks
fields.trailText: Circus Oz Sadler's Wells, London ***
fields.body:
Circus Oz Sadler's Wells, London ***

Revered as pioneers in re- inventing the big top, Circus Oz has been whipping the rug from under the ringmaster for almost 22 years. When it started out, circus still meant a man sticking his head in a lion's mouth (was I the only one who wanted the lion to bite?) and a tradition of hyped-up thrills and spills so locked in a world of its own that Burt Lancaster could wear a pink leotard in the film Trapeze, and not compromise his masculinity.

Times, as they say, have changed. Circus skills have been redeployed, from the Millennium Dome show (its one saving grace) to all manner of dance and theatre productions. Aerial stunts, juggling tricks and every twist of contortion have been turned on their heads and put to greater effect in a dramatic context. Circus Oz can take a great deal of the credit for that.

This may be why its latest visit to London feels a touch old-hat. It's not that the acts aren't good, but that's just what they are: acts. For all the air of artful shambles that cloaks the proceedings, the Circus Oz experience, circa 2000, is not so very far removed from the circuses of yore. The turn does a turn and the master of ceremonies fills the gaps.

It was in the gaps that Circus Oz fell flat. Kate Kantor's puffed-up ringmaster had its moments, but lame gags about the Millennium Bridge and Euan Blair had the air of desperate favour-currying rather than any genuine satirical edge. There is nothing more limp than a topical gag already past its sell-by date.

But buoyed up by an engagingly feelgood Aussie enthusiasm that skilfully steers a fine line between keeping both kids and adults amused - no mean feat - there is no doubting the star quality scattered among the performers. Chief among these is Michael Ling, a bottom-baring high-wire slave (his tricks turned at the behest of a brace of Miss Whiplashes) whose tour de force is a genuinely hair-raising headfirst dive down a scarily tall pole. Also good value is Matt Wilson as the world's most self- effacing stuntman cum cabaret crooner. What these two deserve is a bigger canvas on which to make their mark. Circus Oz may have led the way in putting the new into new circus, but such companies as De La Guarda have overtaken them in leaps and bounds.

Circus Oz is at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020-7863 8000), until August 27.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Ladies night
fields.standfirst: The hardest thing in a smutty sexual harrassment case is to keep a straight face, says our employment tribunal lawyer
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: My long, increasingly hot, summer of smut continues.
fields.body:
My long, increasingly hot, summer of smut continues. I am trying to flatter myself that I am in demand for this stuff because I have become famed for my deadpan delivery (very crucial in smut cases - just try saying "And then you said 'sit on my knob'?" with a straight face in a room full of people taking longhand notes and you will appreciate what a talent this is). However, I think the reality is that there is just a lot of smut about.

This week's smut was out of town, so far out of town I had to get a train up the night before and stay in yet another Alan Partridge-style hotel. My minibar was oppressively full of chocolate (I somehow seemed to rack up a bill for £10 worth of fun-size Kit-Kats without trying) and the police removed someone very loud and pissed from the bridge outside my window at about 3am (oh well, it was too hot to sleep anyway) but otherwise it was ok.

The case itself was about an office where, if you believed the witnesses, everyone had pretty much had everyone else, mostly in public at the Christmas party. The applicant was sacked for sexual harassment of a colleague. He didn't really seem to be denying the sexual harassment. What he seemed to be saying was that it wasn't reasonable to sack him in view of what everyone else in the company, including the harassee, was up to.

Parts of his case were nonetheless opaque. There was, for example, an allegation that the harassee had been involved in "gross indecency" at a works do which sounded a bit like a scene out of Boogie Nights (but with rather less charm). None of my witnesses (on behalf of the company) wanted to explain to me what this might mean. Harassee looked tearful, everyone else just looked away.

But there's no point not knowing the worst of the filth in these cases so I popped off to the applicants' waiting room to talk to the barrister on the other side.

Me: So what is this gross indecency exactly?

Older-style barrister with candyfloss comb-over: Well, it was with a young gentleman in the ladies lavatories, ehmm.

Me: Oh. But what was it? I mean, presumably you are planning to put to her what it actually was in cross-examination?

OSB: Well, yes. I was a little concerned she might not know the technical word, so I have been searching for the appropriate colloquial expression. I think perhaps the best way to put it is "lady's blow job"...

He looks at me uncertainly. What do you say to that? Even the most highly-trained facial muscles might not withstand the stress of wispy comb over asking in his courtly tones about the administration of a lady's blow job.

I am saved by the appearance of some adolescent stringers in the respondents' waiting room. Suddenly the company decides it cannot really face the press interest and we settle up with the applicant. Wispy bids me a hearty and relieved farewell. I toy with sharing with him some more conventional colloquial expressions for the act he was referring to. But it wouldn't really be ladylike.

webTitle: Proms review: Mothers Shall Not Cry.

fields.headline: Wisdom of women
fields.trailText: Mothers Shall Not Cry Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3 ****
fields.body:
Mothers Shall Not Cry Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3 ****

Aftershocks from the Bach anniversary last week continue to pulse through the Proms. Two of his organ works framed Wednesday's programme given by the BBC Symphony Orchestra conducted by Jac van Steen. To start, there was the C Minor Prelude and Fugue in its original form, played on the Albert Hall's elephantine instrument by Martin Neary; and to end, the "St Anne" Prelude and Fugue, in Schoenberg's ebullient but rarely heard orchestration.

Between these slabs of German Protestant counterpoint came an eloquent, intimate account of Brahms's Double Concerto with the immaculately musical violinist Joshua Bell in partnership with cellist Steven Isserlis, and the first performance of a Proms commission from Jonathan Harvey - Mothers Shall Not Cry.

Harvey's brief from the BBC was to compose a "millennium cantata" that embraced the religions of the world. His response is fascinating: a choral work with elements of theatre, which confronts the evils perpetrated by males on the 20th century with "the sort of values that mothers routinely display in their unconditional love and cherishing of their children", as the composer puts it in his programme note.

The 40-minute work opens with a litany of names, innocent victims of countless conflicts, proclaimed by the all-female chorus before the "latent opera", as Harvey calls it, begins.

A soprano soloist offers up Buddhist and Christian pleas for reconciliation, and the clash between male-induced suffering and the liberation that the sacred feminine offers is exemplified by the appearance of the tenor, the Unknown Warrior (Robert Brubaker), singing an aggressive, invented language. His encounter with female wisdom produces reconciliation and the work ends in a ritual chant.

It is tautly organised and the orchestral writing, using sophisticated electronics to project and modulate the sound around the auditorium, is full of finely imagined detail. The writing for the chorus, full of tightly knit canons, occasionally lapses into English choral tradition blandness, but the solo parts are sharply characterised.

Whatever one thinks of the message, Mothers Shall Not Cry works out its theme lucidly, though the amateurish theatrical elements - kitting out Brubaker like a blindfold refugee from Parsifal, giving the soprano (the excellent Susannah Glanville) a diamante tiara and having the orchestra gradually leave the stage during the final section - are an unnecessary distraction. The music and the texts are really what matter.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Royal & Sun fights back
fields.standfirst: Insurer says figures show post-merger recovery
fields.trailText: Royal & Sun Alliance yesterday claimed to be showing progress along its rocky road to recovery after a difficult merger three years ago. Bob Mendelsohn - who during his two-year tenure as chief executive has faced repeated takeover rumours - said: "We've turned a corner in the public's perception."
fields.body:
Royal & Sun Alliance yesterday claimed to be showing progress along its rocky road to recovery after a difficult merger three years ago. Bob Mendelsohn - who during his two-year tenure as chief executive has faced repeated takeover rumours - said: "We've turned a corner in the public's perception."

The insurance group's shares - which have lagged behind the overall market by more than 20% - rose 3% to 430p after it reported a £5m rise in operating profits to £320m in the first six months of the year.

"We're pleased that the market is recognising the enormous step on the journey we've taken to the goals we'd set ourselves," he said. Royal & Sun Alliance has set itself a target to reach an operating ratio - a measure of efficiency - of 103 by 2001, still some distance from the 107.6 level at which it stood yesterday.

Mr Mendelsohn insisted, however, that the insurer would meet that goal and would adopt a "fix or eliminate" on any part of its business which might hinder its achievement.

The group has made a number of acquisitions recently, including Orion in the US and Trygg-Hansa in Scandinavia, and Mr Mendelsohn made it clear that further deals would be considered in its core markets of Britain, the US, Canada, Scandinavia and Australia.

Unlike its rival, CGNU, which revealed this week that it had been battered by storm damage in France, Royal & Sun Alliance took the pain last year, Mr Mendelsohn said. However, he admitted storms in Denmark earlier in the year had cost £5m.

He also said the group had not yet decided whether to begin negotiations with market regulators about how to distribute its £1bn "orphan" estate - as Axa Sun Life recently did, pledging payments to policyholders.

Mr Mendelsohn said that the insurer was able to charge higher premiums in most of the markets in which it operates for the first time in many years. In Britain, however, the higher cost it was charging for motor insurance had led to a 6% fall in its general insurance premiums.

fields.headline: Coventry splash the Keane cash
fields.standfirst: Liverpool part with £2.5m Thompson as Sky Blues flex financial muscle
fields.trailText: Liverpool part with £2.5m Thompson as the Sky Blues flex their financial muscle.
fields.body:
Coventry City last night invested the first chunk of the £13m they received for Robbie Keane on Liverpool's 22-year-old midfielder David Thompson, who signed for £2.5m.

Thompson agreed a four-year contract and will join his new team-mates on their tour of Belgium and Holland. The England Under-21 international had been at Anfield since he was a schoolboy, and the Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson says that he will keep on spending. "He's the first of three specific targets," he said. "Hopefully we'll have some more news over the next week or so."

While Thompson was on his way out of Liverpool, Robbie Fowler was busily dismissing speculation about his future. The striker insisted he would "stay and scrap for a place" up front with Michael Owen and Emile Heskey.

"Every day I'm on my way to a different club," he said. "I'm going to Madrid, Barcelona, Roma, London, Leeds, even Middlesbrough. I'm supposed to be going to cities all over Europe. If I believe everything I hear I should have my passport permanently in my top pocket.

"The fact is I am going nowhere. There is only one city for me and that is Liverpool. In Jamie Redknapp's absence I am stand-in skipper for Liverpool and nothing could make me prouder."

There was further good news for Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier when Markus Babbel announced he was taking a two-year break from international football with Germany to focus on his club career. "That is the most important thing for me at the moment," the 28-year-old said.

In a similar move, the Middlesbrough striker Hamilton Ricard declared himself unavailable for Colombia's World Cup qualifiers. His decision may have been swayed by Alen Boksic, a potential rival up front, arriving on Teesside last night to discuss a move from Lazio. "Colombia may not qualify for the finals," Ricard said. "I don't think they will, and then all those long trips would have been pointless."

A more celebrated South American, Rivaldo, has agreed a much-improved three-year deal to stay at Barcelona. Spanish newspapers estimated the contract to be worth up to 1,100m pesetas (£4.2m) a year. "Barcelona have gone a bit mad to pay this money," said the president Joan Gaspart. "My priority was to make sure Rivaldo was happy."

Airdrie's owner Steve Archibald is trying to bring Hristo Stoichkov, a former European player of the year, to the Scottish First Division club. The pair played together at Barcelona and Archibald said there was "a very real chance" of the Bulgarian joining. Stoichkov, 34, is contracted to the American side Chicago Fire until December.

The Leeds goalkeeper Nigel Martyn has signed a two-year extension to his contract, which now runs until 2004.

Portsmouth have signed the 22-year-old midfielder Nigel Quashie from Nottingham Forest for £600,000 on a three-year contract, their First Division rivals Fulham have taken the France under-21 winger Fabrice Fernandes on loan from Rennes for a year, and Sheffield United will sign the Dutch wing-back Gus Uhlenbeek today. Rangers' 21-year-old midfielder Barry Nicholson has joined Dunfermline for an undisclosed fee.

The former Charlton captain Benny Fenton has died at the age of 81. He served various backroom positions at the Valley after his playing career and also managed Colchester, Leyton Orient and Millwall.

webTitle: England front up to firing squad

fields.headline: England front up to firing squad
fields.standfirst: Hussain seeks to carry on from Lord's against Ambrose and Walsh, writes Mike Selvey
fields.trailText: Nasser Hussain seeks to carry on from Lord's against Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh, writes Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
England and West Indies today pick up the pieces left behind 33 days ago at Lord's when a wild-eyed Dominic Cork hit the runs that squared the series.

The gap, with the subsequent loss of momentum, means in effect that the two teams are contesting a new three-match series, and it has captured the Lancashire public's imagination so much that apparently more people turned up down the road on Tuesday to buy the new Manchester United strip than have pre-booked tickets for the first day.

However, public indifference cannot take the gloss off the achievement of Mike Atherton and Alec Stewart in reaching 100 Tests. Sometime over the next few days, in what England hope will be a seamless transition from the old order to the new, Atherton will walk out to open with the debutant Marcus Trescothick, the burly Somerset left-hander who will become his 13th opening partner - unlucky for some.

Trescothick, identified only last year by the England coach Duncan Fletcher as a batsman of potential, showed during the recent triangular one-day tournament that he has a sound temperament and a technique which is both solid and robust.

After much searching England feel they have found someone to carry on the torch. All he has to do now is succeed against two of the most prolific pace bowlers of all-time, and the chances of him doing so in this match are - if the history books have any relevance - virtually non-existent.

Only six batsmen have made a century against West Indies in their first Test and only two openers: the South African Andrew Hudson and England's Billy Griffith, a wicketkeeper who was picked to open the batting because of injuries. So far, so bad.

Fortunately Nasser Hussain takes the optimistic line that the less something has happened in the past the more likely it is to do so in the future. He does not disguise his belief that Trescothick has all the credentials to succeed.

"He can play," the England captain insisted yesterday, in that understated way sportsmen have of talking about fellow players. "You never know until you are on the biggest stage facing the best bowlers, and he will have two of the best ever coming at him. But from what I've seen of him I think he can play.

"He has got everything he needs technically and in terms of temperament and in the way he is building up. The next stage is how he copes with the mental battle of Test cricket. It's that remaining 10% when you reach that final stage and the world is watching."

No one is under any illusion that it will be easy. Trescothick's one-day successes served notice of a talent but, in the context of what is to come, little else. There was no constant ring of slips, no Ambrose, no Walsh and no chin-music. It will not be so comfortable here with Ambrose, in particular, bowling the tightest of lines and giving him little to drive.

In Trescothick's favour, however, is the full face of the bat he presents to the bowler - he is not one for instinctive and destructive angles to third man - and his ability to play the line and not follow the moving ball.

Just as it was to his advantage to have Stewart with him in the one-dayers, so it will be to have Atherton in the Test. "It is ideal," Hussain said. "It couldn't be better. He will learn a lot, even just sitting around watching Atherton prepare."

Hussain turned prickly yesterday when it was suggested that thrusting a young man in at the top of the order in such an important match was asking for trouble. "I have never played in a Test that is not important," Hussain said indignantly. "He is an opening batsman, get him in there. The sooner he plays, the sooner he faces Walsh and Ambrose, the sooner he becomes a proper Test player and the sooner he is on the road to playing 100 Tests as well. It is quite simple."

Little else is straightforward about the team, however, other than Hussain resuming his position at No3. The captain was giving no clues yesterday as to the composition of the side or the batting order, except that the final place will be between a batsman - probably Graeme Hick - and the frontline spinner Robert Croft.

However, he did point out that the Old Trafford Test pitch tends to play more conservatively than the habitually turning county tracks. In the past three years England spinners have been singularly unsuccessful here, and it may be that Michael Vaughan and Hick will fulfil that role.

West Indies have injury problems, with the exciting 20-year-old left-hander Ramnaresh Sarwan coming in for his third Test instead of Shivnarine Chanderpaul. Despite concerns over the paceman Franklyn Rose and Brian Lara, who is nursing a hamstring strain, both were included in the XI that was announced last night.

West Indies : Adams (capt), Campbell, Griffith, Hinds, Lara, Sarwan, Jacobs (wkt), Ambrose, Rose, King, Walsh. Umpires : DB Cowie, P Willey.

fields.headline: Hollioake meets his match
fields.standfirst: Surrey 191-6 v Lancashire
fields.trailText: Surrey 191-6 v Lancashire.
fields.body:
It is disconcerting for a batsman to look up from his crease and see his double coming in to bowl. Alec and Eric Bedser, who played against each other in a Test trial, knew what it was like.

Yesterday Adam Hollioake, the Surrey captain, had the same feeling. He glanced up and there was his clone, who has assumed the name of Joe Scuderi, scampering in to deliver.

Scuderi has the same scuttling, bandy-legged approach that has been such a feature of the older Hollioake's cricket for some years now. His height, shape and colouring are also identical.

Hollioake, who had pulled round the Surrey innings with a plucky innings that was promising to become something more substantial, was so shocked that he chased a wide delivery and edged to the wicketkeeper Warren Hegg, who took a good catch in front of first slip.

A little earlier Ben Hollioake seemed put off too and was lbw to the same bowler. Those two wickets, just before the tropical, tea-time rain washed out further play, confirmed that Lancashire had won the truncated day.

Lancashire are the most plausible pretenders to Surrey's throne, so this is a real 40-pointer. Surrey lead the table but they failed to win any batting points here on a good pitch while Lancashire picked up two for bowling.

Three of their batsmen, Ian Ward, Alistair Brown and the captain, were out chasing wide deliveries. But Michael Smethurst, who has 41 first-class wickets in his first season, should take some of the credit for Surrey's malady. Smethurst took three wickets in three overs. In fact he had three for no runs in 11 deliveries and finished the day with four for 27 in 15 overs.

Surrey had won the toss. The Lancashire captain John Crawley has now lost the toss on 11 occasions out of 12 in the Championship, which would suggest that he is not really concentrating on the job in hand.

Ward was the first to go, in the 10th over, caught at first slip by Andrew Flintoff. Mark Butcher, who is having a horrid time of it, was out in Smethurst's next over, when he edged to Neil Fairbrother at third slip. And, when Smethurst had Nadeem Shahid lbw, with the batsman only half forward, the first three wickets had fallen with the score on 10, 11 and 12.

Brown took 18 deliveries to get off the mark, then started to play with his old fluency. He raised the fifty partnership with Adam Hollioake when he thumped Gary Keedy for four. At lunch the score was 87 for three from 35 overs. Brown and his skipper had struck so many succulent fours that they looked in the mood to carry the afternoon before them.

But Brown was out when he nibbled at a wide delivery that went wider. His 54 had come from 81 balls and he had struck 11 fours in his usual, fast-handed, eye-catching way.

Ben Hollioake now joined his brother and straight-drove with such timing and power that he suggested his form was returning. He was within sight of his season's best of 29 when he was lbw, playing crookedly to one that straightened.

Adam Hollioake, who had been dropped at mid-on by Glen Chapple on 40, responded by driving Keedy over mid-off for six. Then he cut a short and wide ball from Scuderi for four. The next ball was even wider, but pitched up, and Hollioake pursued and was caught behind.
