webTitle: England outcast fills boots in exile

fields.headline: England outcast fills boots in exile
fields.standfirst: Middlesex 214-5 v Essex
fields.trailText: Middlesex 214-5 v Essex.
fields.body:
As you watch Mark Ramprakash compose a beautifully controlled innings of 84 batting at second wicket down for Middlesex in front of a sprinkling of spectators at Lord's, the question that springs to mind is: "Why is this man not batting at No4 for England at Old Trafford instead?", though the audience in Manchester might not turn out to be much bigger.

Not for the first time in his career, Ramprakash has responded to the despair of being ditched by his country by hitting a purple patch for his county. Since making nought and two as an opener in the last Test here he has reverted to a more familiar position in the Middlesex order and made 300 in his last four championship innings.

Until he prodded with surprising uncertainty at Ashley Cowan yesterday and was caught behind, another century looked as certain as Middlesex not winning promotion from the Second Division this season. Before that, he produced an array of strokes to rival any batsman in the world without a sign of trouble. So why does he never quite bat with the same authority for England? And why has he never been given an extended run at No3 or No4?

But he seems happy to be back where he belongs and in between the showers that dogged yesterday's play he admitted as much.

"When I came back from the Test matches, obviously things hadn't gone well and I had a long chat with Justin [Langer, the Middlesex captain] and Mike Gatting [the coach] and they felt that for the balance of the team they wanted me to bat four. They had Andy Strauss batting well at the top of the order and they wanted to fit Mike Roseberry in as well."

If central contracts have done nothing else they have at least given players who are dropped, such as Ramprakash, the incentive to carry on. In the past, he may have reacted angrily to his rejection but now there is a steely determination to get back in the England side.

"I was very low after the Lord's Test," he said, "but people have been very supportive and it's always a great tonic if you can get a few runs.

"I still feel I could do the job of opener but I had a golden opportunity and unfortunately it hasn't come off. My preparation was good, I felt good when I went to the wicket but I got out on a couple of pitches that I'm sure the bowlers enjoyed bowling on.

"I wouldn't put a line through it and I don't see why batting at No4 for Middlesex should complicate things with England. But I'm happy to bat anywhere and I still feel I have some unfinished business at Test level."

The cricket, like the weather, was pretty indifferent after Ramprakash was out. Essex are still chasing promotion but, against a side with little to play for but pride, they will be disappointed not to have made more of winning the toss on an overcast day.

webTitle: Pollock breaks duck as Sri Lanka fall in a heap to Boje

fields.headline: Pollock breaks duck as Sri Lanka fall in a heap to Boje
fields.trailText: South African cricket turned a new page in a cataclysmic final half-hour in Kandy yesterday, Sri Lanka losing their last four wickets for eight runs to present Shaun Pollock's team with an improbable seven-run win.
fields.body:
South African cricket turned a new page in a cataclysmic final half-hour in Kandy yesterday, Sri Lanka losing their last four wickets for eight runs to present Shaun Pollock's team with an improbable seven-run win.

History is likely to judge the all-rounder's first victory as a Test captain as significant indeed, not just for the perilous margin but for the symbolic dawning of a new South African era of innocent prosperity.

Pollock's side, cleansed of Hansie Cronje and Herschelle Gibbs, has looked a shadow of the ruthlessly efficient unit headed by Cronje. That all changed yesterday and, ironically, the hero was Nicky Boje, himself implicated in alleged match-fixing, who took three for 24 as Sri Lanka failed in their fourth-day pursuit of 177.

On the stroke of tea Boje dismissed Arjuna Ranatunga for 88 from 103 balls - a lone hand, having arrived at the crease in his penultimate Test with the score 21 for four, which some observers praised as his greatest ever innings.

With 16 needed and three wickets left, Sri Lanka panicked: Upul Chandana was bowled by Lance Klusener straight after the break, Chaminda Vaas was run out and Boje had Muthiah Muralitharan caught at the wicket first ball. The series now stands at 1-1. Normality, in South African eyes, has resumed.

There was good news for Australia too when the International Cricket Council ruled that Brett Lee, touted as the world's fastest bowler, does not need to change his action. "I was always very confident but it's good to get that last bit of paper to say there's no problem," said Lee.

Australian officials claimed it was the flawed processes of the ICC, not Lee, which now had a case to answer.

webTitle: Reeve's tale comes to a modest end

fields.headline: Reeve's tale comes to a modest end
fields.standfirst: Somerset 73-3 v Yorkshire
fields.trailText: Somerset 73-3 v Yorkshire.
fields.body:
Dermot Reeve will leave Somerset rather more quietly than he arrived. He will depart at the end of the season to concentrate on his work in the media and Kevin Shine, the former Hampshire, Middlesex and Somerset fast bowler, will be promoted to head coach.

Somerset have never climbed higher than third in the championship table. Reeve, with his radical ideas, renowned motivation and gritted teeth, was going to change all that. In fact, the county have won nothing since he arrived in 1997. What is more, many of the regulars around the boundary have been growing increasingly anxious about his frequent absences from their matches.

He is, however, a busy man. His work as a Channel 4 broadcaster has multiplied, as may other media activities; he remains a popular corporate hospitality and after-dinner speaker.

"I wouldn't criticise Dermot," Peter Anderson, the chief executive, said last night. "We had a pretty cynical dressing-room but he sorted that out and changed the culture of the players who'd been inclined to safe, boring cricket."

Yesterday's play was restricted by rain and 66 overs were lost. Somerset, who had chosen to bat, reached a tormented 73 for three.

Reeve's decision to drift out of coaching was not the only shock. Yorkshire dropped their experienced wicketkeeper Richard Blakey for the first time in his career. His place went to the 21-year-old Simon Guy, making his championship debut.

Matthew Hoggard and Chris Silverwood bowled with much fire and merit. Jamie Cox, still having some difficulty recapturing any of his brio of 1999, was quickly a victim of Silverwood's lift. Then Mark Lathwell lost his leg stump to a fast seaming beauty from Hoggard.

Like Lathwell, Piran Holloway is searching for form. But, just as he appeared to be starting to build an innings, he clipped a catch to square leg.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: The last time Derbyshire entertained Hampshire in the championship both counties' places in the new First Division were at stake and a riveting climax ensued, accompanied by enough allegations of skulduggery to warrant an investigation deploying the combined talents of PC Plod, Dixon of Dock Green, Inspector Clouseau and Dirty Harry.
fields.body:
The last time Derbyshire entertained Hampshire in the championship both counties' places in the new First Division were at stake and a riveting climax ensued, accompanied by enough allegations of skulduggery to warrant an investigation deploying the combined talents of PC Plod, Dixon of Dock Green, Inspector Clouseau and Dirty Harry.

Warwickshire, who consequently went down, will doubtless be amused to see the pair occupying the bottom two places. No less fittingly, perhaps, the central figures at Derby yesterday were complete innocents. Alan Mullally, who left Grace Road last October, took the first five home wickets before salvation emerged in the shape of Matthew Dowman, whose maiden century for Derbyshire led a revival from 74 for four to 241 for five.

Marred by injury and poor form, Vince Wells's first full season as Leicestershire captain has not gone swimmingly, so it was with no little relief that he contributed a season's best 72 to the fifth-wicket stand of 128 that repulsed Kent during a Canterbury Festival rendered less than festive by anxiety over the condition of Lord Cowdrey. Aftab Habib was unbeaten on 78 as the visitors closed on 263 for six.

For all their one-day plunders and wonders Gloucestershire, the circuit's own Jekyll and Hyde, are more adept at first-class blunders. Unable to win at home all season, they will be eyeing redemption at Bristol after skittling Glamorgan for 122.

Michael Cawdron took five for 45 but the Welsh avoided an even sorrier fate thanks to Darren Thomas's 64-ball 52, which hoisted them from 59 for eight. Whereupon who should clasp three catches behind the stumps but Matthew Maynard. Maybe he fancies Stewie's job?

webTitle: Teachers frozen out of house market

fields.headline: Teachers frozen out of house market
fields.standfirst: Homes trap as gap in wages and house prices widens
fields.trailText: Teachers and nurses are so poorly paid they cannot afford to live in areas where they work, according to a study published yesterday.
fields.body:
Teachers and nurses are so poorly paid they cannot afford to live in areas where they work, according to a study published yesterday.

Service workers such as primary school teachers, nurses and hospital porters, have to commute long distances to work because their salaries do not match property and rent prices, according to the report by Britain's general trade union, the GMB.

The worst-hit areas are Kensington and Chelsea in London, Windsor and Maidenhead in Berkshire, and Hertfordshire and Dorset.

In the south-west, hospital porters earn £11,454 a year and are priced out of the property market completely. Only Plymouth offers accommodation affordable for bus drivers on £13,620.

Despite London salary weightings of around £2,000, nurses and teachers can only afford to buy properties in nine out of 32 London boroughs. According to the National Housing Federation, an income of £20,000 is needed to buy a small house in 75% of English counties.

The minimum income to buy a property in the London borough of Dagenham and Barking is £22,332. But the average salary for a newly trained teacher is £16,000 and a newly qualified nurse earns £14,890. As a result, unions said teachers and nurses faced a brick wall. They could not afford to buy in London, so they had to rent. But if they rented, they would never be able to save enough for the deposit to buy.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, said it was a scandal that such gaps in affordable housing existed.

"The announcement last week by the government that £500m is to be made available to house essential workers is a move in the right direction, but we are yet to be assured that it will be enough. The GMB would like to see a development in social housing too."

The Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions will this autumn announce proposals for the starter home initiative included in April's housing green paper.

This scheme would help low-paid service workers meet accommodation costs.

John Prescott has suggested the possibility of interest-free loans for nurses and teachers, as well as first time buyers on modest incomes.

A housing department spokeswoman said: "The government is accutely aware of the problem. It is imperative that key workers, who are essential to our society, should be able to afford to live close to their work."

Rory Taylor from St Bartholemew's and the London NHS trust said London recruitment of nurses was hin dered by the gap between salaries and house prices.

"We are one of many London trusts working with housing associations to build new staff accommodation and renovate our older properties.

We have been involved in this for a couple of years and our target is to create 1,000 new halls of residence-style flats."

webTitle: Government cracks down on unruly drinkers

fields.headline: Government cracks down on unruly drinkers
fields.trailText: Fixed-penalty fines for out-of-control drunkards and powers to close down nightspots which are a regular focus of drink-fuelled violence have been unveiled by the government.
fields.body:
Fixed-penalty fines for out-of-control drunkards and powers to close down nightspots which are a regular focus of drink-fuelled violence have been unveiled by the government.

The crackdown on under-age drinking and alcohol-related crime includes a possible new law banning drinking in public places and more widespread use of proof-of-age identity cards for those wishing to enter pubs and clubs.

While falling short of the prime minister's idea for police officers to march unruly drinkers to cashpoints to pay on-the-spot fines, the plan allows for consultation on fixed-penalty fines which must either be challenged in court or paid at a later date.

Unveiling the Alcohol Action Plan in central London, Home Office minister Charles Clarke said: "The extent to which alcohol abuse impacts on crime is very serious.

"Public drunkenness can give rise to serious problems of disorderly conduct, nuisance, criminal damage and alcohol-related assaults, particularly in the proximity of licensed premises at closing time. In addition, it can increase fear of crime and so reduce the quality of life for many people. This is clearly unacceptable. "

The government will seek to extend proof-of-age schemes in a bid to stop under 18s buying alcohol. Mr Clarke said he wants to introduce a national ID card for teenagers but the card would not be compulsory. Public drinking may be banned in specified places, giving police the power to seize bottles and cans.

The new laws would take the form of a national framework of legislation which local authorities could opt into or out of, replacing the current system of bylaws.

fields.headline: Millbankettes on the march
fields.standfirst: Why the women on Blair's backbenches have gone too far
fields.trailText:
Of all the beastly things to have been said about the "Blair Babes",
        perhaps the most unjustified is the charge that these women are deficient
        in passion: robotic voting machines who think, move, speak, and even
        dress only in accordance with instructions issued by their masters.
fields.body:
Of all the beastly things to have been said about the "Blair Babes", perhaps the most unjustified is the charge that these women are deficient in passion: robotic voting machines who think, move, speak, and even dress only in accordance with instructions issued by their masters.

In the first year of Blair's administration, it must be admitted, the women seemed content to perform, for the most part, in that demurely skirted, superbly trained chorus line, the Millbankettes, but in the past few months one after another of the so-called automata has broken away, proving that all they were waiting for, in those long months of mute servitude, was the right cause, something big enough to ignite the latent fire inside the fuschia jacket. No one reading Barbara Follett's recent cri de coeur - "It is time to put an end to this nonsense. No more shillyshallying, no more excuses" - or Oona King's no less stirring attack on "the world's most luxurious prison", or Joan Ruddock's modernisation-or-dishonour piece in the Guardian this week, can doubt either the passion or the effectiveness of these women once they encounter an injustice that is equal to their eloquence.

And the enormity that finally moved them to action? The abuse that could no longer be tolerated? Why, their own working conditions. These, as King pointed out, can be arduous. "Important legislation affecting millions of lives is routinely discussed in the middle of the night." Very worrying. Or it would be if discussion in the House of Commons were not, as the attendance at these discussions suggests, superfluous. "How awake are you at 4am?", King continued. Not very, as many regular shift-workers, from factory shift workers to casualty nurses, would no doubt testify. What makes it all worse, as Follett explained, is that the Tories sometimes keep the Labour voters up all night out of pure mischief: "We resent being taken away from our real work by the childish behaviour of a handful of parliamentary pranksters." Quite. Just as the Tories must have resented it a few years ago when the then Labour opposition gleefully got up to exactly the same sort of tricks. Ruddock discloses that she has been campaigning for change ever since she arrived in 1987. "Our priority," she writes of the modernisers, "is effectiveness . . . We cannot - and should not - divorce chamber and constituency. Nor should we have to live lives divorced from our families and friends."

Absolutely. Perhaps it is time to increase MPs' 17 weeks' holiday a year to something more consistent with the demands of modern friendship and parenting. But Ruddock and her fellow modernisers do not stop there. "I want a 21st-century speaker," Ruddock demands, "who shares my vision of a modern parliament with modern procedures and sensible hours in a redesigned semi-circular chamber in which every member has a seat and a mechanism for electronic voting." This may seem ambitious, but if the recent achievements of the modernisers are anything to go by, it is by no means unrealistic. Who could have predicted, a year or so ago, that attitudes to breastfeeding in committee would be a decisive factor in the election of the next speaker? Or guessed that the enhancement of their own working conditions would become, for so many MPs, an all-consuming preoccupation, a subject for petitions and threatened walkouts, a cause that is, if I understand King, the one reason some women MPs choose to battle on - "to change this system for good".

It is done, naturally, for the purest of motives. If women MPs are allowed to breastfeed during the longeurs of their job, then it cannot be long before non-MPs are asserting their right to have their babies brought to the office for nursing. If parliament is to enjoy - or regain - public esteem, the reformers argue, highmindedly, it must provide a model of modernity and family-friendliness. Anne Campbell, the MP for Cambridge, who organised a petition signed by 210 MPs calling for reformed hours, says the current regime "sends out the message that Parliament is out of touch". Though not quite so out of touch, perhaps, as a parliament which appears so exclusively absorbed with its own physical and social well-being. If there is any truth in the surveys showing British workers to be the most stressed and overworked, the most unhappy and downtrodden of all the drones in Europe, then maybe parliamentary hours - to remain in touch - should stay just the way they are?

Still, all this agitation must make the backbench modernisers feel that they are, at least, doing something. Michel Houellebecq, in his impressive novel, Atomised, describes the behaviour of frustrated animals. "When unable to find food, for example, pigeons ( columba livia ) will frequently peck the ground even if there is nothing there which is edible. Not only will they forage indiscriminately, but they start to preen their feathers such inappropriate behaviour, frequently observed in situations of frustration or conflict, is known as displacement activity."

So, it seems, frustrated backbenchers, denied any influence in government, will try to assert themselves with campaigns relating only to their personal comfort and prestige. Some forget themselves to the extent that they believe they were elected to pursue this very displacement activity.

Unfortunately, among MPs as opposed to pigeons, this behaviour is not merely inappropriate but counter-productive: the more self-consciously "modern" they try to be, the more the modernisers seem mystifyingly solipsistic. And if it ever comes true, Ruddock's glorious vision of a "redesigned semi-circular chamber in which every member has a seat" could be the end of the place. There is, after all, already a place with not one but two semi-circular chambers, with seats and rooms and showers for everyone and electronic gadgets and every possible modern parliamentary contrivance. Modernity, as the up-to-the-minute European parliament proves every day, need not mean effectiveness. Sometimes it just means blond wood, expense accounts and something called the democratic deficit.

fields.headline: Who is Alex Allan?
fields.standfirst: Alex Allan is live online on Friday at 3pm. Post your questions here
fields.trailText: As the only top civil servant known to have played Grateful Dead albums inside Number 10 and to have windsurfed to work down the River Thames during a train strike, Alex Allan is the exception which proves the rule about Whitehall officials. We suspect that they are all faceless men from the ministry. As the webmaster behind the internet's best Grateful Dead lyric finder he shows that they are not.
fields.body:
As the only top civil servant known to have played Grateful Dead albums inside Number 10 and to have windsurfed to work down the River Thames during a train strike, Alex Allan is the exception which proves the rule about Whitehall officials. We suspect that they are all faceless men from the ministry. As the webmaster behind the internet's best Grateful Dead lyric finder he shows that they are not.

Once a treasury official, then permanent private secretary to John Major and more recently to Tony Blair (the role held by Bernard Woolley in Yes, Prime Minister) he is now Britain's e-envoy - responsible for "making the UK the best place in the world for e-commerce". He was appointed to the post by Tony Blair and reports directly to him.

As such he is at the heart of debate over issues such as the recent Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which gives the government powers to spy on your use of the net. Civil servants carry out policy - rather than decide it - so he is not responsible for the government's aims. But he is charged with making sure that Britain does not fall behind in the electronic rat-race.

Among his projects is uk.online, an ambitious web portal for all government services being developed with British Telecom. He is also an enthusiast for e-democracy: a hot topic in the US which is beginning to win notice over here. In a recent speech, he called for governments to use the internet to increase openness.

Whether they do, or whether they continue to see it purely as a commercial opportunity is partly up to the e-envoy.

webTitle: Casiraghi considering £2.5m claim over lost wages

fields.headline: Casiraghi considering £2.5m claim over lost wages
fields.trailText: The Premier League are investigating a potential claim of up to £2.5m in wages by injured striker Pierluigi Casiraghi against Chelsea following the club's move to end his contract after receiving a £4m insurance payout.
fields.body:
The Premier League are investigating a potential claim of up to £2.5m in wages by injured striker Pierluigi Casiraghi against Chelsea following the club's move to end his contract after receiving a £4m insurance payout.

Chelsea have received the payout from their insurers after medical tests were carried out on the serious knee injury which the Italian suffered almost two years ago and on which he has since had 10 operations.

The club, who have been paying Casiraghi his estimated £25,000-a-week wages since he incurred the injury against West Ham in November 1998, gave him six months' notice to end his contract earlier this year and this is due to expire on August 17. From then on, Casiraghi would no longer be a Chelsea player and therefore not entitled to receive any wages for the two years which had been remaining on his contract.

However, Casiraghi disputes the view of Chelsea and their insurers that his top-level career has come to an end. And his advisors have contacted London solicitors with a view to making an appeal to the Premier League's board or taking possible civil action in the courts.

A Premier League spokesman confirmed: "This is an FA Premier League matter. The Premier League have been in communication with the player's solicitor. Chelsea are aware of the possibility of a hearing before the FA Premier League board."

The onus would now seem to be on Casiraghi, whose latest operation was only last month in Italy, to produce medical evidence that he would be able to carry on playing.

However, Chelsea are convinced that despite their regret at the striker's fate, they have the right to end his contract - a view accepted by their insurers.

Chelsea company secretary Alan Shaw declared: "A payout has been made by our insurers. Gigi has been injured for almost two years and has been paid during that time. But there comes a point when the medical opinion suggests that he will not play again.

"It is a tremendously sad case that someone coming up to the age of 32 has had his career cut short in this way. But he would have to bring some evidence to bear that he will play again."

Casiraghi's agent, Fabio Parisi, confirmed that the striker disputes Chelsea's view of his playing future even though he conceded that his client had only a "slim chance" of making a full comeback. Parisi told the Daily Star: "We have appealed to the Premier League about this because his contract requires that an independent medical report is completed and that's not been done.

"Gigi has been checked by a doctor from Chelsea and another one from the insurance company in February. We asked for a copy of the insurer's report but didn't receive one and we've passed on the problem to lawyers in London. We are waiting to see what the FA Premier League board or the civil court will decide."

webTitle: Brooking: 'Technically we are not good enough'

fields.headline: Brooking: 'Technically we are not good enough'
fields.trailText: Trevor Brooking, famous for his non-committal punditry on Match of the Day, spared no blushes today as he tore into the state of English football. The former West Ham midfielder, who is now head of Sport England, claimed that English players were simply not good enough to compete on the world stage and that it would be at least 10 years before there is any real improvement.
fields.body:
Trevor Brooking, famous for his non-committal punditry on Match of the Day, spared no blushes today as he tore into the state of English football. The former West Ham midfielder, who is now head of Sport England, claimed that English players were simply not good enough to compete on the world stage and that it would be at least 10 years before there is any real improvement.

"Euro 2000 was proof that we are not as good as some people would have us believe," Brooking said today. "Technically, we are not good enough and people are starting to realise that."

Brooking said it was unfair to blame the decline in standards on the influx of foreign players into the English game. "I can understand why people want a restriction on the number of foreign players but I don't think that is going to happen," he said. "They have come in because we do not have sufficient players of that quality. If they left the standard of the Premier League would collapse."

Brooking instead blamed lack of investment at the grassroots level for the game's current malaise. "We have ignored the grass roots for 20 years," he said. Last week, Sport England announced a £90m initiative to support the foundations of football, but Brooking warned results would be a long time in coming. "The work we are doing now will take five years for the first signs to show and 10 before the real benefits are felt," he said.

In a veiled swipe at Charles Hughes, technical director of the FA during the 1980s, Brooking claimed that "kick and rush" football also had its part to play in England's demise. "The standard of football it produced was dire and it was awful to watch," he said. "Kick and rush spread down to the grassroots and scouts were being told to look for big, strong, hulking youngsters. Anyone who was small was almost completely ignored, yet ability and technique more than make up for a lack of inches."

"We have to put something back into the primary schools because the ages between five and seven are the most impressionable for any youngster," Brooking claimed. The Football Foundation will provide extra equipment for clubs and schools, but Brooking believes the standard of teaching must also improve. "Unfortunately, there are some primary teachers taking sports classes who have only had six hours training themselves, " he said. "If nobody can show these kids how to kick a ball, they will never get any better and then will switch off completely. Once that happens we have lost them, which is a travesty."

webTitle: Fifa decide to rotate World Cup after 2010

fields.headline: Fifa decide to rotate World Cup after 2010
fields.trailText: The World Cup will be rotated between the six continental federations from the year 2010.
fields.body:
The World Cup will be rotated between the six continental federations from the year 2010.

The decision, taken by Fifa's powerful executive committee, followed the controversy over last month's choice of Germany as hosts for the 2006 World Cup in preference to South Africa. In the aftermath of the vote, Fifa president Sepp Blatter proposed each continent take it in turns to host the tournament - and his view was unanimously supported today.

However, the exact form in which the World Cups will be rotated is still to be worked out by Fifa's strategic studies committee.

A Fifa statement said: "The Fifa executive committee has expressed a clear opinion in favour of some form of rotating the World Cup among the six continental confederations, as from the year 2010.

"The committee unanimously backed Blatter's suggestion to ensure that all continents be given an equal opportunity to host the World Cup."

But Blatter has ruled out any chance of a new vote over the 2006 hosts, and insisted the decision to award the tournament to Germany was final.

"Mr Blatter added that the initiative taken by the defeated South African FA to take the matter to arbitration was inappropriate, and not supported by the African Football Confederation," said the Fifa statement.

Other decisions confirmed today included the second Club World Championship to be held in Spain in summer of next year, with 12 teams taking part.

webTitle: Europe's last POW, the man who was locked away for 56 years

fields.headline: Europe's last POW, the man who was locked away for 56 years
fields.standfirst:
Locked up for 56 years, the last POW. By Amelia Gentleman in Kotyelnich

3 August, 3.45pm: Audio report from Amelia Gentleman in Kotyelnich
fields.trailText: There is nothing in the clean but bare hospital ward to suggest that this has been Andras Tamas's home since 1947. The only belongings by his bed are a pair of crutches. Elsewhere in the room, half a dozen other inmates gaze vacantly at the floor or lie facing the wall on single, iron beds.
fields.body:
There is nothing in the clean but bare hospital ward to suggest that this has been Andras Tamas's home since 1947. The only belongings by his bed are a pair of crutches. Elsewhere in the room, half a dozen other inmates gaze vacantly at the floor or lie facing the wall on single, iron beds.

These patients know nothing about the extraordinary history of their fellow inmate. "He keeps himself to himself," said Ilya Mamayev, who has slept in the neighbouring bed for the last 12 years. "He has always been a loner."

Mr Tamas is probably Europe's last remaining second world war prisoner of war. He has spent his life in a psychiatric institute in the depths of rural Russia, unclaimed for more than half a century and with no way of communicating with the people that are around him.

It has been more than 53 years since he last had a proper conversation. Doctors have only recently begun to trace his roots, hoping that he would be taken off their hands, thus alleviating the hospital's severe financial problems. As a foreigner, Andras Tamas was not eligible for a Russian pension and had become a financial drain.

Their efforts have sparked long overdue diplomatic negotiations in an attempt to get him back to his homeland after an absence of almost six decades.

Mr Tamas was yesterday oblivious to the mounting international concern about him as he sat on the edge of his bed, in the corner of ward number two of the psychiatric institute in the small town of Kotyelnich, 700 miles east of Moscow. It is a depressingly bare room with 11 beds and large, barred windows.

Bemused by the sudden attention he has attracted, he was uncertain how to respond - first laughing, then mumbling in Hungarian before swearing enthusiastically in Russian. Doctors apologised, explaining that this was as far as his grasp of the language went.

Mr Tamas's story is a tragic account of a wasted life. It is thought that he served in the Hungarian army which was destroyed during the battle of the River Don in 1944.

He was transferred from a Russian prisoner of war camp to Kotyelnich in 1947 in a state of extreme confusion. Officials from the NKVD - the pre-cursor to the KGB - accompanied him to the hospital but they provided no proper documents revealing where he was from, when he was born or how he had fallen into captivity.

The form authorising Mr Tamas's transfer to the hospital, a yellowing sheet of paper which has been preserved alongside his medical notes, provides no insight into his earlier life. "Transferring POW, Tamas, Andras to a psychiatric institute in Kotyelnich, diagnosis psycho-neurosis," a small handwritten note, dated January 11 1947, reads.

Judging by his physical condition, doctors assume that he must now be around 75 years old. But they have never even been totally sure that they have got his name right - some insist that Tamas must be his first name.

They can only speculate that the notoriously harsh conditions in which enemy captives were kept by the Soviet army may have caused him to lose his mind. The medical files state that he was in a "pitiful state" when he arrived - wearing a thin coat, a torn military jacket, an old fur hat, mis-matched gloves and a pair of worn-out grey felt boots - an outfit wholly inadequate for the extreme temperatures of the Russian winter. He was "emaciated in the extreme", the doctor's records state, and suffering from "extreme psychosis".

Initially, he appeared extremely disturbed, behaving aggressively, shouting in Hungarian and picking fights with the other patients. Doctors were never able to ask him what had happened because Mr Tamas spoke no Russian then, and has never learned to speak it. No one at the hospital spoke any Hungarian and all attempts to talk to him in German failed. For the next 53 years he existed in self-imposed isolation, shunning any contact.

In the early years he spent most of his time lying on his bed with his face to the wall, his covers pulled up over his head. Gradually his mental condition improved enough for him to start helping out with work on the hospital farm, looking after the horses and helping with the potato harvest.

The hospital's chief doctor, Yuri Petukhov, who has known him for 18 years, said he believed Mr Tamas' progress towards recovery would have been much swifter had there been someone for him to talk to. He has improved so much that if there had been anywhere for him to go to, doctors would have discharged him in the 1970s.

For the last 30 years, he has had the right to wander freely around the small, provincial town, but he has chosen never to venture beyond the hospital grounds. In recent years, he has done little except sit on a bench in the garden.

Local officials made an occasional attempt to trace his family, appealing to the Red Cross for assistance, but because he possessed no documents their efforts proved fruitless.

Until a few months ago it seemed probable that Mr Tamas would die within the same hospital ward where he has languished most of his life.

It was only by chance, when a visiting Slovakian doctor treating him for another disease in the mid 1990s recognised a few Hungarian words, that officials began to understand where their patient was from. But doctors could find no one in Kotyelnich who spoke even a word of Hungarian.

Then earlier this year a local newspaper article finally managed to attract the attention of a Hungarian journalist and diplomat who at last began to champion his cause.

Since he was rediscovered, several Hungarian nationals have travelled to the hospital to try to talk to him - with increasing success.

He spoke with great difficulty at first, but has gradually regained some fluency, using old-fashioned idioms and pre-war vocabulary.

Although he remains deeply confused, with each conversation he remembers new details of his past. Last week he named for the first time the place where he thinks he was born - a small village in a part of Transylvania which is now in Slovakia.

Memories of his time in captivity remain vivid and he has repeatedly made halting references to the cold in Siberia, the frost and the snow. "He talked about warming his hands at a camp fire, the arrival of soldiers with machine guns and being put in a train carriage. We think he must be referring to the time when he was taken prisoner," said Dr Petukhov.

Andras Veer, a Hungarian psychiatrist who visited Mr Tamas for the first time last week, said that with a few weeks of therapy his mental condition should improve dramatically and recommended he should be returned to Hungary immediately where he would be surrounded by people who speak the only language he understands. But it remains unclear whether he has any surviving relatives.

More importantly, no one knows whether he has any desire to leave the hospital. "In the few exchanges he has had in Hungarian, he has never ex pressed any desire to go home," Dr Petukhov said. "When he is asked, he does not respond, as if he doesn't really understand the question."

Despite the pages of medical reports dating back through the years of his confinement in the hospital, all of which describe him as almost autistic in his desire for solitude, Mr Tamas appeared grateful for the attention he received yesterday and eager to find somebody able to talk to him.

Mr Tamas' sole concern appears to be getting a wooden leg - his own was amputated three years ago when a smoking-related illness turned it gangrenous.

During attempted conversations with the hospital doctor he points repeatedly to the space where his leg used to be and gestures that he would like them to build him a wooden replacement. He is oblivious to the medical developments in prosthetics.

He greeted every visitor to the ward yesterday by jabbing at the knot tied below his stump in his tracksuit trousers. "We think he is telling us to sort out his leg first and then he'll think about going home," Dr Petukhov said.

webTitle: Police fail on ethnic minority targets

fields.headline: Police fail on ethnic minority targets
fields.standfirst:
Home Office plan hit by 75% shortfall in recruitment goal
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The effort to boost ethnic minority recruitment in the police service, in the wake of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, is not succeeding, parliamentary data show.
fields.body:
The effort to boost ethnic minority recruitment in the police service, in the wake of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, is not succeeding, parliamentary data show.

Instead, some of the forces, such as West Yorkshire, that are under greatest pressure to recruit and retain more police, are seeing falling numbers of ethnic officers.

On average, police forces need to recruit an additional 826 officers a year to meet the 10-year targets set by the Home Office. But over the year to this March there were only 209 more officers from ethnic minorities.

The forces that need to recruit the majority of additional officers - the Metropolitan police, and West Midlands, Greater Manchester, and West Yorkshire - are all failing to meet their targets. In West Yorkshire, the number of officers from minority ethnic communities has fallen over the past two years from 133 to 127.

At this rate of progress, the forces where further minority ethnic recruitment is needed most, will fail to meet the government's targets.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman who compiled the figures from parliamentary written answers, said the figures were "very disappointing".

In the two years between March 1998 and March this year, the number of ethnic minority officers rose from 2,483 to 2,754. But police forces need an increase of 8,265 officers at an average of 826 a year to meet the home secretary's 10-year goal. The officer targets, intended to reflect particular communities served, will inevitably put pressure on inner city police to transform their outfits.

The Home Office hopes a rapid expansion of the police service, as heralded in recent budget announcements, will provide a timely chance to recruit from ethnic minorities. Ministers have admitted that the "canteen culture" inside police forces needs to be dispelled not only to attract ethnic minorities but keep them.

The figures show the Met needs an average of 566 officers each year to meet its target. Between March last year and March this year, there were only an additional 125 officers. Their target is to increase the proportion to 25.5% by 2006. The present strength is only 4%.

The West Midlands force needs an average of 86 additional officers a year. Between March 1999 and this March, there were only an additional 17 officers; the target is to have a police force with a 16% ethnic minority by 2009. Greater Manchester needs an average 35 additional officers a year, but in the same two years achieved four extra officers.

Meanwhile, West Yorkshire, needing an average 34 extra officers, had four fewer in the time period. Officers from ethnic minorities make up 3% of this region's police strength; the target is for 9.4% by 2009.

The Home Office has defended the slow increase saying there is no need for the targets to be achieved by equal annual increments. The target for retention is that the percentage of ethnic minority officers resigning or dismissed should equal the percentage of white officers leaving.

webTitle: Cocu: I want to play for Arsenal

fields.headline: Cocu: I want to play for Arsenal
fields.trailText: Phillip Cocu has confirmed that Arsenal have made a bid for him - and that he would like to play for the Gunners.
fields.body:
Phillip Cocu has confirmed that Arsenal have made a bid for him - and that he would like to play for the Gunners.

However, the 29-year-old still has another year to run on his contract and Arsenal may have to wait until next year when Cocu will be able to cash in on a free transfer.

Writing on his personal website, icons.com, Cocu admits: "Tonight's match against Arsenal will very interesting. I think my new team-mates Manu Petit and Marc Overmars are particularly looking forward to it because it's always special to play against your old team.

"On the subject of Arsenal, there's been quite a bit of speculation about me joining them. What I understand is that Arsenal made an offer for me but Barcelona said that I was not for sale. Arsenal are a great team and I'd like to play for them, but I've no reason to leave Barca at the moment.

"I have a good situation here, but I have one year left on my contract so we'll have to see what happens in the future."

Meanwhile George Graham's bid to sign Boudewijn Zenden looks like coming to nothing, with Ronald De Boer admitting today: "We still have Zenden playing with us at Barca but I think everyone still expects his transfer to Lazio to go through at some stage."

webTitle: Yugoslav army arrests two Britons, two Canadians for spying

fields.headline: Yugoslav army arrests two Britons, two Canadians for spying
fields.trailText: The Yugoslav military has arrested four foreigners - two Britons and two Canadians - who are suspected of training pro-western forces in Montenegro for terrorist purposes.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav military has arrested four foreigners - two Britons and two Canadians - who are suspected of training pro-western forces in Montenegro for terrorist purposes.

The four were arrested on Tuesday on Mount Cakor, on the border between Montenegro and Kosovo. The Yugoslav army said that military equipment and explosives had been found in their possession.

The Serbian authorities, who command the Yugoslav army, recently alleged that special British forces and other foreign experts were training the Montenegrin paramilitary police force in preparation for the pro-western republic's secession from Yugoslavia.

"There are indications that the arrested foreigners were training special units of Montenegrin police and that they are specialists for explosives and terrorist actions," the military said in a statement.

The ruling Montenegrin Democratic party of Socialists said that by claiming that foreign instructors were training Montenegrin troops, the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, and his allies were trying to "prepare ground for a physical assault on Montenegro ... and the elimination of its democratic leadership".

The arrests come amid fears in Montenegro that the Yugoslav army may try to oust the republic's government ahead of Yugoslav elections in September - polls that the leadership has vowed to boycott.

Yugoslav authorities - who have been stepping up anti-western propaganda ahead of the vote - announced on Monday that four Dutchmen had been arrested in Yugoslavia in July for allegedly plotting to assassinate Mr Milosevic.

There have been allegations that that Nato has hired mercenaries to snatch war-crimes suspects on Yugoslav territory and bring them to the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

In Vienna, a spokesman for the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe said that two Britons working as instructors at the OSCE-run Kosovo police academy in Vucitrn had been missing since Tuesday and were believed to have been with two Canadian aid workers.

The four were arrested on Tuesday on Mount Cakor, on the border between Montenegro and Kosovo. The Yugoslav army said that military equipment and explosives had been found in their possession. The Serbian authorities, who command the Yugoslav army, recently alleged that special British forces and other foreign experts were training the Montenegrin paramilitary police force in preparation for the pro-western republic's secession from Yugoslavia. "There are indications that the arrested foreigners were training special units of Montenegrin police and that they are specialists for explosives and terrorist actions," the military said in a statement. The ruling Montenegrin Democratic party of Socialists said that by claiming that foreign instructors were training Montenegrin troops, the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, and his allies were trying to "prepare ground for a physical assault on Montenegro ... and the elimination of its democratic leadership". The arrests come amid fears in Montenegro that the Yugoslav army may try to oust the republic's government ahead of Yugoslav elections in September - polls that the leadership has vowed to boycott. Yugoslav authorities - who have been stepping up anti-western propaganda ahead of the vote - announced on Monday that four Dutchmen had been arrested in Yugoslavia in July for allegedly plotting to assassinate Mr Milosevic. fields.headline: NoW 'finds common ground' with critics
fields.trailText: Hopes that the News of the World and critics of its campaign to "name and shame" sex offenders would find some common ground rose last night, after four hours of talks broke up with an agreement to talk again before the weekend.
fields.body:
Hopes that the News of the World and critics of its campaign to "name and shame" sex offenders would find some common ground rose last night, after four hours of talks broke up with an agreement to talk again before the weekend.

The Sunday newspaper's managing editor, Stuart Kuttner, declined to say if it would continue to publish photographs and names of convicted sex offenders, but said: "After four hours of talks, significant common ground was established and both sides agreed to consider the issues raised. A period of reflection during which contact will be maintained has been agreed. In addition, both parties agreed on their common aim to improve protection of children."

Among those who met senior newspaper executives, including editor Rebekah Wade, were Tony Butler, the chief constable of Gloucestershire, chief probation officers, child welfare charities, and the relatives of murder victims. They had joined forces to halt the public "outing" of sex offenders, on the grounds that it drove them underground and created a climate for vigilante action.

The meeting was held the same day as Home Office research was published showing the sex offenders' register introduced in 1998 was "working well", with a 97% registration.

About 12,000 names of convicted sex offenders are on the register, a figure that is expected to expand to 25,000 when it is fully operational. The official study did however disclose police concerns with loopholes in the legislation, a lack of resources to maintain sufficient monitoring of sex offenders, and the creation of unrealistic expectations among the public and media.

Mr Butler said it was important to remember the research was undertaken more than a year ago, and there had been important improvements that had helped raise the registration rate of convicted sex offenders to 97%.

The Home Office study, Where are they now?, does show however that the police have been using a limited form of community notification, depending on an assessment of risk in each case. Some 17 forces have passed on information about sex offenders to individuals and organisations outside the usual network, in cases where they thought it was justified. Amongst those notified were community youth groups, schools, leisure centres, and local papers.

Beginning its campaign, the News of the World said that, in the aftermath of the murder of Sarah Payne, eight, in West Sussex, it wanted to see the introduction of a British version of the US-style Megan's law, under which residents are given the right to be informed if a convicted serial paedophile is living in their area. The paper also wanted to see the government introducing a "life means life" sentence for sex offenders.

Last night Michael and Sara Payne, parents of the dead girl, who attended the meeting, said they "had never really been happy" about the approach of the campaign.

But, they said, the public wished to know who and where these people were - "and until someone comes forward with something else we will continue to do this ...

"We [those at the meeting] will get together at the end of the week to see if people around the table want to come on board for the 'For Sarah' campaign. 'For Sarah' stands for a public register we all have access to."

Amongst those attended to express their criticism of the newspaper were the Association of Chief Probation Officers, the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, and the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders.

Paul Cavadino of Nacro said the Paynes were a tremendously impressive and courageous couple: "We will remain in touch to see if we can find a way forward in the best interests of the children. We have agreed that while these discussions are continuing, it would not help the process if we engaged in further interviews on this subject."

The News of the World published 50 photographs and names in the first week, and 34 last weekend. On Monday it was revealed one of those named had died in prison six years ago from cancer; police said they were concerned that a second named man had gone on the run.

 More about the Sarah Payne case

fields.headline: GM crop trial sites announced
fields.trailText: Environment minister Michael Meacher today revealed the names of 25 sites across Britain where new trials of GM crops are likely take place - provoking accusations of irresponsibility from environmental groups.
fields.body:
Environment minister Michael Meacher today revealed the names of 25 sites across Britain where new trials of GM crops are likely take place - provoking accusations of irresponsibility from environmental groups.

Mr Meacher insisted that without trials, society would never know for certain whether the crops were safe or not. In the past, environmental campaigners have attacked fields of GM crops.

The crop involved, created by the seed company Aventis, is a winter-growing variety of oil-seed rape, genetically modified to be more resistant than its conventional counterparts to herbicides.

Mr Meacher said that the plants had already been through exhaustive tests in the laboratory and in smaller trials. He will make a final decision on trials at the 25 sites later this month.

"One thing I must make crystal clear is our commitment to protecting the countryside," he said. "These herbicide tolerant crops have been through one of the toughest regulatory processes in the world, having been extensively tested in laboratories and in small scale trials.

"We cannot take action in respect of GM crops unless we can show evidence that they constitute a risk of harm either to human health or the environment.

"These trials will show whether there is such evidence. Only by testing these crops under farm conditions can we be sure whether or not they pose any threat to local wildlife."

Even before GM crops reach the point of human consumption, there are fears that they could contaminate the environment, spreading their artificially-altered mix of genes into other animals and plants, with unpredictable consequences.

Beekeepers, whose bees would pick up GM pollen from the test sites, would suffer losses if they were too close to the farms involved, Friends of the Earth said today.

"Beekeepers are having to move their hives six miles from the farm-scale trials to protect the purity of the honey. Will they be compensated?" an FoE spokesman said.

Mo Mowlam, who as Cabinet Office minister is trying to pull together the government's GM policy, said: "These crops are being grown legally, and under strict controls Those who have vandalised sites are prejudicing the very trials which could provide the evidence to support or refute their claims."

In a separate report today, parliament's agricultural select committee criticised the government's confusion which followed the discovery earlier this year that farmers had accidentally sowed rape containing a small percentage of GM seeds.

"Clearer procedures are required for dealing with incidents of this kind," the report said. "It was obvious that confusion existed as to which ministry should lead on this issue."

At the heart of the debate over GM foods lies a dispute between most scientists and most environmentalists about the nature of genes. Genes are long stretches of an acid called DNA, found in the nucleus of all cells of all living creatures. They give instructions to chemicals inside an organism to maintain and renew it.

Scientists point out that if you pick a natural apple off a tree and eat it, you are consuming billions of cells, each of which contain apple genes - yet the apple genes are not incorporated into your DNA.

The same, most argue, applies to GM foods containing non-natural genes.

Environmentalists counter that the mechanisms of inserting new genes into plants are not fully understood, that there is a danger of kindred species acquiring unintended characteristics from GM species, and that the chemicals "ordered up" by novel genes could themselves be hazardous.

fields.headline: Consideration, Condemnation and Contracts
fields.trailText: TAKE GOOD KARE OF MY CASIRAGHI
fields.body:
TAKE GOOD KARE OF MY CASIRAGHI

When times are tough, it's important to have people around you who care. Think how lucky Pierluigi Casiraghi is, then, to have Kuddly Ken Bates. For nearly two years, Chelsea's Italian striker has been battling to save his career after suffering a horrendous knee injury against West Ham. He's recently undergone a morale-sapping tenth operation, so who knows what state he'd be in had Karing Ken not announced to the world that his career is over and Chelsea will stop paying his wages next month (after serving notice on a contract which still had two years to run).

"Casiraghi won't be playing any more," Konsiderate Ken announced with a tear in his eye. "We have been paid £4,050,000 insurance, which will mean he can't play top-level football again." This heartfelt speech comes a week after Casiraghi had accused the club of showing little interest in his progress, a charge Bates hotly denies: "We gave him 20 months, but he was still walking with a limp, so we had no choice."

Whether Chelsea really did have "no choice" is a moot point, however. "Of course it was a very, very bad injury and there is only a slim chance of him making a comeback," Casiraghi's agent Fabio Parisi said today, "but we consider it is still too early to say he will not. It looks strange that Chelsea should collect the money without Gigi's consent." Parisi, who claims that an independent medical report should have been completed, has lodged an appeal with the Premier League on behalf of his client, and hasn't ruled out going to the civil courts. It's a terrible business which could turn unpleasant - so if Ken feels he needs a cuddle himself, he knows where to find us.

GREG THE PEG

Aston Villa went out of European competition last night, pretty much before it had even started, going down 2-1 at home to Celta Vigo in the semi-finals of the Intertoto Cup. This, in terms of European milestones, is about as significant as an EU directive on the size of men's turn-ups. So is it any wonder that John Gregory, football's Mr Angry, got a little hot under the collar over events?

"If the ref's last name is Shocker," said Greg of referee Shoch, who handed out three red cards and eight yellow during the game, "then his first name should be Hadda." Great stuff. And funny too. "The referee was unbelievably petty. If there were rules and regulations, he stuck to the letter of the law," Greg went on, as if this was a bad thing.

With steam beginning to make its way out of his mouth as well as his ears, Greg then turned his attentions to his own players. Asked whether the arrival of David Ginola would persuade Southgate, Ehiogu et al to stay on at Villa Park, Greg said: "Frankly I don't care. If people want to leave here then in my opinion it is their loss. If they want to go, then go, providing we are compensated in the right manner." All this on the same day that his chairman, Dashing Doug Ellis, said of Southgate: "As far as I'm concerned he is under contract for a further three years and I'd like him to stay." Looks like things are warming up nicely for the new season. And to think Villa are only 100-1 for the title.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"He has arrived with a big reputation. I am told he is as big as Alan Shearer in Saudi, and he has looked very smart in training" - Wolves' manager Colin Lee talks up the elbowing, sorry, striking skills of 'The Blue Fox', Saudi Arabian international Sami Al-Jaber, currently on trial at Molineux.

OWEN NOT GOIN'

Michael Owen wants to make it quite clear that he's as "happy as he's ever been" at Liverpool. And he certainly doesn't want to leave. Oh no. And to prove his loyalty, England's boy wonder suddenly announced today that he'd be "delighted to discuss a new contract" - despite having three years left on his present one. My, the lad's keen! And anyone who dares suggest that he's using Real Madrid's reported £25m interest to bump his contract to Rivaldo-like levels with get very short shrift from us. Alright?

"I've still got three years left on my current contract, and I'm as happy as I've ever been at Liverpool," said Owen. "But if Liverpool decide they want me for even longer, I'd be delighted to discuss it." And he had a special message for Madrid president and construction magnate Florentino Perez, who last month admitted he was "enchanted" by Liverpool's no.10 - well, he is an attractive lad - and has been after him ever since.

"When you see things like that it means two things," said an earnest Owen. "First I can come out and say I'm flattered. But on the other hand I'm not happy because I don't want it to cause a problem with Liverpool fans." And to make his point, Owen reiterated his commitment to Gerald Houllier's side. "I'm very proud to play for Liverpool and have no intention of leaving. The calibre of signings we have made is an indication of how far we are going," he said with a straight face, as Bernard Diomede and Gary McAllister suddenly stumbled into view.

THE RUMOUR MILL

The chairman of Internazionale, Massimo Moratti, has said he would like to bring Paul Ince back to the San Siro. "I have been hurt by many players leaving the club, but none more so than Paul Ince," Moratti said. "He was forced to return to England because of his wife. Just this summer I proposed to Lippi that we should take him back."

Rangers have been linked with a move for Paolo Poggi of Roma, after Real Mallorca striker Diego Tristan said he would not leave Spain.

Bobby Robson is interested in signing Jason Euell from Wimbledon, and has asked the club for first refusal on the midfielder.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Phillip Cocu has confirmed Arsenal have made a bid for him - and that he would like to play for the Gunners. However, the 29-year-old still has another year to run on his contract and Arsenal may have to wait until next year when Cocu will be able to cash in on a free transfer. "What I understand is that Arsenal made an offer for me, but Barcelona said that I was not for sale," he said. "Arsenal are a great team, and I'd like to play for them. But I've no reason to leave Barca at the moment."

Trevor Brooking has launched a scathing attack on the standards of English football - and claimed it could take another 10 years to repair the damage of the 1980s. "Euro 2000 was proof that we are not as good as some people would have us believe," he said. "Technically, we are not good enough and people are starting to realise that. I can understand why people want a restriction on the number of foreign players but they have come in because we do not have sufficient players of that quality," he went on. "If they left the standard of the Premier League would collapse. The harsh fact is that there is no short-term solution. We have ignored the grass roots for 20 years, and the work we are doing now will take five years for the first signs to show and 10 before the real benefits are felt."

Ian Walker has warned George Graham that he could seek a transfer if he is left of Spurs' opening game against Ipswich. "I won't be happy if I don't play in that game and I don't think that is being controversial," he said. "I cannot afford to be sat on the bench at my age."

Newcastle captain Alan Shearer has promised he will be fit for the opening match of the season after undergoing a scan on a troublesome knee injury. "The scan has shown that the knee is no worse than when I was scanned by England during the European Championships," he said. "I'm not that short of match fitness because I didn't stop playing until June 20 with England. All I need to be ready for Manchester United is one full game or a game and a half."

Bradford striker Dean Saunders will miss the opening game of the season after being diagnosed with fluid on his knee.

Ally McCoist has signed a new one-year deal with Kilmarnock.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Argentinian Football (1am)

Boca Juniors v Argentinos Juniors, with a half-time rendition of Mama Used to Say from electro-pop artiste Junior.

Major League Soccer 2000 All-Star Game (2.40am)

Preki goes head-to-head with Mo Johnston. Don't worry, the LA OJ Simpsons return next week.

British Eurosport: Football Live (7pm)

Eurosport, we have information! Juventus, Inter Milan and Bari compete in some inconsequential pre-season tournament...

Sky Sports 3: Five-side-football (7.30pm)

...although if you want to stick with British you can always watch pub players kicking lumps out of each other on Hackney Marshes. Thank God for Sky!

Fifa TV (9.30pm)

Who needs Burnside when you've got Sepp Blatter?

World Cup Classics (10pm)

And who wouldn't call the Group D clash between Argentina v Haiti from the 1974 World Cup finals a classic?

webTitle: Consumer campaigns: How to air your complaints on the net.

fields.headline: Watchdogs on the web
fields.standfirst:
Are you sick of being messed around by big companies? Increasing numbers of dissatisfied customers are airing their complaints on the net. Steve Gold explains how

Net news
fields.trailText: Are you sick of being messed around by big companies? Steve Gold explains how to air your complaints on the net.
fields.body:
If you've ever had reason to complain to a large company about a problem you've encountered - perhaps taking issue with an inferior product or service, or about the way your case was handled - you'll know how frustrating it can be.

A select few firms have excellent customer service and complaints operations, rapidly resolving and compensating customers for the hassle and inconvenience they have experienced. But too many seem hell-bent on refusing to resolve and recompense customers who feel they have been cheated, wronged or poorly treated. And, while many industries, such as the travel trade, do have recognised complaints organisations many consumers understandably feel less than pleased with the way their case has been handled. Take the case of Steve Pardoe (www.pardoes.com) and his ongoing battle against BT Cellnet.

Early in 1999, Pardoe was amazed to find his Barclaycard had been debited by Cellnet (now BT Cellnet) for £50. The debit was unauthorised and, as a result, he contacted Cellnet, only to get, what he claimed was, rather unsympathetic handling. After contacting Barclaycard, who were more helpful, he had his account credited with the unauthorised debit. When two further debits of £50 appeared on his statement, Pardoe cancelled his Barclaycard, which he says was less than convenient, as he was about to travel and so needed a credit card.

What annoyed Pardoe most was that BT Cellnet was at the time apparently unable to prevent its prepaid cellular customers from using his card number and expiry date to get call credit on their mobiles.

Because of Cellnet's poor response to his original complaint, Pardoe - described by one cellular trade magazine as "Mr Angry" - has staged a one-man campaign on the web to publicise the mobile network's loopholes in its security procedures. BT Cellnet has tried to deal with the problem by making sure that any new mobile phone owners have to register their debit or credit card number when they buy a mobile phone. Pardoe remains incensed, as witnessed by an ongoing campaign on his site, much to BT Cellnet's annoyance. BT Cellnet now appears to have realised - too late - that it handled Pardoe's case with less than its usual level of professionalism, and is now reaping the negative publicity rewards.

According to Alan Stevens, digital media specialist with the Consumer's Association (www.which.net) and editor of Which? magazine, cases like Pardoe's, and the Dump the Pump campaign (www.boycott-the-pumps.com) against high petrol prices, show that, thanks to the web, consumers are becoming empowered against large organisations. There are plenty of other instances where consumers have used the internet to complain about services.

The "Flaming Ford" site (www.flamingfords.com) for example, started when a Ford owner, who claimed his car burst into flames, complained to the company only to be told that his was the only case they had encountered. When the irate owner posted his grievances on the web he was contacted by other "Flaming Ford" owners and the campaign really took off. A class action against Ford is currently being heavily disputed.

The Consumer's Association, has also used the power of the web to stage its own campaign. Alongside its www.which.net site, the CA has opened a campaign site at www.carbusters.com, to highlight the extra costs of buying a car - almost any car - in the UK, comparing the prices that continental motorists pay.

Before you turn to the web to air your grievances, make sure you have explored the normal avenues of complaint, and ensured your complaint is valid, advise the Consumer's Association. Alistair Kelman, a barrister who specialises in IT law, warns of the legal consequences of a badly-thought-out web campaign. "Consumer's tales have a habit of becoming embroidered, and the danger is that customers can end up libelling another person, or more usually, a company, with their campaigning web site."

It is easier for companies to show damage to their trading reputation. "This makes it relatively easy for a company to take action against someone posting incorrect or untruthful allegations on their web sites. Users should take care to only report the facts, referring to copies of their correspondence or email on their site, which they can also post." By referring to correspondence or emails with the company in question, and sticking to the facts, and the facts only, you shouldn't go too far wrong.

So how easy (and expensive) is it to wage a legitimate campaign against a major company or organisation you feel has wronged you? Provided you have explored all normal avenues of complaint and have got nowhere, or have not received a sensible and satisfactory response, the answer is - very easy, and relatively cheap.

The last 12 months has seen the cost of registering and maintaining a web site on an Internet company's servers tumble from a relatively great height. UK2Net (www.uk2.net), which claims to be the largest web hosting company in the UK, currently with 435,000 registered users, charges just £8.98 for a year's basic registration on its servers.

In return for this modest fee, you get your own registered web domain, plus email forwarding. On top of this, you'll pay from around £10 a year for hosting (storing) your web pages on UK2net's servers, with the internet firm offering to publicise your site via a variety of search engines for free.

You can also upload and maintain your own web pages via your existing internet service provider (ISP), usually for free, although usually with a less than obvious address. Another company, Free Parking, (www. freeparking.co.uk) will register, park and manage your pages for free, although you'll also have to allow the service's adverts on your pages.

Creating and editing your site is also surprisingly easy, as Microsoft's Internet Explorer (www.microsoft.com), the free Internet browser and email package that most internet kits come with, includes a page editing and upload package called Front Page Express.

Front Page Express, like Internet Explorer, is free to download and use from the Microsoft site. You can also use it to interact with your internet company's servers. All you pay is the usual cost of accessing the internet, which for most users amounts to a local phone call.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst:
Sailing equipment

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sailing equipment
fields.body:
Cowes Week is in full swing, and while a visit to www.sailsail.com won't compensate for the thrill of the ocean waves, it will help you plan your next nautical adventure. It hopes to attract beginners and professionals alike with a mix of sailing news, weather reports and interactive tutorials on sailing skills.

Before signing up for any of the clubs or schools listed on the site, the newcomer should ensure they have the latest marine clothing (if you're going to indulge in the pastimes of the rich and famous you've got to look the part). The product range at www.sweatband.com is limited to a few Douglas Gill basics including dinghy trousers (£65), gloves (£20) and buoyancy aids (£45) - but will ultimately feature brands such as Reef, Helly Hansen and Fat Face in addition to specialist technical clothing and a wide range of nautical equipment. An embroidery service, which will allow crews to email the site with their logo and have it embroidered on their kit, will be introduced shortly.

The online home of Cruisermart Express - www.yachtpeople.com - has around 4,500 items of clothing and equipment. The product range includes equipment such as binoculars (starting at £49.50 for the Tasco black rubber armoured binoculars and rising to £949 for the Steiner Commander electronic binoculars, which include a micro-processing compass) as well as specialist items of equipment for specific types of sailing.

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a saucepan
fields.trailText: ... a saucepan.
fields.body:
Rarely has a saucepan acquired such lofty status. More objet d'art than homeware - Thomas Goode, the exclusive UK retailers of this elite cookware collection, don't "do" homeware - this is a saucepan for people who take their kitchen accoutrements very seriously. The unimaginatively titled Cooking in Pure Silver collection, comprising whisks, saucepans and rice pots, was designed by Italian architects and made by San Lorenzo in Milan from the purest silver that it is possible to produce. But this is no silly extravagance. Far from it. Pure silver is, the retailer reminds us, a great conductor of heat.

Call Thomas Goode on 020-7499 2823.

webTitle: Veteran British charmer pitted against Lara Croft

fields.headline: Veteran British charmer pitted against Lara Croft
fields.trailText: Veteran screen charmer Leslie Phillips is to play a villainous sidekick in the blockbuster movie based on computer game Tomb Raider
fields.body:
Veteran screen charmer Leslie Phillips (pictured) is to play a villainous sidekick in the blockbuster movie based on computer game Tomb Raider.

The 75-year-old star - best known as a foppish ladies man in the Carry On comedies - will play a treacherous ex-friend of the father of movie heroine Lara Croft.

His character, Wilson, will join forces with villain Powell in the battle of wits against Croft, played by Oscar winner Angelina Jolie.

A spokesman for Phillips said, "Leslie has been cast in Tomb Raider . . . and he's delighted. He's just started filming this week at Pinewood."

Phillips' part in Tomb Raider is that of a one-time admirer of Lara Croft's father, Lord Croft, who has turned against him and teamed up with evil mastermind Powell.

The role of Powell is being played by Scottish actor Iain Glen, who found fame appearing naked with Hollywood star Nicole Kidman in Sam Mendes's The Blue Room at London's Donmar Warehouse Theatre.

fields.headline: Weddings
fields.standfirst:
All the chancellor of the exchequer needs to know about getting hitched

Gordon and Sarah tie the knot

Wedding photo gallery
fields.trailText: All the chancellor of the exchequer needs to know about getting hitched.
fields.body:
1. Congratulations are due today to Gordon Brown. He is making an honest woman, as they used to say, of his long-term love, Sarah Macaulay.

2. The wedding, in the chancellor's local parish church in Dunfermline, was not a lavish affair. Only close friends and family were invited. The prime minister wasn't.

3. Tony Blair was told of the happy event a few days ago. Nobody else was, outside the guest list. That is odd, because under Scottish law, the couple must notify their local registry office at least 15 days in advance of the wedding, and the notice is publicly displayed.

4. Prudence has not been altogether abandoned. The cost of the wedding is unlikely to be anything close to the astonishing national average of £12,000.

5. Still, an iron chancellor can't be too careful, especially when he has abolished the married couple's income tax allowance.

6. Scottish weddings are not especially noted for conspicuous consumption. But they can be fun, particularly in Gretna Green.

7. Marriage is an institution. It is also a vast industry which sells hard, not least on the internet.

8. You can even find out whether you and your life-partner are compatible.

9. Most of the sales pitch is directed at prospective brides, but there is also a good deal of useful advice for husbands-to-be, such as how to take out wedding insurance.

10. A canny groom could offset worry about the expense of getting hitched by browsing through some of the upmarket suggestions for that most loathsome of matrimonial adjuncts, the wedding list.

11.What gushing Gordon told Sue Lawley on Desert Island Discs: "I'm not married. It just hasn't happened. I hope it does. It may yet. It probably will do. It's one of those things that I'm surprised hasn't happened, but it hasn't."

fields.headline: Arts and sport
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, looks at how we will cope with increasing amounts of leisure time
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, looks at how we will cope with increasing amounts of leisure time.
fields.body:
The importance of leisure in our society is growing and the manifesto should recognise the longer term impact of technology which is likely to lead to a shorter working week, earlier retirement ages and people living longer.

Government should not intervene in people's leisure time, but it should recognise and discuss the importance of this dimension. Specifically, the importance of libraries and the arts in raising literacy and awareness standards, for those adults who are still impoverished on this score, should be acted on. At the same time, in sport there should be a clearer distinction between those who participate and those who watch.

For the arts such a strategy should involve more effort, and some more money, to bring about not just wider access but better understanding and appreciation of their value. To tread the path between dumbing down and damaging popularisation on the one hand and making no progress in "selling" this concept to sceptical people will not be easy. But it could be done with a determined long term effort involving local authorities, charities and enlightened employers.

Sport is a different kettle of fish and, while it doesn't compete with the arts, has to live alongside it. Again local authorities and others might have a role to play in developing facilities both for "individual" sports, such as jogging, as well as team activities and team events.

For major sports self regulation is best, but given the national importance of some of these, especially football, public money accompanied by appropriate promises of delivery in return might be in order, backed by some kind of regulator. But the emphasis should be on the players not the spectators; and on the widest public involvement, not just winning World Cups.

The manifesto should promise that the department of culture - perhaps renamed "department of leisure" - should take a more positive, but light handed, long term role towards what is going to be one of the biggest challenges in the 21st century.
