fields.headline: Heavy surfers pay the price
fields.standfirst: Of course you can have unlimited, unmetered access to the net - as long as you don't use it too much, reports  Neil McIntosh
fields.trailText: Of course you can have unlimited, unmetered access to the net - as long as you don't use it too much, reports Neil McIntosh
fields.body:
When Robin Downs signed up for Breathe's unmetered internet access deal, Breathe Freely, he thought it would save him a fortune.

For a one-off payment of £50, Robin - a systems consultant based in the West Midlands - could surf the net whenever and for as long as he wanted. Breathe Freely's free 24/7 internet service, one of a rash of new unmetered access deals announced in April and May this year, would mean he would have no worries about racking up those giant phone bills every UK-based net user dreads.

Or so he thought. Last week, three months after signing up to Breathe's offer, he was unceremoniously disconnected from the service provider's unmetered offering. The reason? He was using it too much.

Around 500 other "heavy users" found they, too, were no longer breathing freely.

Their disappointment was mirrored by thousands of surfers using different ISPs around the country who - while not actually thrown off their services - were suffering woeful levels of service.

Breathe, founded by Martin Dawes Telecommunications and backed by £20m from Chase Capital Partners, 3i and US Flatiron Partners, had invoked a clause in its terms and conditions allowing it to disconnect anyone who "puts our ability to supply the service at risk".

But at least Downs and his fellow "heavy breathers" had enjoyed some kind of service - albeit briefly. Rhys Tucker, from Cardiff, is one of many NTL users who were looking forward to similar savings way back in March, when the cable giant promised: "From 17 April 2000, you'll be able to surf the internet free of charge!" Tucker is still waiting, along with thousands of other net users, for the vital CD-rom to arrive in the post, so he can get connected.

By the end of last week the Advertising Standards Authority had received 144 complaints about NTL's advertising of the service, and it has launched a formal investigation. NTL, if nothing else, can at least claim the dubious honour of the highest ever number of complaints over matters of fact in an advertisement, notching up nearly double last year's record.

Meanwhile, across the country, net users signed up to other unmetered ISPs are struggling with engaged tones, slow service and technical cock-ups.

LineOne has announced it is pulling the plug on its unmetered access from the end of September, provoking a frosty letter from its trade association, the Internet Service Providers' Association, asking it to explain its actions. Virgin.Net abandoned plans to unveil its own flat-rate service last month. Even BT's own ISP, BTInternet, has drawn complaints over its level of service, especially on weekday evenings.

The ISPs' long summer of discontent started in a blaze of hype in March. AltaVista announced it would launch a new form of internet access which would give users free calls to the net. The company did not actually deliver until the very end of June - but that did not stop several other ISPs launching competing offers almost straight away.

On the horizon was a deal, brokered by telecoms watchdog Oftel, which would force BT to offer the means to provide unmetered internet access at wholesale prices. With BT dragging its heels, that is only beginning to happen, meaning the ISPs are left paying users' phone bills. Some ISPs feel that is a price they are not willing to pay.

At Breathe Freely, however, it appears to have simply been a question of capacity - or lack of it. The company decided it wanted to skim off the most internet-use intensive - and expensive - 1% of its users.

"We got it wrong," admits Sean Gardner, chief operating officer of Breathe, trying to explain why Robin Downs and around 500 other users were cut off. "When we launched Breathe Freely we were among the first unmetered ISPs, and there was no forward visibility as to what the usage patterns would be.

"Looking over the first three months of the service, we found that 1% of the users were causing real problems for the rest. Had it been half of the user base, we would have had problems, but doing this was the right thing for the majority."

But why could Breathe, with its high-profile financial backing and big-budget advertising campaign, not simply invest in its infrastructure to provide a decent service to all its users? Gardner says the technology which they opted for at launch was, remarkably, not scaleable to meet demand. Breathe Freely will relaunch this month, he says, with more flexible technology in place.

Meanwhile, he says, the company has learnt a lot about users' voracious appetites for the internet when they are not paying by the minute for a connection.

"The research company, Durlacher, predicted a three-fold increase in a user's internet use when they got unmetered access. Our experience pointed to an increase of six to 10 times previous usage. We just could not predict that," says Gardner. He says one user somehow managed to clock up 29 hours of usage in one day by setting up an ISDN-style connection.

"There were also several businesses using the service," he adds, "and we had made it clear this offer was not for business users."

But Downs insists that he was not abusing Breathe Freely before he was cut off, using it mainly in the evenings and then largely only for internet chats with friends living abroad. "They say they have a small proportion of users on for a long time," he says. "But, statistically, that is always going to be the case - you're going to get people who use it a lot, and those who do not use it at all."

Downs is now challenging the validity of the clause in Breathe's contract that says users can be disconnected if their level of use puts the service at risk.

He is also angry he got no warning that his levels of use were considered abnormal. "At no point have I had problems getting on to Breathe," he adds. "I've not been hearing the engaged tone - it didn't appear line capacity was an issue."

Over at NTL, consumer public relations manager Jacqueline Aldridge says it, too, has been caught out by demand. It has been limiting the number of CDs issued to preserve the quality of their service (although Online readers who have managed to get CDs have complained about engaged tones, downed email services and sluggish responses from NTLworld).

"There has been very high demand for the service so we have been managing distribution of discs," she says. "Obviously, there are very frustrated and disappointed customers, because they are keen to get the service as soon as possible.

"We're sending out discs now very rapidly to people in the queue, and everyone who signed up before the end of May should get their disc before the end of August. Anyone who signed up after that is being told exactly how long they will have to wait.

"Most people who are using the service are really liking it. Just because it is a free service doesn't mean you shouldn't be able to get connected, or have the service collapse under the weight of people using it. We want to make sure that, for the people who are using it, it's a really high quality experience."

For would-be NTLworld user Rhys Tucker that isn't the point: he feels the email he was sent in March promised him free internet access in mid-April, and NTL's failure to deliver that has cost him money in charges made to NTL's standard, metered service. He is now pursuing a claim against NTL in Cardiff county court in an attempt to recoup those charges.

"I'm really annoyed by it all," he says. "What really gets me is that they can promise free internet access and then just not honour that commitment. They promised existing customers would have priority, but that doesn't seemed to have happened at all."

The problems some ISPs are facing with unmetered access are not deterring their rivals - this week ic24 announced plans to extend its free hours online to weekday evenings. The company's marketing director, Jill Playle, has even lambasted other ISPs for deceiving consumers and taken a lie detector test in an attempt to prove her company's "after eight" deal is really free.

It is, but the company's offering is still restricted, running only for four hours a night during the week, and users get cut off after one hour to discourage loitering.

So is unconditional, quality unmetered internet access ever going to come to pass? Telecoms analyst Tim Johnson of Ovum, an IT research house, says that the arrival of a new bulk-buying arrangement with BT (see panel) will make it much easier for ISPs to offer flat-rate access 24 hours a day, by fixing their costs.

The new system, he says, has proven technically difficult to implement, and has taken BT and some ISPs by surprise. But, he adds, "when they do get round to it, it will change the whole scene.

"In 12 months' time," he promises, "fixed rate access will be what everyone is doing, as a matter of course."

Can we turn this telecoms fiasco into Friaco?

So far, unmetered access has been a fiasco. Aside from problems with quality, even signing up to an unmetered ISP has been complicated by demands to switch phone companies, and install special software that forces you to look at advertisements.

These problems stem from the struggle ISPs face to recoup their costs from unmetered access. They are effectively having to pay users' phone bills by the minute, while being paid only a flat fee, if anything, by the user. They are unable to buy connections in bulk from BT, whose only flat rate product - Surftime - is dismissed by many as too expensive and too complicated to administer.

There is some hope, however. BT has been told by the telecoms regulator, Oftel, that it must offer a new solution for ISPs wanting to offer unmetered access. That solution is called Friaco - for flat rate internet access call origination. Friaco could have a dramatic effect on the way Britain accesses the internet. According to the Campaign for Unmetered Telecommunications (Cut), "always-on" Friaco connections could cost ISPs as little as £60 a year per user, which works out at 60 to 80% less than BT Surftime.

That is low enough to keep subscriptions low, or even free.

Friaco was supposed to be available from June 1, but continued haggling between BT and ISPs means it has been delayed.

Negotiations are continuing between ISPs and BT over how the costs will be split, but it is expected that we will begin to see the first Friaco services in the last three months of this year.

And that means, finally, we could be surfing on a flat rate in time for Christmas.

Cut's Erol Ziya says that, while this summer's problems might create short-term scepticism about unmetered offers, in the long term "it will take off".

"It is the only sensible way to use the internet," he says.

"Things will settle down, and there will be a range of providers at a range of prices and quality.

"There is a market for pay by the minute, but that will become the niche it always should have been."

webTitle: How Macaulay triumphed when so many others failed

fields.headline: How Macaulay triumphed when so many others failed
fields.standfirst: Wedding photo gallery
fields.trailText: Prudence never did pose a threat to Sarah Jane Macaulay and today this smart, successful woman will prove just that.
fields.body:
Prudence never did pose a threat to Sarah Jane Macaulay and today this smart, successful woman will prove just that.

As she marries one of the most confirmed bachelors in British politics, the communications executive should be safe in the knowledge she has triumphed where so many others have failed.

As with all his romantic attachments, Gordon Brown's passion for politics has muscled in on the relationship and blunted romance, but unlike those who went before her, Ms Macaulay always held her own.

Sarah was a 34-year-old public affairs consultant when she encountered the chancellor for the first time, but it was not until two years later that romance blossomed. The couple became inseparable but the 49-year-old chancellor never allowed their relationship to get in the way of his work at the Treasury.

One of Mr Brown's friends commented: "She is intelligent, fun and quite political. On top of that she is attractive and successful. They are quite an item. They are simply made for one another."

It was the kind of situation which had caused Gordon Brown's former girlfriends to "move on" as one of them had put it, unable to cope with a man who was virtually mesmerised by his job. But Miss Macaulay realised, probably more than he did, the depth of their feeling for each other.

He told an interviewer: "I do have a relationship at the moment, but I don't think she'd appreciate me talking about it."

The all-consuming passion for politics frightened off more than one woman in Mr Brown's romantic past. Princess Margarita of Romania was one of his long-standing sweethearts.

The eldest daughter of the exiled King Michael and the great, great, great granddaughter of Queen Victoria, 53rd in line to the British throne met Mr Brown at a soiree in Edinburgh in 1968. But the couple parted after five years. She said: "I never stopped loving him, but one day it didn't seem right any more. It was poli tics, politics, politics, and I needed nurturing."

Sarah Jane Macaulay was born in Beaconsfield in October 1963, the eldest of three children. Her father Ian Macaulay worked for Longman the publisher and her mother Pauline was a secretary, later a schoolteacher.

When she was two, Sarah moved to Tanzania where she lived with her parents and brothers Sean and Magnus for seven years. Her parents split up shortly after they returned to Britain.

She attended Acland Burghley comprehensive school in Tufnell Park, north London and spent her sixth form at Camden High School for Girls.

It was there that she first met Julia Hobsbawm, daughter of Eric Hobsbawm, the historian, who later became her partner in the successful PR firm Hobsbawm Macaulay Communications.

Sarah went to Bristol University where she gained a 2.1 in psychology before moving into design and communications. The firm she established with Ms Hobsbawm was ranked in the country's top 50 in public relations.

webTitle: Gordon and Sarah tie the knot

fields.headline: Gordon and Sarah tie the knot
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor's wedding surprise
How Macaulay triumphed
The marriage no one noticed
Wedding photo gallery
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown and PR executive Sarah Macaulay got married today in a small church ceremony in the chancellor's Dunfermline constituency.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown and PR executive Sarah Macaulay got married today in a small church ceremony in the chancellor's Dunfermline constituency.

Mr Brown proposed in January this year but had kept the date secret from cabinet colleagues and the press to minimise publicity. The couple met in 1994 and began their relationship in 1996.

"We are overjoyed. It has been a wonderful day and a lovely ceremony," the newly-weds said afterwards at the chancellor's Dunfermline home.

The service was conducted by Church of Scotland minister Sheila Munro. The prime minister, Tony Blair, and his wife, Cherie, did not attend the service but were said to be delighted at the news.

Mr Brown, 49, and his 36-year-old bride emerged from the house at 11.36am to pose for photographers. The chancellor was wearing a blue suit and white shirt with a white rose in his button hole. His new wife, wearing a long tailored ivory jacket and matching dress, was carrying a posy of white and cream roses.

The couple kissed each other as their guests looked on smiling from the back of the house. Mr Brown's brother, John, 51, who had been best man at the ceremony, came out on to the lawn grinning.

The newly-weds are expected to fly to the upmarket New England resort of Cape Cod, on the United States east coast, to begin their honeymoon later today.

When the couple return they will move into Mr Brown's central London apartment, and split their time between there and the chancellor's Scottish home. His wife will sell her south London apartment, said friends. The couple plan a celebration party in Mr Brown's constituency in September, as well as a London party for colleagues and friends.

webTitle: Bank keeps interest rates on hold at 6%

fields.headline: Bank keeps interest rates on hold at 6%
fields.standfirst: Inflation hawks tamed in interest rates debate
fields.trailText: The Bank of England today gave relief to both industry and homeowners, leaving interest rates on hold for the sixth month in succession.
fields.body:
The Bank of England today gave relief to both industry and homeowners, leaving interest rates on hold for the sixth month in succession.

The Bank's nine-member Monetary Policy Committee voted to keep the official cost of borrowing unchanged at 6% - a decision widely expected by City analysts.

It will come as welcome respite for manufacturers who had feared a rate rise would drive the pound back up against the euro, adding to their problems in overseas markets.

The decision will also be welcomed by the City, which was concerned recent government figures showing an unexpectedly strong 0.9% growth in gross domestic product could lead to a rise.

Analysts were also worried about the effect on wages of extra public spending from the chancellor's Comprehensive Spending Review which could create inflationary pressures in the economy and lead to a rate rise.

The decision follows evidence that the housing market has come off the boil, strengthening the case for the committee not to put up rates.

The Confederation of British Industry backed the decision to keep interest rates on hold. Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economist, said: "This will help soothe fears that manufacturing could slip back into a downturn. But companies across the economy will need longer term respite as they struggle to compete in tough foreign markets.

"The outlook for inflation is favourable, with the housing market more stable, earnings growth slowing and sterling keeping up the competitive heat. We should no longer assume that the next interest rate move will be up."

Dr Ian Peters, deputy director general of the British Chamber of Commerce, said: "The Bank is right to sit on its hands for the time being. Sterling remains too high for our exporters but, along with the cooling in average earnings and the housing market, is keeping the inflation outlook benign."

Neil Parker, senior UK economist at RBS Financial Markets, said the Bank's decision did not come as a surprise. "The City expected this decision, but this is probably only a temporary stay of execution," said Mr Parker. He said there could well be a hike in rates in the next couple of months as inflationary pressures in the economy build up.

The Institute of Directors said the decision was not surprising. The head of policy, Ruth Lea, said: "Manufacturing output growth is weak and the housing market has cooled, and the pound is still very strong against the euro." But the IoD expects rates to rise by up to 0.5% before the end of the year.

The decision was attacked as a "disaster" for jobs by union leaders who had been pressing for an immediate rates cut.

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, said that manufacturing workers would be angry at the committee's "failure" to relieve pressure on the industry. "Thousands of jobs are at risk from excessively high interest rates and the overvalued pound," he said.

fields.headline: Passnotes: Macaulay Culkin
fields.trailText: Macaulay Culkin
fields.body:
Age: 19

Appearance: Sad-eyed overgrown husk of a once angelic, blond-fringed brat.

From where do I remember that face? Think one of the most successful films of all time.

Doctor Zhivago? A Bout de Souffle? The Godfather? Home Alone.

Eh? Precocious scamp - hands slapped around face; mouth dropped open in alarm - left at home by mistake by mom and dad.

Isn't that criminal negligence? No, it's entertainment. The movie made over £300m, propelling Mac to prepubescent megastardom.

But the bubble burst? The little cherub hasn't made a movie since 1994, since when his parents have split up amid a legal wrangle over the nipper's millions. Mac's pop Kit is the archetypal showbiz dad from hell.

How Macaulay must long to, ahem, cull his kin. On the contrary, Mac now plans a family of his own with teenage bride Rachel Miner.

Macaulay Culkin a dad! He's already a stepdad, to pal Michael Jackson's son, Prince Michael Jackson Jr.

I find that scary. Me too.

And the career today? The comeback starts here, in Britain, where Mac is preparing to take to the London stage, in the play Madame Melville, by RSC veteran Richard Nelson.

Surely not a cynical casting coup designed to flog extra tickets and revive Mac's ebbing career? Not at all. "He auditioned last week and amazed everyone," says a production insider.

What's it about? A teenager has a fling with an older woman.

And the resemblance to current West End talking point The Graduate? Is purely coincidental.

Theatre/child star crossovers from which Mac takes heart: Shirley Temple's Lady Macbeth; Lena Zavaroni's Hedda Gabler; Billie Piper's Madame Ranevskaya.

You made them up, didn't you? You always have to spoil everything.

Most likely to be: Obligingly interviewed by every single paper in the weeks preceding his show.

fields.headline: Bigsave.com shelves stock market listing
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Bigsave.com, the online department store owned by Hong Kong-based financier Jim Mellon, has shelved plans for a stock market flotation that was to have valued the business at £300m.
fields.body:
Bigsave.com, the online department store owned by Hong Kong-based financier Jim Mellon, has shelved plans for a stock market flotation that was to have valued the business at £300m.

Ian Wilson, Bigsave's chief executive, said the decision had been informed by tough market conditions, which continue to punish hi-tech stocks. The company will re-examine plans to join the market at the end of year.

"We had been looking at the second quarter of this year for a flotation but the market conditions are not right," he said. "We are not experiencing any difficulties raising private financing because we are meeting our performance targets so there is no need to rush."

Bigsave's stated aim is to reach profitability by 2002. The company has raised $22m (£14.7m) in private investment so far from backers including Equitable Life, Friends Provident and a string of wealthy individuals.

Its latest initiative is the launch of a nightly Bigsave-branded show on digital home shopping channel Ideal World.

Mr Mellon has been a late convert to the internet but has adopted the faith with some vigour. In March he rebranded his investment vehicle Regent Pacific as iRegent.com, reflecting the weight of money going into internet stocks. One of his most profitable investments has been a 45% stake in Korea Online a profitable web-based insurance company. He owns 60% of Bigsave.

The British tax exile, however, is better known in this country for leading the attack that spelt the end for Hambros, the merchant bank.

Bigsave claims to have between 40,000 and 50,000 hits a day and offers a wide range of goods from electrical goods, to children's toys, books and CDs. The company's board includes former Kingfisher director Nigel Whittaker.

Mr Wilson said the Bigsave TV home shopping programme was illustrative of the way e-tailers would need to develop. "This is quite clearly a key initiative for us," he said. "It is about doing what the consumer wants and if the consumer would like to buy through the TV then we will provide the service."

webTitle: August 3: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Robert Downey Jr secures early release from jail, Ed Norton set for war drama, Goran Paskaljevic casts for How Harry Became a Tree, and Ben Affleck in line for Cinderella lead
fields.body:
 Troubled actor Robert Downey Jr (pictured) walked out of a jail in California, following his lawyers' successful lobby for an early release (see last week's story). The 35-year-old actor had served eleven months at the state prison in Corcoran when he was set free on a nominal $5,000 bail. Downey's attorney, Ross Nabatoff, had argued that the initial sentence had failed to take into account the 53 days that the actor had already served under lock and key at a drug rehabilitation centre.

 Ed Norton is reported to be in line for a $8m pay-cheque (his biggest ever) should he sign up for the lead role in MGM's Hart's War for Frequency director Gregory Hoblit. The Hollywood Reporter claims that Norton is in negotiations to star as a Princeton-educated prisoner of war in the second world war who elects to defend a black man wrongly accused of murder. The film is based on the novel by John Katzenbach and shoots next year. Norton is currently co-starring in The Score alongside screen legends Robert DeNiro and Marlon Brando.

 Ian Hart, Colm Meaney and Peter Mullan have all signed up for the eccentrically titled How Harry Became a Tree, an allegorical fable about cultural conflict in 1930s Ireland. The picture will be the first English-language project for Serb director Goran Paskaljevic, whose acclaimed Cabaret Balkan was released in the UK last week.

 Ben Affleck is in talks to take the lead in Cinderella Man, a Universal/Miramax co-production which studio bosses are hoping Billy Bob Thornton will direct. Far from being a gender-swap version of the old fairytale (Affleck in glass-slippers and a ballgown), the film spins the fact-based tale of a depression-era hero who resorts to bare-knuckle boxing in order to put food on his family's table. If talks are successful, Affleck will shoot the film immediately after completing work on Disney's Pearl Harbor and the new Jack Ryan adventure, The Sum of All Fears.

fields.headline: The end for Casiraghi
fields.trailText: Chelsea have finally accepted defeat in their bid to get Italian striker Pierluigi Casiraghi back to full fitness - and decided to collect more than £4m insurance money.
fields.body:
Chelsea have finally accepted defeat in their bid to get Italian striker Pierluigi Casiraghi back to full fitness - and decided to collect more than £4m insurance money.

The decision means that Casiraghi will never play professional football again.

Stamford Bridge chairman Ken Bates admitted: "We have been paid £4,050,000 insurance, which will mean he can't play top-level football again. We gave him 20 months, but he was still walking with a limp, so we had no choice."

The 31-year-old Italian striker played just 10 games for the Blues before suffering a horrific knee injury against West Ham. Within a few months insiders at the club were speculating - off the record - that the injury was so bad Casiraghi would never play again.

During the past two years, Casiraghi, who was Chelsea's record buy when he joined from Lazio for £5.4m, has undergone 10 operations in a brave attempt to prove the doubters wrong - but without any apparent success.

Earlier today Casiraghi's agent Fabio Parisi admitted that the player had been served six months notice by Chelsea, who will stop paying his wages this month. But he claimed the Blues have acted prematurely in consigning his player to the football scrapheap.

"Of course it was a very, very bad injury and there is only a slim chance of him making a comeback," said Parisi. "But we consider it is still too early to say he will not. It looks strange Chelsea should collect the money without Gigi's consent."

And Parisi said he hasn't ruled out the possibility of civil action against the club. "We have appealed to the Premier League about this because his contract requires that an independent medical report is completed and that's not been done," he said.

"We asked for a copy of the insurer's report but didn't receive one and have passed on the problem to lawyers in London. We are waiting to see what the FA board or the civil court will decide."

fields.headline: You are watching Big Brother ...
fields.standfirst: ... and so is everyone else.  Gareth McLean, who today joins Nancy Banks-Smith as Guardian TV critic, explains its massive - and unexpected - appeal
fields.trailText: ... and so is everyone else. Gareth McLean, who today joins Nancy Banks-Smith as Guardian TV critic, explains its massive - and unexpected - appeal.
fields.body:
Poor Ben Fogle. There was a time when he was the apple of the nation's eye, a home-grown, humble heart-throb who charmed women and inspired men. He was good with children, animals, orienteering maps and assault courses. He was handsome and clever, gallant and charming, and wise beyond his years. A leader but not authoritarian, an optimist but not a dreamer, diffident but not self-doubting. And even though he was a bit posh, Fogle was the embodiment of the hopeful wholesomeness of the BBC's Castaway experiment.

When the BBC screened the process by which they selected the 30-odd members of the public who were to be marooned on the Hebridean island of Taransay, Fogle was the kind of righteous man in whose hands most people would willingly place their future. The other castaways liked him; the public liked him; Cynthia, Castaway's resident psychologist, was full of praise for him; even the Daily Mail liked him. And the camera loved him. Alas, Fogle is now yesterday's man.

For today we have Big Brother; gentleman Ben and the other castaways are last-year's loves. The housemates ensconced and under watchful eyes in the specially built complex in east London are our new obsession. Critics may have castigated the show but Big Brother has proved as much of a hit here as in its country of origin, Holland, and the other territories where the format has been picked up.

In the US, 22m viewers have been tuning in to CBS to watch the American version; in Germany, an evicted housemate has cut a number one single and now fronts his own Saturday night TV show; and frenzied fans invaded the house in Spain on the show's final day and forced an airlift evacuation of the remaining housemate. However, it is in the Netherlands that the programme has had most impact. Trouncing everything else in the ratings, Big Brother there spawned several "stars" including Bart, the winner, who was famously caught on infrared cameras having sex with housemate, Sabine. Bart is now a Dutch national hero.

While Channel 4 isn't releasing audience figures, the first show won a higher than normal share of the audience for the station and, as the weeks go by, evictions are proclaimed and the tension mounts as to who will win the £70,000 prize; Big Brother's grip on audiences and the national psyche seems assured. And its popularity proves one thing: we like to see people suffer. Where Castaway appeals to our better nature with its intrinsic optimism, Big Brother does the opposite. The Taransay experiment is designed to show how (and whether) a community can be built. It is about cooperation, problem-solving and conflict resolution. There is something admirable and high-minded about the castaways. While there are inevitably a couple who seek fame through their appearance on the show, taking a year out to live on a Hebridean island with a bunch of strangers, grow - and kill - your own food, while eschewing creature comforts, is a high price to pay for a five-minute appearance on Richard and Judy. Castaway is about creating a utopia for all the participants. They may fight, but their situation isn't a competition; there are no losers. The prize is the experience.

Conversely, Big Brother is positively dystopian. As in all good drama, conflict was an essential part of the docusoap genre that preceded "reality TV" such as Castaway and Big Brother. Lost musicians, uncatered-for banquets and dogs in jeopardy made docusoaps the ratings successes that they were. But these were conflicts that simply arose, as they do. Castaway and Channel 4's Shipwrecked took ordinary people and put them in extraordinary circumstances. In them, conflicts arose because of the dislocation involved. The attraction of people-marooned-on-an-island programmes is seeing how ordinary people cope in alien environments.

Big Brother has taken the genre further by adding another ingredient to the mix. By introducing the prize money, its producers have made betraying one's housemates and erstwhile friends a necessity, not simply a by-product of being in a strange situation. It takes the unique selling point of the American game show Greed, which gives contestants the opportunity to eliminate fellow team members in order to get a bigger share of the prize money, and raises the stakes.

Conflict is inherent in Big Brother because it is a competition. Treachery is essential, as Nick, the stockbroker, has realised. Maligned by the media he may be - the Sun's Dominic Mohan has started a Kick Out Nick campaign - but Nick is liked by his housemates. In this week's vote on eviction, no one has voted to have him ousted. He plays the game too well, as proved by his exploits last week, when he encouraged everyone to vote for Sada and Caroline's expulsion then provided them with a shoulder on which to cry. Like Mel, he is everyone's friend and friends with no one. Nick's continual scheming and continuing presence is a testament to Big Brother's dystopian underpinnings. If the lovely Tom gets chucked out before Nick - and it could happen - it may even prove the old maxim that good guys finish last.

But it's not just the money that makes the exploits of the Big Brother housemates compelling. There is their naked desperation for fame and fortune. In the first show, Nichola came out with the bald statement: "I want to be really rich and really famous." Like the others, she will do anything that (she thinks) will endear her to the nation and her roommates. Hence Craig's inability to keep his clothes on, Nichola's please-like-me-I'm-dead-wacky clay painting and Sada's New Age philosophies and singing. Their exploits are made all the more delicious by the gap between what a candidate thinks will endear him or her and what actually does.

According to the official website, of the nine housemates left, six have said their dream job is in the media. Mel's ideal occupation is presenting a TV travel show, as is Nick's. Caroline's is writing and performing songs, while Craig wants to be a performer. Anna wants to work in the music industry and Darren is torn between presenting on MTV Europe and children's television. For them, Big Brother is a means to an end as well as a means in itself. Nick's two-facedness shows his awareness of the conventions of the game and how to subvert them.

Big Brother is such a success because, unlike Castaway, it appeals to the base urges of human nature. Of Nick, Mel, Caroline, Anna, Darren, Andrew, Tom, Nichola and Craig only the strongest - or the most scheming - will survive. Popularity, not goodness nor morality, will persist. Were Ben Fogle to stumble into the Big Brother house, he would be voted out with Machiavellian swiftness. He is simply too nice to prosper. We all love a villain, and sometimes the good guys are just too dull.

Most of the Big Brother housemates only care about winning, and those who don't care won't win. Where Castaway is about community, Big Brother is about individuality. That's why it's easier to relate to this lot than those marooned on Taransay. This is Thatcherism TV - 1984 indeed.

webTitle: Hou Hsiao-hsien: The Time to Live and the Time to Die

fields.headline: Hou Hsiao-hsien: The Time to Live and the Time to Die
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies
fields.trailText: There are several sequences of amazing emotional power, [whose] honesty and truth ...manage to summon up this little microcosm of the world perfectly. And that world succeeds in reflecting the larger universe outside, in the same way that Satyajit Ray's Apu stories did. Everything is right: the miraculous use of sound, the limpid cinematography, the natural acting create an atmosphere you can't forget
fields.body:
If Hou Hsiao-hsien, the Taiwanese director, hailed from the west, he would be more widely known as one of the world's foremost film-makers. Even so, his films have extraordinary currency on the festival circuit and have received top prizes at Venice, Cannes and Berlin, the three major European festivals. They have also been shown in art houses in at least 40 countries. His is a major voice, even if it is often drowned out by the clamour of more commercial talents.

In a way this is Hou's own fault. After making two or three superbly attractive early films, he became interested not only in the political and social intricacies of Taiwanese history, but in new and complicated narrative forms. This made his work more difficult to penetrate, even for his own countrymen. Despite that, Flowers of Shanghai, the last film of his that was presented at Cannes, was described by the Guardian's Richard Williams as worth all the rest of the programme put together.

The Time to Live and the Time to Die (a terrible English title, possibly based on the Douglas Sirk film, A Time to Love and a Time to Die) was Hou's second film to reach the west after the charming A Summer at Grandpa's and, like that film, was semi-autobiographical. In 1947, a man and his family leave the Chinese mainland and settle in a village in Taiwan. When the revolution comes, they decide to remain. The film spans several years of their life, recalled through the childhood of Ah-Ha-Gu, probably at least partly Hou himself.

The style of this family saga is spare and simple but eloquence itself. Dotty old Grandma walks down a winding road, thinking she will soon reach her old home in China; the boy grows older and instead of playing marbles and listening to stories of the old days becomes a young man trying to prove himself on the streets. There are several sequences of amazing emotional power, such as the moment when the young man's father dies and he walks into the room, completely devastated by his first meeting with mortality.

The honesty and truth of this and other similar passages manage to summon up this little microcosm of the world perfectly. And that world succeeds in reflecting the larger universe outside, in the same way that Satyajit Ray's Apu stories did. Everything is right: the miraculous use of sound, the limpid cinematography, the natural acting create an atmosphere you can't forget.

People have often compared the earlier Hou to Ray and also to Ozu. But he has always claimed that he never saw the work of those directors, at least not at the time. Perhaps it is simply that great film-makers tend to think alike. The fact is, however, that he is very much his own man, ploughing a lonely furrow, even in Taiwan. But after City of Sadness won the Golden Lion at Venice, the Taiwanese government began to regard him as their blue-riband director, despite seldom understanding his pictures, and sometimes objecting to their clear-eyed political content.

Hou went on to make more audaciously structured films like the magisterial The Puppetmaster, the true story of a famous old folk artist. And Flowers of Shanghai was certainly one of the most visually satisfying you could wish to see. But his style is now more minimalist and more introspective. The Time to Live and the Time to Die is one of his simplest films, and one of his most universal.

CREDITS

Director Hou Hsiao-hsien

With You Anshun,Tian Feng, Mei Fang

Taiwan, 1985, 137 minutes

A retrospective of Hou Hsiao-hsien's work is at the NFT, London SE1 (020-7928 3232), till August 30.

webTitle: Cage latest catch in Spiderman casting?

fields.headline: Cage latest catch in Spiderman casting?
fields.trailText: Nic Cage is rumoured to be in negotiations to play the Green Goblin, an emerald-skinned, pink-hatted psychopath given to tossing exploding pumpkins at anyone who gets in his way
fields.body:
Hot on the heels of Monday's confirmation that Tobey Maguire will star in the Spiderman feature comes news that Nicolas Cage may be poised to snare the role of his arch-enemy. The 36-year-old star is rumoured to be in negotiations to play the Green Goblin, an emerald-skinned, pink-hatted psychopath given to tossing exploding pumpkins at anyone who gets in his way.

Spiderman gossip is being monitored with enthusiastic zeal by the website spidermanhype.com. The fan-site first broke the Maguire casting news and claims that the Nic Cage tip stems from the same insider source. The Gone in Sixty Seconds star is now considered to be in pole position for the role. Onetime favourite Liam Neeson is a doubtful bet following last month's road accident which resulted in a broken pelvis and internal injuries.

Spiderman is scheduled to begin filming in November, which should fit in neatly with Cage's schedule. The actor is currently on location in Greece for the trouble-plagued adaptation of Captain Corelli's Mandolin. After that, a well-paid spot of pantomime villainy may offer a much-needed change of pace.

webTitle: Net reveals secret of Hollywood hits

fields.headline: Net reveals secret of Hollywood hits
fields.trailText: How to turn out a blockbuster is the elusive holy grail of film-making. John Travolta's Battlefield Earth was only the latest turkey to vindicate screenwriter William "The Sting" Goldman's maxim that in Hollywood "nobody knows nothing".
fields.body:
How to turn out a blockbuster is the elusive holy grail of film-making. John Travolta's Battlefield Earth was only the latest turkey to vindicate screenwriter William "The Sting" Goldman's maxim that in Hollywood "nobody knows nothing".

A survey by the internet Movie Database now claims to shed light on what Steven Spielberg calls the "mystery of mysteries", after questioning some of 50,000 fans who use the website regularly.

It found that, unless a film fitted a recognisable genre, the odds would be heavily stacked against it - crime stories, prison dramas, sci-fi and bio-pics figure in many "all-time great" lists of films.

Another asset was a conventional boy-meets-girl love story running through the film. And, though it may seem blindingly obvious, strong plots helped, as did a few big name stars. Keeping the title short, preferably one or two words, did not do any harm either, the study found.

Film-making might not be rocket science, said the Guardian's veteran critic Derek Malcolm, but in 30 years of reviewing "mostly bad" films, he had found there were no hard and fast rules.

"No one really knows, but what Hollywood tends to forget is that you can't beat a good story and a good script." Producers used to say that if a person thinking about going to a film could not explain it to a friend in a sentence beforehand, they were not likely to buy a ticket.

"So much film-going is based round word of mouth, that you cannot make the sell too complicated for the masses. That may sound a bit condescending, but I'm afraid they have found that to be the case."

Alan Parker, the head of the new Film Council, and director of such hits as The Commitments, Bugsy Malone and Midnight Express, was also convinced that only good, well told stories could be popular.

But money did make a difference, he said. "There is a strong correlation between how big a film's budget is and how much it makes. That has been the problem with so many British films down the years." Many film-makers also forgot that, if a film appealed to under-25s, most of the cinema audience, it was far more likely to succeed.

Titles were a trickier issue. "It's true that short ones tend to work better," said Derek Malcolm, "but look at Four Weddings and a Funeral. The most perfect British title of recent years has to be The Full Monty - short, snappy and suggestive, you can't get better than that."

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Spinal Tapster | Apocamon now
fields.body:
Spinal Tapster
While a certain heavy metal band - yes, you know the one! - seems to have some kind of problem with MP3s, archetypal headbangers Spinal Tap, thankfully, do not, especially when they are looking for ways to promote the September re-release of their film This Is Spinal Tap. You can go to the new Tapster site and download the free MP3 of their comeback single, Back from the Dead. While there, why not download some more free MP3s of music "inspired by, ripped off from and dedicated to Spinal Tap". The press release notes: "This will be far more controversial than Napster, really," said Tap's Nigel Tufnel. Bassist Derek Smalls added: "We' re not unnecessarily concerned about intellectual property - this isn't about Harvard, Yale or Oxford."

Rude bits
If the appeal of saccharine electronic postcards with those horrible tinkly computerised music tracks has just about worn off by now, how about going for a mix of naughty bits and atoms instead? At www.moonpig.com you can use the web to send a proper paper card for £1.99 plus P&P, which they'll print out and sign for you. Of course there are clean cards there too, but we liked being able to choose from categories such as Beer and Beaujolais, Lavatorial, and Rumpy Pumpy. Extra bonus feature: a "naughty filter" lets you look at (or avoid) all the dirty-joke cards.

Top of the flops
Lost Musicals is a UK-based site that lovingly chronicles all those painful flops and failures that fleetingly graced the West End and Broadway stages. Moby Dick, the musical, is among them, but you can read the playbills for others or keep an eye on promising failures in the Flopwatch section of the site.

Pop charts
Factoid and pie graph fans will like the Population Reference Bureau, which has every imaginable type of statistic relating to population for 221 countries. The subsection on the European region brings up details on world refugee populations, women's lives, the high death rate among Russian men, and more.

Apocamon now
Many parents already consider Pokemon monsters to be a plague, so the existence of Apocalypse Monsters, or Apocamon, may come as no surprise. See them in full colour and read all about each one at Apocamon, the Final Judgement. A drop-down menu encyclopedia lets you "find out their powers, their missions, and which segments of humanity they intend to destroy". If you doubt the authenticity of Apokemon, note that the site's contents are copyright 80AD to St John the Divine.

Money talks
Political activism is alive and well on the web, even for billionaires. They are getting organised for the US presidential election at billionaires for Bush or Gore www.billionairesforbushorgore.com "because inequality is not growing fast enough". To further their ends, they offer a price/performance analysis of the presidential candidates, and invite visitors to participate in the ultimate posh protest, the Million Billionaire March. If you prefer to rebel at home, the site also offers a section full of useful chants and slogans. "Take to your cell phones, take to your faxes, Join the fight to end all taxes!"

Happy eaters
Finding vegetarian-friendly restaurants can be tough, but it is especially hard for travelling veggie lovers. Globetrotting vegetarians might want to check out the Happy Cow, which offers a listing of more than 1,600 vegetarian restaurants all around the world.

Boo hoo
Reports of the death of the net economy may be exaggerated. But there is a certain grim fascination in watching things go wrong, and sites are springing up to follow the death throes of assorted dot.coms. Best known is www.fuckedcompany.com, "the dot com deadpool", which relishes kicking 'em while they're down. More mainstream is Bubble Economy at www.bubbleeconomy.com ("prepare for the pop"), which tracks the business pundits as they voice their internet angst.

Jargon watch
WordSpy is a word-a-day site dedicated to recently coined words or words that are staging a comeback but used in new ways. It has a random word generator and an archive, or you can subscribe to a daily mailing list. The site also has a Tech WordSpy section.

New and noted
Follow Macmillan Cancer relief's two-week bike-ride across Mongolia from your armchair at www.everyoneswelcome.com; generate your own Corrs and U2 lyrics at www.p45.net; and search for services five minutes from any motorway junction at www.5minutesaway.co.uk.

At www.moonpig.com you can use the web to send a proper paper card for £1.99 plus P&P, which they'll print out and sign for you. Of course there are clean cards there too, but we liked being able to choose from categories such as Beer and Beaujolais, Lavatorial, and Rumpy Pumpy. Extra bonus feature: a "naughty filter" lets you look at (or avoid) all the dirty-joke cards. Top of the flops Lost Musicals is a UK-based site that lovingly chronicles all those painful flops and failures that fleetingly graced the West End and Broadway stages. Moby Dick, the musical, is among them, but you can read the playbills for others or keep an eye on promising failures in the Flopwatch section of the site. Pop charts Factoid and pie graph fans will like the Population Reference Bureau, which has every imaginable type of statistic relating to population for 221 countries. The subsection on the European region brings up details on world refugee populations, women's lives, the high death rate among Russian men, and more. Apocamon now Many parents already consider Pokemon monsters to be a plague, so the existence of Apocalypse Monsters, or Apocamon, may come as no surprise. See them in full colour and read all about each one at Apocamon, the Final Judgement. A drop-down menu encyclopedia lets you "find out their powers, their missions, and which segments of humanity they intend to destroy". If you doubt the authenticity of Apokemon, note that the site's contents are copyright 80AD to St John the Divine. Money talks Political activism is alive and well on the web, even for billionaires. They are getting organised for the US presidential election at billionaires for Bush or Gore www.billionairesforbushorgore.com "because inequality is not growing fast enough". To further their ends, they offer a price/performance analysis of the presidential candidates, and invite visitors to participate in the ultimate posh protest, the Million Billionaire March. If you prefer to rebel at home, the site also offers a section full of useful chants and slogans. "Take to your cell phones, take to your faxes, Join the fight to end all taxes!" Happy eaters Finding vegetarian-friendly restaurants can be tough, but it is especially hard for travelling veggie lovers. Globetrotting vegetarians might want to check out the Happy Cow, which offers a listing of more than 1,600 vegetarian restaurants all around the world. Boo hoo Reports of the death of the net economy may be exaggerated. But there is a certain grim fascination in watching things go wrong, and sites are springing up to follow the death throes of assorted dot.coms. Best known is www.fuckedcompany.com, "the dot com deadpool", which relishes kicking 'em while they're down. More mainstream is Bubble Economy at www.bubbleeconomy.com ("prepare for the pop"), which tracks the business pundits as they voice their internet angst. Jargon watch WordSpy is a word-a-day site dedicated to recently coined words or words that are staging a comeback but used in new ways. It has a random word generator and an archive, or you can subscribe to a daily mailing list. The site also has a Tech WordSpy section. New and noted Follow Macmillan Cancer relief's two-week bike-ride across Mongolia from your armchair at www.everyoneswelcome.com; generate your own Corrs and U2 lyrics at www.p45.net; and search for services five minutes from any motorway junction at www.5minutesaway.co.uk. Tottenham have made a £2m bid for Watford striker Tommy Smith, who scored two goals last season, reports the Sun.

Portsmouth have had a £3m bid for Millwall striker Neil Harris rejected.

webTitle: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Left hanging on the line

Ist Line, that mobile phone telesales company which has adorned this page so frequently, may be dead, but its ghost still haunts readers like E Herbert of Carmarthenshire. She received her handset a month after ordering it on January 15. She could not get it to work and was told to return it because it was not suitable for her area. Six months later the promised pre-paid envelope finally turned up. 1st Line, however, declared the week it expired, that she would have to give thirty days' written notice and pay for the privilege before the contract could be terminated because she'd phoned to cancel on January 15, one month after connection. In vain did she explain that the handset had only arrived on that date. All, as they say, was silence.

Happily Consumer has discovered someone willing and intelligent at Cellular Operations, which services 1st Line customers and has outlived its trading partner. The balance on Herbert's account has now been cleared and a letter of apology been sent.

All in the garden is rosy

Sue Walker of Fife has spent most weekends this summer getting her new and overrun garden into shape. No sooner was it finished when she returned home to find Scottish Power had dug a huge trench across the plot, destroying bulbs and plants.

"There was no warning," she says, "and although the trench has now been filled in, the workmen have gone off for a fortnight and left all their stuff in my garden. Surely I should have been asked for permission and offered compensation."

Ofgem, the gas and electricity watchdog, says that its guidelines allow companies to do what they must without prior warning if an emergency arises, but require written permission for pre-planned work. Scottish Power says it is blameless because, although it is the one laying underground cables in Ms Walker's village, the trench was dug by a contractor, who should have warned her. "But," says a sympathetic spokesman, "because the local holidays are due for two weeks we will send round our own gardener to restore Sue's garden to its previous glory and ensure her summer toil is not completely wasted."

Getting value from your printer ink cartridge

A letter that we printed about the high price of printer ink cartridges has rattled a number of you. The Dixons Group, which is a dominating force in that market, explained that the new generations of cartridges are highly sophisticated animals whose astonishing capabilities justify the cost.

Geoff Wicks of Basildon declares it a well-known fact that manufacturers make more money from their supplies than from the actual printers. He suggests readers shop around. "The RRP of my printer cartridge is £23 but you can now get it for much less," he says. "Recently, professionally reinked cartridges have come on to the market which are cheaper still." Graham Mace also advocates ink-jet refills, which he has bought for as little as £11. Keith Scott suggests, in somewhat unmeasured tones, that the problem is lack of competition in the high street and points out helpfully that US prices are much cheaper.

According to Tracey Rawling Church of Kyocera Electronics, it's not the retailers who inflate the prices, but the manufacturers (with the exception of her own firm, naturally). "Most of them admit that it's their objective to milk the market," she says. "Hewlett-Packard has just increased its laser consumables by up to 22% - the third increase this year - and IT magazine Microscope this week quotes an HP representative as saying, 'We have a profit we want to make ... if people don't like it they don't have to buy HP printers.' "

Over to the manufacturers. Hewlett-Packard admits its recent price hikes, but blames them on "currency fluctuations" and on its $1bn investment in improving technology. "All our cartridges contain a printer head, which others don't, and increased printer efficiency means you actually use less ink per page," says a spokeswoman. Epson says that it "prices itself against the opposition". "We offer RRPs but we have no control over what retailers charge," says a spokesman.

As for Canon, Consumer did a bit of quick research and found that cartridges on sale on its web site cost more or the same as in much-maligned Dixons. The key is to divide the price of the cartridge by the yield to discover the cost of printing per page. You might find that some of the pricier examples work out better value in the long run.

webTitle: The moment the Republicans' smiley mask slipped

fields.headline: The moment the Republicans' smiley mask slipped
fields.standfirst:
Delegates forgot about their party's cuddly new image when Dick Cheney took the podium, reports Julian Borger in Philadelphia

Full text of speech
fields.trailText:
3 August, 10.30am: Delegates forgot about their party's cuddly new image when Dick Cheney took the podium, reports Julian Borger in Philadelphia.
Full text of speech
fields.body:
The Republican crowd had been drip-fed on syrup all week. Sweet, positive talk, a sugar-coated version of racial inclusion and huge doses of honeyed optimism.

They lapped it up happily enough, but the sort of people who cross the country to come to party conventions are political carnivores. They crave red meat, and when they finally got it last night, they roared their appreciation.

The man chosen to feed them was the vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney, who had been thought too nice and dignified a man to take on the traditional number-two role of going negative.

He went all out to prove the pundits wrong last night with an aggressive speech attacking Al Gore as a mere surrogate of the hated Bill Clinton.

At last, the 2,066 delegates had a means to vent the accumulated anger of the past eight years. And when Mr Cheney told them that President Clinton's "last hour is coming", the release of pent-up fury filled the Philadelphia convention hall. The cheering lasted nearly two minutes, and Mr Cheney had not yet reached his punchline.

It was a punchline he repeated, slowly, three times in the course of his prime-time address, and brought the house down each time. "It is time ... It is time for them to go," he said, unsheathing what is clearly to be one of the principal rhetorical weapons of the campaign.

It was a phrase used to effect by Al Gore in 1992, now turned against him. Last night, it found an instant resonance among party followers who have spent eight years in the wilderness.

"Time to go," the crowd chanted. It was the full-throated vocalisation of Clinton fatigue. The underlying strategy emerged clearly: to bind Mr Gore to Mr Clinton at every turn so that they become one double-barrelled epithet in the minds of the voters, and then to revile the Clinton experience.

But whereas the 1992 Gore use of the "time to go" line had an economic significance in hard times, in Cheney's lips it took on the twist of moral distaste. Neither the word "Monica" nor "Lewinsky" was mentioned, nor are they likely to be during the course of the campaign.

The Bush camp is well aware that if there is Clinton fatigue in middle America, there is even more weariness of his persecutors. The erstwhile Republican heroes of the House judiciary committee, who led the charge against Mr Clinton in the 1998 impeachment hearings, have been invisible throughout the convention, locked away like an embarrassing, muttering relative.

As the Washington Post pointed out, the Republicans were determined this year to appear "friendly neighbours rather than nasty snoops". So the Bush camp, reluctant to foreswear the memory of Monica altogether, have evolved a set of euphemisms, like vicarage gossips who are dying to reprise a squalid tale but prevented from doing so by good taste and propriety.

"On the first hour of the first day" of a Bush administration, Mr Cheney promised, the new president "will restore decency and integrity to the Oval Office."

You could almost hear the sighs of relief coming from the Gore campaign headquarters. The nice multicultural Republicanism of the first three days had really begun to scare the Democrats, for whom the low point was General Colin Powell's rousing appeal for racial inclusion on Monday night.

In a presidential race in which Mr Gore is trailing by more than 10 points, the Democrats are longing for the mean-spirited, middle-aged white men of the Republicans' 1994 revolution led by Newt Gingrich (another name not even whispered in this year's convention).

Possibly for that reason, President Clinton has appeared in recent days to play the role of goad, taunting George W Bush for his alleged reliance on "daddy" to fight the election, nearly provoking George senior into losing his temper, but not quite.

Even if George the younger resumes the upbeat, positive tone of the convention, the Democrats will still have Dick Cheney to gnaw on. They have his past congressional votes: against the release of Nelson Mandela from an apartheid jail, and against the Head Start educational assistance programme for poor children.

Now he has turned negative. It stoked the crowd and made him the party's darling for the night, but it also meant that the happy-smiley mask, elaborately painted in many hues over the first 72 hours of the convention, finally slipped.

fields.headline: Stars' money-man admits to fraud
fields.trailText: The financial guru to a galaxy of Hollywood stars, including Leonardo DiCaprio and Cameron Diaz, yesterday broke down in tears as he pleaded guilty to embezzling as much as $10m from his clients' bank accounts
fields.body:
The financial guru to a galaxy of Hollywood stars yesterday broke down in tears as he pleaded guilty to embezzling as much as $10m from his clients' bank accounts.

Dana Giacchetto, 37, handled the finances of some of the industry's biggest names, including Leonardo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. "Everyone will get paid back," Giacchetto promised US district court judge Robert Patterson. "We will make reparations and no one will lose any money."

Giacchetto - the owner of the Cassandra Group investment firm - pleaded guilty to one count of defrauding his clients under the Investment Advisers Fraud Act. He is believed to have used the cash to facilitate his own expensive lifestyle: reportedly purchasing a Mercedes Benz and spending $100,000 on plane tickets and $175,000 on hotel bills. When one star client would notice his or her balance shrinking, Giacchetto allegedly paid them back by plundering the accounts of another. In his heyday, he became a regular fixture on the Manhattan celebrity circuit and was regarded as a close personal friend by DiCaprio.

Offering his plea bargain yesterday, Giacchetto cut a more forlorn figure in his prison clothes, claiming that he initially set up his investment business to protect Hollywood artists from being exploited but that matters then got out of control. "I'm sorry that I'm crying, but I've been in a box for six months and it's very difficult," he said.

In fact Giacchetto has been in jail since April 12, after he allegedly jumped bail and was caught attempting to flee the country with a forged passport. He will now be formally sentenced on November 1 and could face up to five years behind bars.

fields.headline: Close-run things
fields.trailText: South Africa's breathtaking victory by seven runs in Sri Lanka yesterday was the narrowest win ever in terms of runs that has not involved Australia. The Aussies were involved in both the tied Tests, against West Indies at Brisbane in 1960-61 and against India at Madras in 1986-87. They lost to West Indies by one run at Adelaide in 1992-93, beat England by three runs at Old Trafford in 1902, and lost to England by the same margin at Melbourne in 1982-83. They lost, harrowingly, to South Africa by five runs at Sydney in 1993-94, beat England by six runs at the same venue in 1884-85, and beat England by seven runs at The Oval in 1882 (the game that spawned the Ashes).
fields.body:
South Africa's breathtaking victory by seven runs in Sri Lanka yesterday was the narrowest win ever in terms of runs that has not involved Australia. The Aussies were involved in both the tied Tests, against West Indies at Brisbane in 1960-61 and against India at Madras in 1986-87. They lost to West Indies by one run at Adelaide in 1992-93, beat England by three runs at Old Trafford in 1902, and lost to England by the same margin at Melbourne in 1982-83. They lost, harrowingly, to South Africa by five runs at Sydney in 1993-94, beat England by six runs at the same venue in 1884-85, and beat England by seven runs at The Oval in 1882 (the game that spawned the Ashes).

In all, 17 of the 22 closest wins-by-runs have involved Australia, and 13 have involved England - who pulled off one of their narrowest wins-by-wickets just the other day, when they beat West Indies by two wickets at Lord's.

Another funny thing about the list of close finishes (wins by runs, 20 or fewer) is that half of them have occurred in the last 20 years. It all started with Botham's Ashes in 1981: the world-famous victory at Headingley, by 18 runs, was only the second win by 20 runs or fewer since the Second World War (the other being another 16-run win, by the inevitable Aussies against India at Brisbane in 1976-77). But it started a fashion, and now 11 of the 22 closest finishes (victory by fewer than 20 runs, or tie) have come in the past 20 years.

It's not just runs either. There have been nine one-wicket wins in Test history, and three of them have been in the past six years - Pakistan beating Australia at Karachi in 1994-95, West Indies beating Australia at Bridgetown in 1998-99 (Lara's match), and West Indies again beating Pakistan at Antigua just the other day. Plus, the closest draw ever, the one between Zimbabwe and England that ended with the scores level, took place in 1996-97. But no Aussies were involved in that one, unless you count Alan Mullally.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

Plus, the closest draw ever, the one between Zimbabwe and England that ended with the scores level, took place in 1996-97. But no Aussies were involved in that one, unless you count Alan Mullally. Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Lastminute.com makes £9.3m loss
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com, the internet shopping service co-founded by Martha-Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman, made a loss of £9.3m in the last three months, the group said today.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, the internet shopping service co-founded by Martha-Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman, made a loss of £9.3m in the last three months, the group said today.

The figure, recorded for the quarter-year to June 30, compares to a loss of £1.1m for the same period last year. However the group, which sells holidays and gifts online, said it had seen a set of "strong" results. It added that the current quarter-year had begun with July being "significantly the strongest" trading month the company had experienced.

Lastminute said its subscriber numbers across Europe had jumped by 50% to 2.1m while the number of items sold over its service grew by 21% to 90,500. The group, which floated on the London stock market in March, has been in the spotlight after its shares, which leapt following the flotation, quickly fell below their issue price leaving investors nursing a big loss.

webTitle: All change and smiles all round

fields.headline: All change and smiles all round
fields.trailText: The weather was wet for the start of Atherton and Stewart's 100th Test, but England's bowlers did much to tee up the moment when they will they will eventually take to the crease.
fields.body:
The weather was wet for the start of Atherton and Stewart's 100th Test, but that's probably just how they liked it. Atherton merely to be awkward; Stewart because it ensured that he wouldn't break into a sweat and sully his beautifully white and pressed shirt. But despite the truncated play (only 42 overs were possible) both will feel free to raise a glass and toast a successful Thursday.

England announced four changes from Lord's - so much for consistency. It was goodbye to Matthew Hoggard (for ever?), Andy Flintoff, Mark Ramprakash and Graeme Hick (who if they ever play again will be on their 11th call-ups). And hello Nasser Hussain, Graham Thorpe, Marcus Trescothick and Robert Croft. Croft's inclusion was the most illogical. It is said that Old Trafford's Test pitches take less spin than the county ones, and Croft's county form, though not diabolical (17 wickets at 36), hardly suggests Murali-style demolition.

But maybe it was his inclusion which encouraged Jimmy Adams to bat first - perhaps he doubted whether his batsmen in their current state of collapsability could face the craft of Croft in the final innings? They certainly didn't look too hot against England's seaming sensations.

Darren, Dominic and Andy are really starting to have a nice ring to them these days. Caddick found extra height and bounce, Cork found substantial early and late swing. When he got Wavell Hinds, a little fortunately, in his 3rd over he had conceded not one run. And Darren Gough charged in and hit Brian Lara with a short 90mph-plus ball before opening him up as easily as a battered old envelope. That's three Lara dismissals in the bag now for Goughie, something he won't be keeping quiet about.

Thorpe, meanwhile, is having a dream return. Two reaction catches at third slip of the sort that David Lloyd would have put on a tape to the accompaniment of Land of Hope and Glory. And Thorpe smiled - nay, grinned and even opened his mouth to shout with joy. He must be glad to be back. But it is probably another nail in the coffin for Hick, who has dropped more catches than he has taken for England recently. And a slip cordon of Atherton, Trescothick and Thorpe looks a safer one than England have seen for a while.

England shouldn't get too overconfident. Adams is still hanging around; and as England found out at Edgbaston, Pakistan discovered in Antigua (and Australia too, last time they toured West Indies) he can be a limpet to end all limpets. At the other end is Sarwan, one of today's most talked-about young players, who has already unleashed one textbook on-drive.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: The cricket hooligans who ruined a Test match

fields.headline: The cricket hooligans who ruined a Test match
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Can you refresh my memory about that famous Test which was abandoned when protesters dug up the pitch? asks Steve Sheekey
fields.body:
Can you refresh my memory about that famous Test which was abandoned when protesters dug up the pitch? asks Steve Sheekey

It was the third Test between England and Australia at Headingley in August 1975. The match was evenly poised going into the final day: England had made 288 (David Steele 73, John Edrich 62, Tony Greig 51, Gary Gilmour 6-85) and 291 (Steele 92, Greig 49). Australia were bowled out for 135 (Phil Edmonds 5-28 on debut), raising hopes that England would level the series at 1-1. Needing 425 to win, Australia had reached 220 for 3 by the end of the fourth day. But when the players arrived next morning they discovered that part of the pitch had been dug up, and oil had also been poured on it. The perpetrators were campaigning for the release of George Davis, a small-time criminal who had recently been convicted and imprisoned. The match was abandoned (it then rained for much of the day, so it would probably have been a draw anyway). The main sufferer was Australia's opener Rick McCosker, who was stranded on 95 not out. At the time he had not scored a Test century - but he put that right with 127 in the next Test, at the Oval. That match was also drawn, with Bob Woolmer making 149 for England, and Australia took the series 1-0.

Can you tell me the address of Rashid Latif's website? asks Waqar Ali

Rashid Latif is the former Pakistan captain and wicketkeeper who has been one of the loudest voices in the fight to expose match-fixing. You can find his website at www.rashidlatif.8k.com

Where and when was the first day/night one-day international played? asks Chinta Rajap from Switzerland

The first matches under floodlights were played during Kerry Packer's World Series Cricket at the end of the 1970s, but they don't count as official one-day internationals. The first official one-dayer under lights was Australia v West Indies at Sydney on Nov 27, 1979. Australia, batting second, won by five wickets. The first man to score an international century under lights was Allan Border, with 105* for Australia v India at Sydney on Dec 18, 1980. Geoff Boycott (105 for England v Australia, Melbourne 1979-80) and Greg Chappell (138* for Australia v New Zealand, Sydney, 1980-81) scored centuries in day/night matches before Border, but unlike him they batted in the first innings of the match, before the lights had taken effect.

Can you tell me who topped the batting averages for the 1998-99 Sheffield Shield season please? There's a lot riding on this one says Craig Hodges

It was Darren Lehmann, of South Australia, who made 539 runs in the Sheffield Shield alone at an average of 134.75. Michael Bevan of New South Wales was second with 636 runs at 106.00. In all first-class matches in Australia in 1998-99 the highest average was 118.70 by Greg Blewett, who scored two centuries for an Australian XI as well as four more for South Australia. In all first-class matches Lehmann averaged 65.78.

Is there any difference between a wrong'un, a bosey, a chinaman and a googly? asks Sandy Morgan

Wrong'un, bosey and googly are all terms for the same sort of ball - a right-arm legspinner's "mystery" ball that looks like a legbreak but actually turns into the right-hand batsman instead of away from him. The first person to bowl this regularly, early in the last century, was Bernard Bosanquet, which is where "bosey" comes from. Oddly, since Bosanquet was an Englishman (Reginald Bosanquet, the 1970s newsreader, was his son), bosey is used mainly in Australia. So is wrong'un. The odd one out is chinaman: this is delivered by a left-arm bowler rather than a right-armer, and refers to the left-arm wrist-spinner's googly (except in Australia, where it's used for his normal ball).

My office has been trying to work out who Mike Atherton's 13 Test opening partners have been. Can you help? asks Richard Harris

There has been some confusion over this in the press, not least on the part of Atherton himself, who thought he had had 10 partners, not 11, before this season. But prior to the Old Trafford Test against West Indies, his 100th, Atherton had opened the innings with 12 different people: Graham Gooch, Wayne Larkins, Alec Stewart, Mark Lathwell, Robin Smith, Jason Gallian, Nick Knight, John Crawley (in the second innings of one match after Knight was injured), Mark Butcher, Steve James, Darren Maddy and Mark Ramprakash. At Old Trafford he was due to open with Marcus Trescothick, who therefore becomes his 13th partner.

I've been trying to find out some information about Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century. Can you tell me more about the 49 players who received votes? asks Sue Guttman

The "Wisden Almanack" asked a panel of 100 distinguished players and writers from around the world to nominate their five players of the 20th century. The top five were Don Bradman (who received votes from all 100 judges), Garry Sobers, Viv Richards, Jack Hobbs and Shane Warne. For details of how the other votes were distributed click here.

Is there a fielding position called "mad-man point"? asks Ankur Agarwal

No-one at the Wisden office has heard of such a position. Someone who fields close to the bat on the off side, just in front of the crease, is called silly point (in fielding terms, "silly" describes a close-in version of a normal position, like silly mid-on or silly mid-off) - so maybe "mad-man point" is even closer to the batsman than that. But I wouldn't recommend standing there - silly point is a frightening enough place to field!

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read his previous Q&A session, Five wickets in an over - and better, click here

fields.headline: Suharto charged with corruption
fields.standfirst: Former president could be in court within days in test of Indonesia's commitment to democratic reform
fields.trailText:
Former president could be in court within days in test of Indonesia's commitment to democratic reform.
Special report: Indonesia
fields.body:
Prosecutors in Indonesia have charged former president Suharto with corruption on a huge scale and said today that he could be in court within days. "He has been formally charged. This will be followed with us filing the indictment and a dossier on the case in court," said Umbu Laga Lazore, a member of a state investigative team that looked into Mr Suharto's wealth.

"From now on Suharto's status is as a defendant," Mr Umbu said after the team officially handed over responsibility for the case to prosecutors.

The case is seen as a test of Indonesia's resolve to roll back years of corruption and push ahead with democratic reforms.

Mr Suharto, 79, a grim autocrat who ruled Indonesia for 32 years, was forced from power after riots in May 1998. He is accused of using charities under his control to siphon off £380m in state funds during his years in power. He denies any wrongdoing.

President Abdurrahman Wahid has called for Mr Suharto to be prosecuted, but says he will pardon him if he returns any ill-gotten gains. Officials met Mr Suharto's lawyers at his heavily guarded home in central Jakarta, where he has been under house arrest for several months.

Hundreds of police were nearby in case of protests by students who want Mr Suharto tried immediately, not only for corruption but also for human rights violations. Mr Suharto's lawyers say he is too sick to face trial because of a series of recent strokes. "Suharto has brain damage," said his chief counsel, Juan Felix Tampubolon. One of the former president's personal physicians, Hari Sabardi, cautioned against forcing him into a courtroom.

"We're not sure if he will be able to understand questions put to him and be able give the right answers," he said.

Attorney-general Marzuki Darusman says a recent independent medical examination found Mr Suharto fit to stand trial. He has said he wants to see the former president before a judge by 10 August. Yushar Yahya, a spokesman for the attorney-general's office, said that during today's hour-long meeting, Mr Suharto had signed a document acknowledging that he had been notified that the case was in the hands of prosecutors and that he was charged with corruption.
