webTitle: Future of the global car industry

fields.headline: GKN shrugs off car industry fears
fields.standfirst: Engineering group plans big spending on automotive supply sector
fields.trailText: The British engineering group, GKN, yesterday shrugged off fears surrounding the future of the global car industry, saying it could spend much of its £1bn war chest on acquisitions and growth in the automotive supply sector.
fields.body:
The British engineering group, GKN, yesterday shrugged off fears surrounding the future of the global car industry, saying it could spend much of its £1bn war chest on acquisitions and growth in the automotive supply sector.

GKN, which has just merged its Westland Helicopter interests with Agusta of Italy, posted record profits from its global car business on the back of a 27% increase in US sales. For the first time GKN produced more profits in the US than Britain. The company wants to double its US shareholder base from the current level of 9%, and is looking at a secondary stock market listing. Chief executive Sir CK Chow has however ruled out any corporate move to the US.

GKN also wants to expand further into the Japanese car markets, having set up a joint venture with Toyota. The UK supplier expects to see other manufacturers like Honda outsourcing much of their business. It has just signed up a similar deal with Opel in Germany, which awaits regulatory approval.

The company's automotive businesses produced a 16% increase in operating profits to £162m in the first half of the year. Overall group interim profits were up only 3% to £259m, due to currency exchange difficulties and a slowdown in aerospace orders. The figures came in at the tail end of City expectations even after an earlier profit warning.

Sir CK Chow shrugged off the setbacks saying the company overall was showing continued growth with strong performances from industrial services. Commenting on the record automotive profits, he said: "Looking forward, the automotive businesses continue to trade more strongly than the market as a whole and we expect market share gains to more than offset any weakening in North America in the second half."

In the last six months GKN has bought Sinter Metals Oberhausen in South Carolina, and increased its stake from 16% to 65% in ATH Albarus, and from 30% to 60% in Unidrive. GKN shares have outperformed most its sector peers but have still trailed the average FTSE 100 company. Last night they ended the day up 6.5p at 855p.

fields.headline: Insurer suffers £90m French storm damage
fields.trailText: The eve of millennium storms that lashed France blew a £90m hole in CGNU's results, which yesterday reported first-half profits down 7% to £800m from £853m.
fields.body:
The eve of millennium storms that lashed France blew a £90m hole in CGNU's results, which yesterday reported first-half profits down 7% to £800m from £853m.

The storms, which killed 30 people, now rank as the worst insurance disaster to hit Europe since the British hurricane of 1987, with total losses put at £5bn. The losses masked a 24% increase in operating profits at CGNU's life division, which rose to £754m from £621m. Worldwide general insurance profits, which include motor, home and property cover, fell to £327m from £370m.

The results are the first since the merger of CGU and Norwich Union, completed in May this year, which made CGNU the largest insurer in Britain. Yesterday it raised its estimates for annualised savings from the merger to £275m from the £250m predicted at the time of the deal. But the cost of achieving the savings, which include 4,000 job losses, has also increased from £350m to £425m.

During the first half CGNU pushed through car insurance premium increases averaging 20%, but at the cost of losing around 100,000 motorists to other insurers. The number of vehicles it insures fell from 2.7m to 2.6m and it says it expects the figure to decline further as it maintains a hard line on premium increases.

CGNU is part of a consortium that insures Concorde, but says its share of the losses from the recent crash will not exceed £5m.

Apart from the French storms, first-half profits were knocked by £41m in costs for developing Asserta, its property website and £15m spent on the rebranding of its high street estate agency chain as Your Move.

Chief executive Bob Scott also announced a £250m project to launch an wealth management website in October, branded Norwich Union, offering traditional life insurance products plus a funds supermarket and share dealing.

Later next year it will add banking products including deposit accounts, credit cards and mortgages in the style of Egg.com, but says it will do so with banking partners rather than originating products itself. It disclosed it has axed its in-house mortgage lending operation, set up only months ago in a bid to match Standard Life Bank's success in the homeloan market.

Mr Scott declared CGNU's future strategy to be in the top five of all markets in which it operates, which in the short term will result in its exit some areas, including the US and Canada. Negotiations are under way to sell its US property and casualty business, which has $4bn (£2.7bn) in annual premiums but is only the 13th largest insurer in the country.

fields.headline: US go-ahead for Alzheimer's drug
fields.trailText: American drugs regulators have given a thumbs-up to Shire Pharmaceuticals' new treatment for Alzheimer's Disease, which can slow down the onset of memory loss and confusion.
fields.body:
American drugs regulators have given a thumbs-up to Shire Pharmaceuticals' new treatment for Alzheimer's Disease, which can slow down the onset of memory loss and confusion.

The company said it had received an "approvable letter" from the Food and Drugs Administration yesterday - which means the treatment, Reminyl, can be launched subject to final negotiations about labelling.

Shire announced the news alongside a 45% rise in second-quarter profits to $26.8m (£18m), which sent its shares up 43p to £12.48. The group has been among the drugs industry's best stockmarket performers of the year - its shares have more than doubled since January.

Chief executive Rolf Stahel said: "We're very happy with our progress - we continue to grow at two to three times the average industry rate."

Reminyl, which was originally developed from a substance found in snowdrops, has already been approved by European regulators. Shire expects to begin selling it on the Continent by the end of the year, with an American launch in early 2001.

The drug works by stimulating production of acetylcholine - tiny chemical messengers which help brain cells communicate with each other. Analysts believe annual sales of the drug could top £250m - Shire wants to target the 85% of Alzheimer's sufferers who take no medicine for the condition at present.

Shire's growth has been driven by two drugs for attention deficit disorder - Adderall and DextroStat. Sales of these jumped 46% to $46.2m, as the number of children diagnosed as hyperactive has grown rapidly in America.

Mr Stahel believes opportunities are opening up in selling the drug to adults, as many hyperactive children still have a short attention span as they grow up.

Shire has suffered a setback, however, on Lambda - a product for kidney failure. The American authorities have asked for more safety tests, delaying approval until late 2001.

webTitle: Jonathan Jones on the Elgin marbles.

fields.headline: Tainted love
fields.standfirst: What happens to great art when it is taken from its original setting? Do the Elgin marbles belong in a dreary room in London - or in the magnificent Parthenon? Jonathan Jones concludes his search for beauty
fields.trailText: What happens to great art when it is taken from its original setting? Do the Elgin marbles belong in a dreary room in London - or in the magnificent Parthenon? Jonathan Jones concludes his search for beauty.
fields.body:
An American visitor to the Duveen gallery at the British Museum is telling a companion about the Greek campaign for the return of the Elgin marbles. They can only have them back when they've proved themselves worthy, he says.

At the other end of the melancholy grey hall, a guard is telling two children that Lord Elgin took the sculptures when there was a war in Greece and saved them from being lost for ever. You start to suspect everyone here is talking or thinking about the one thing everyone knows about the Elgin marbles - that there is an international row about them. We have all come here to see the "controversial Elgin marbles".

Something has disappeared from the experience of looking at these pieces of carved stone. In all the arguments and scandals, we have lost track of why they were ever considered important. Was it to do with Greek nationalism or British imperialism? Was it because of the way Lord Elgin obtained them?

It was none of these things. The Elgin marbles matter because they are uniquely beautiful.

When the marbles were put on display in the British Museum in 1817, John Keats kept coming back to sit before them. The fourth verse of his Ode on a Grecian Urn describes images from the Parthenon frieze. "Who are these coming to the sacrifice?" What all those hours of solitary looking told Keats was: "Beauty is truth, truth beauty - that is all ye know on earth, and all ye need to know."

It is hard to recall those words looking at the Parthenon frieze today, or the metopes - the sculptures of centaurs fighting humans from the outer frieze - because the weight of modern history has crushed the lightness of this ancient art. Even the architecture of the Duveen gallery - a 1930s mausoleum of a place - speaks of authority and the museum. Where is the dance of beauty that Keats saw? It's there, but you have to think past the disputes and the words.

More of these words were published recently in a report by the parliamentary select committee on culture, media and sport. In June the committee, chaired by Gerald Kaufman, was addressed by Greek foreign minister George Papandreou, who presented a radically revised proposal for the return of the Parthenon sculptures to Athens.

Papandreou said Greece does not want to force the issue of ownership. Instead it simply wants to see the sculptures in Athens, displayed in a specially built museum as close as possible to the Parthenon, in time for the Olympics in 2004. "This masterpiece must be reunified," he argued, "its integrity restored - within its original historical and cultural environment in Athens." But Papandreou was wasting his breath: Tory committee members boycotted the hearing and Alastair Campbell briefed journalists that the government has no intention of returning the sculptures.

Arts minister Alan Howarth, who addressed the select committee on behalf of the British government, agreed to speak to me about the beauty of the marbles. A great aesthetic experience, he says, is one that "rises above the banal: a heightened experience in which the whole personality is committed". Is beauty important in his job? It is, apparently. Howarth values "that heightened experience of acuteness, that sense that you're dealing with things that are transcendentally important" and says his job as arts minister is to diffuse such experiences more widely. He cites a government scheme to encourage experiment in architecture. "Why should we tolerate mediocrity and ugliness in our buildings? It's quite unnecessary."

That's great, but it is also the reason why we should cooperate with the Greeks to reunite the most beautiful conjunction of architecture and art the world has known. Isn't the reason the marbles should go back to Athens that their beauty will be appreciated there at its most powerful? Isn't this a unique chance for a Labour government to increase the beauty in the world? "I think that's an enormously seductive case; it isn't the case the Greeks are putting to us."

Yet in effect it is. "The visitor or the researcher will be able to juxtapose the marbles in the museum with the Parthenon, as they will be situated there," Papandreou told the select committee. "There will be a true sense of the aesthetics and the historical and cultural context which they were in."

The beauty of the Elgin marbles is one thing; the beauty of the Parthenon is another. The sculptures that Elgin brought to London are part of the works commissioned by the Athenian statesman Pericles to celebrate the city-state's repulsion of a Persian invasion. The Parthenon housed a statue of the goddess Athena by the sculptor Phidias, credited as architect of the Parthenon. Under his supervision carvers created the exterior decorations, including the frieze, which depicts in low relief representatives of the entire Athenian people processing to the Acropolis in the festival of the Panatheneia.

In history it was the building as a whole that impressed. "It is extraordinary and it was extraordinary in its day," says Ian Jenkins, assistant keeper in the department of Greek and Roman antiquities at the British Museum. "It has many additions and embellishments that represented in its day a great aesthetic challenge. Its beauty has persisted because of the sheer quality of its workmanship and the intelligence of its design."

Despite having been blown up by the Venetians in 1682 when it was used by a Turkish garrison as a gunpowder store, the Parthenon is still standing. When you see its honey-coloured pillars against the blue sky, you don't feel you're looking at a ruin. The pillars have a delicate rhythm, echoed in the horses cantering on the frieze. It may be a ceremonial building, but it is also a human one. It seems to soar, and makes you feel more alive to look at it. It is incomparably beautiful.

"The Parthenon sculptures participated in that beauty," says Jenkins, "but they participated as architectural ornament. It wasn't until the 18th century that people began to look really closely at them as art."

Jenkins makes what appears to be a nimble case for the marbles to stay at the British Museum - although he will not make his position explicit. When they were in their original place at the top of the temple 40ft above the ground, he says, visitors could not see the details. They can only be studied up close because Elgin removed them. "They have become this great icon of western art because they were removed. They're physically transformed, but also conceptually transformed: they became what they are through their repositioning. That transformation is an irreversible one: once you have made a museum object by displaying them at eye level, you cannot then see them other than as a result of that process."

Or as the British Museum's case is summarised in the select committee report: "The marbles are now irrevocably established as museum pieces."

When I speak to Alan Howarth about the marbles, he says: "What we're really talking about is the principle of what is in a museum." The government currently takes its line from the British Museum; it is a sophisticated line that sees museums as timeless public spaces, beyond national boundaries, implicitly portraying the Greek claim as narrowly nationalist.

Beauty is not timeless, though, and it is not indestructible. Even if some of us can get closer to the marbles, they are reduced as museum pieces. They have become icons rather than a beautiful element in a larger architectural whole. Brought up on a neo-classical ideal of beauty, 19th-century spectators like Keats were stunned by the delicacy of the Parthenon sculptures: the naturalistic depiction of anatomy, the social detail of the crowd, the fact that these were real people in a real time and place. We can't recapture that in the Duveen gallery partly because of the row: by being controversial, the marbles have become invisible. Yet most visitors to Athens are overwhelmed by the Acropolis. To put the marbles back in this context would shock us into seeing them again. This would not be a simple restoration but something more interesting. It would make a new beauty available, bringing the modern cult of the Elgin marbles together with the ancient authority of the Parthenon. The beauty of the Parthenon and its sculptures leaves all other arguments out in the cold, including the issue of creating a precedent.

It's no insult to ancient Egypt or Benin art or even the rest of ancient Greek art to call the Parthenon uniquely beautiful. The beauty of the Parthenon makes it a special case. It's our loss if we find reasons not to worship beauty and condemn ourselves to a life of aesthetic squalor.

The marbles, says Alan Howarth, are "a monument not just to Greece but, by their very presence in this country, to the cultural influence of ancient Greece". But that influence has long since been absorbed. In the end it is sophistry to say that the marbles have become beautiful by being removed from the Parthenon. It suppresses the possibility of seeing things whole. We are bombarded with micro-aesthetic experiences every day: we eat beautiful meals, buy beautiful clothes. But is there a place for a great beauty that changes the world?

The return of the Elgin marbles has been a rallying call for the British left from Lord Byron to Christopher Hitchens. This is not just sympathy with Greek nationalists; it comes from a recognition of beauty as a political good. The Parthenon frieze is a monument not to a monarch but to a democratic city-state. It is a beautiful vision of a radically democratic society. Of course Byron and Keats went woozy over it, and so should we.

I ask Alan Howarth again why the government doesn't take this chance to do something beautiful. "I think I have to rest on the position I've already stated.'"

webTitle: George W Bush accepts republican nomination

fields.headline: 'If all goes well, you're looking at the next president of the US'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush arrived in Philadelphia to claim his prize yesterday. He spoke Spanish. He spoke English. And in the most exclusive and expensive reception of a week that has bulged with more than 470 Republican fundraising shindigs, he spoke the language of money.
fields.body:
George W Bush arrived in Philadelphia to claim his prize yesterday. He spoke Spanish. He spoke English. And in the most exclusive and expensive reception of a week that has bulged with more than 470 Republican fundraising shindigs, he spoke the language of money.

Tonight Mr Bush will give his acceptance speech to the Republican convention delegates who have now officially nominated him as their party's presidential candidate. Yesterday his priority was to thank the donors and backers who have raised more than $93m for the Republican party during this campaign - and who were expected to cough up another $7m for the privilege at a Bush lunch.

"If all goes well, you're looking at the next president of the United States," Mr Bush told them. It was a fair bet that most of the donors had made that same calculation too. The contrast between the Republican party as it has packaged itself in the televised convention hall and the party as it conducts its business behind the scenes in Philadelphia's hotels, luxury yachts and suburban country clubs could hardly have been greater yesterday.

In the hall, a succession of speakers officially described as "average people" were scheduled to address the convention, the latest carefully scripted episode in the Republicans' relentless drive to redefine themselves for the voters as an inclusive "big tent" party. Delegates were due to hear from a California Latino small business owner, a fifth generation Oklahoma farmer, two single mothers from Wisconsin and Arkansas, and to be entertained by a band called Regular Joe.

Hungry

Meanwhile a few miles away, the Republican national committee was hosting a gala for Bush and his vice-presidential running mate Dick Cheney. There Mr Bush addressed the corporate bosses and the millionaires who have underwritten this most expensive election campaign in American history. "I'm feeling America's ready for change," Mr Bush told them. "They don't want four more years of Clinton-Gore. America's hungry for new leadership and that's exactly what Dick Cheney and I are going to give them."

Even Senator John McCain, who campaigned strongly in the Republican primaries for campaign finance reform, has bowed the knee to his former rival. In his Tuesday night address to the convention, Mr McCain fully endorsed Mr Bush but did not mention campaign finance once. Yesterday Mr McCain was by Mr Bush's side at a rally for Latino voters in which the Republican leader aped Che Guevara by announcing "Venceremos" - we shall win - in the course of several remarks in Spanish.

Access to the gala reflected the hierarchy and corporate agenda which the convention television viewers are not being allowed to see. At the top of the ladder are the Republican "Regents" who have given $250,000 a head or more to Mr Bush, in return for unfettered access to the most exclusive events in Philadelphia this week and, if Mr Bush becomes president, perhaps an ambassadorship or a White House state dinner invitation. Beneath them come Team 100, the $100,000 donors, followed by the Presidential Trust at $20,000, and the Eagles, at $15,000.

But the gala was only the tip of the iceberg of what one critic described as "an orgy of money" in Philadelphia this week, in which lavishly funded networking and access trading have replaced policy making or debate as the principal activities of the modern convention. For a high price, donors and lobbyists have been getting VIP access to the cream of Republican legislators. They could go fly fishing with House Speaker Dennis Hastert, courtesy of Morgan Stanley, or dance to the Temptations with congressman JC Watts, paid for by DaimlerChrysler. Access to the most sought after group of all, the Republican majority on the house commerce committee, was made possible by the American Chemistry Council.

But the man at the heart of the commercial-political interface is Tom DeLay, the Texas congressman and Republican whip in the House of Representatives. "The Hammer", as he is known, led the drive to impeach President Clinton, and has spent almost every minute of his time in Philadelphia fund raising and schmoozing the party's richest donors.

The list of companies which have put up the money for Bush reads like a roll call of the corporate special interests which were the principal target of Mr McCain's primary campaign. On Monday, sponsored by three of America's biggest medical in surance giants, Mr DeLay teed off at a private round of golf for 50 lobbyists and Republican congressmen in which each hole was sponsored by a different donor. On Tuesday, he hosted a fundraiser for his own private charity, which helps neglected children, and spoke at a private concert, paid for by Coca Cola and Continental Airlines. "We'll leave this convention with a significant amount of resources," Mr DeLay admitted this week.

"It's an orgy of money," said Fred Wertheimer of Democracy 21, a campaign funding watchdog organisation. "We have never seen anything like this convention in terms of the free flow of money, and we will see it again in Los Angeles", where the Democrats hold their convention in two weeks time.

 Former US president Gerald Ford suffered a stroke just hours after being honoured at the Republican convention yesterday. Mr Ford, 87, who was president from 1974-77, was said to be comfortable but would remain in hospital under observation. It was Mr Ford's second small stroke in the past week.

The contrast between the Republican party as it has packaged itself in the televised convention hall and the party as it conducts its business behind the scenes in Philadelphia's hotels, luxury yachts and suburban country clubs could hardly have been greater yesterday. In the hall, a succession of speakers officially described as "average people" were scheduled to address the convention, the latest carefully scripted episode in the Republicans' relentless drive to redefine themselves for the voters as an inclusive "big tent" party. Delegates were due to hear from a California Latino small business owner, a fifth generation Oklahoma farmer, two single mothers from Wisconsin and Arkansas, and to be entertained by a band called Regular Joe. Hungry Meanwhile a few miles away, the Republican national committee was hosting a gala for Bush and his vice-presidential running mate Dick Cheney. There Mr Bush addressed the corporate bosses and the millionaires who have underwritten this most expensive election campaign in American history. "I'm feeling America's ready for change," Mr Bush told them. "They don't want four more years of Clinton-Gore. America's hungry for new leadership and that's exactly what Dick Cheney and I are going to give them." Even Senator John McCain, who campaigned strongly in the Republican primaries for campaign finance reform, has bowed the knee to his former rival. In his Tuesday night address to the convention, Mr McCain fully endorsed Mr Bush but did not mention campaign finance once. Yesterday Mr McCain was by Mr Bush's side at a rally for Latino voters in which the Republican leader aped Che Guevara by announcing "Venceremos" - we shall win - in the course of several remarks in Spanish. Access to the gala reflected the hierarchy and corporate agenda which the convention television viewers are not being allowed to see. At the top of the ladder are the Republican "Regents" who have given $250,000 a head or more to Mr Bush, in return for unfettered access to the most exclusive events in Philadelphia this week and, if Mr Bush becomes president, perhaps an ambassadorship or a White House state dinner invitation. Beneath them come Team 100, the $100,000 donors, followed by the Presidential Trust at $20,000, and the Eagles, at $15,000. But the gala was only the tip of the iceberg of what one critic described as "an orgy of money" in Philadelphia this week, in which lavishly funded networking and access trading have replaced policy making or debate as the principal activities of the modern convention. For a high price, donors and lobbyists have been getting VIP access to the cream of Republican legislators. They could go fly fishing with House Speaker Dennis Hastert, courtesy of Morgan Stanley, or dance to the Temptations with congressman JC Watts, paid for by DaimlerChrysler. Access to the most sought after group of all, the Republican majority on the house commerce committee, was made possible by the American Chemistry Council. But the man at the heart of the commercial-political interface is Tom DeLay, the Texas congressman and Republican whip in the House of Representatives. "The Hammer", as he is known, led the drive to impeach President Clinton, and has spent almost every minute of his time in Philadelphia fund raising and schmoozing the party's richest donors. The list of companies which have put up the money for Bush reads like a roll call of the corporate special interests which were the principal target of Mr McCain's primary campaign. On Monday, sponsored by three of America's biggest medical in surance giants, Mr DeLay teed off at a private round of golf for 50 lobbyists and Republican congressmen in which each hole was sponsored by a different donor. On Tuesday, he hosted a fundraiser for his own private charity, which helps neglected children, and spoke at a private concert, paid for by Coca Cola and Continental Airlines. "We'll leave this convention with a significant amount of resources," Mr DeLay admitted this week. "It's an orgy of money," said Fred Wertheimer of Democracy 21, a campaign funding watchdog organisation. "We have never seen anything like this convention in terms of the free flow of money, and we will see it again in Los Angeles", where the Democrats hold their convention in two weeks time.  Former US president Gerald Ford suffered a stroke just hours after being honoured at the Republican convention yesterday. Mr Ford, 87, who was president from 1974-77, was said to be comfortable but would remain in hospital under observation. It was Mr Ford's second small stroke in the past week.

fields.headline: Further 25 sites for GM trials
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: A total of 25 new sites for GM trials of oil seed rape will be announced today, the first time the government-backed programme has hit the target set by its scientific advisers.
fields.body:
A total of 25 new sites for GM trials of oil seed rape will be announced today, the first time the government-backed programme has hit the target set by its scientific advisers.

Nearly half the autumn plantings will be made on the same farms or in the same villages used for this summer's troubled trials of spring rape, maize and sugar beet.

But advisers are still concerned that a recent spate of crop trashings that have damaged seven sites in recent weeks will mean that it will be difficult to find volunteer farmers in sufficient numbers to protect the scientific validity of the rest of the three year programme run by the industry. Several of 66 sites named earlier this year for the summer trials pulled out after local pressure.

Ministers, who have warned they might have to keep locations secret if attacks by anti-GM activists continued, said the trials were vital to establish what effects, if any, the new crops had on wildlife.

The list of sites, leaked to Friends of the Earth yesterday, contains four in Scotland, two more in Daviot, Aberdeenshire, site of the present trial north of the border, another at Rothienorman in the same county, and the fourth at Munlochy in Highland county.

There are no new sites in Wales. The announcement of the present one at Sealand in Flintshire caused fury in the Welsh assembly this summer.

Ministers will be encouraged they at least have enough sites to start with this autumn.

Today the Commons agriculture select committee is expected to criticise strongly ministers' handling of the accidental contamination of imported conventional rape seed by GM material. Hundreds of farmers had to destroy their crops after unwittingly planting the seeds.

An announcement as to whether ministers regard present buffer zones between GM and conventional crops to be adequate is also expected. The Department of the Environment last night refused to comment "on what we have not announced yet".

For the moment, the government will continue to publish map references but it has warned that illegal activity might forced it to reconsider.

webTitle: UK firms donate funds to US elections

fields.headline: UK firms in party funding dispute
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: British companies have become mired in the controversy over political donations after handing out millions of dollars to Democrats and Republicans in the run-up to the most expensive US presidential elections ever.
fields.body:
British companies have become mired in the controversy over political donations after handing out millions of dollars to Democrats and Republicans in the run-up to the most expensive US presidential elections ever.

BP Amoco, the oil giant, tops the list of British-based sponsors after spending some $2.4m since the beginning of 1999 on corporate and employee donations to the two main US political parties.

The most controversial part of this total - some $877,000 - was handed out as "soft money", corporate gifts to party machines which escape the strict limits on political contributions to individual candidates.

BP Amoco ranks in the top 20 of all soft money donors this year, according to the Centre for Responsive Politics, a US research group. Sources close to BP in London said last night that these levels of political funding were likely to be cut in the future.

Foreign companies are barred from directly financing US elections. However, the increase in cross-border mergers has seen a corresponding rise in contributions from the companies' US subsidiaries.

Meredith McGehee, a senior vice-president at the campaign group Common Cause, said: "These companies are using the soft money loophole to avoid the law meant to stop foreign money influencing elections in the US. The system is corrupt and anyone who participates, on whatever side, is tainted by it."

Other UK-owned companies to have made soft money donations include Glaxo Wellcome, the drugs group, which has donated about $307,600 mainly to Republicans, and Brown & Williamson, the tobacco company owned by BAT, which gave all but $10,000 of its $451,380 in soft money donations to the Republicans.

Many corporate sponsors have faced significant legal or political challenges. BP Amoco suffered a long and painful regulatory review of last year's acquisition of Arco, a US company.

Microsoft, the world's largest software company, has become a leading political donor during legal battles with the US government, while drugs companies need federal approval for their products.

These companies deny any direct link between their lobbying efforts and political donations.

BP, which does not contribute to Britain's political parties, stresses that its recently acquired US subsidiaries have long made political contributions. The company's biggest single contribution was an in-kind payment worth $1.2m to the Democratic convention to be held in Los Angeles this month.

Tom Fuldner, a spokesman for Glaxo Wellcome, said: "An informed citizen and informed voter is the cornerstone of our democracy, so that's why we are involved in this area."

Common Cause has estimated that some $256m has already been raised to fund political campaigns in the US over the last 18 months, 82% more than the $141m raised in the run-up to the 1996 election.

fields.headline: Chancellor's wedding surprise
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last night finally threw prudence aside by announcing that he is to marry his long standing partner Sarah Macaulay today in his local parish church in Dunfermline.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last night finally threw prudence aside by announcing that he is to marry his long standing partner Sarah Macaulay today in his local parish church in Dunfermline.

The marriage, trailed inaccurately for years by Mr Brown's former spin doctor Charlie Whelan, caught Westminster by surprise, and will delight his colleagues. The end to what seemed years of hesitation was announced in a one line statement from his special adviser at the Treasury.

Mr Brown told Tony and Cherie Blair of his intentions yesterday and they were said to be delighted. They will not be attending the ceremony which will be a private affair for the couple's close friends and family only.

It emerged that Mr Brown proposed to Miss Macaulay in January and the couple fixed a date for the wedding shortly afterwards. The announcement had been displayed in the normal way in the parish where the ceremony will take place.

After the wedding, there will be a small reception for close family. The pair will then leave for a secret honeymoon. Mr Brown was due to fly to the couple's holiday retreat at Cape Cod in the US on Saturday. Many believed that Mr Brown had cooled on the idea of marriage to the publicist Ms Macaulay, expecting instead to see the chancellor devote his life to budget surpluses and convergence criteria. It was said he spent many of his holidays in the US with his head buried in economics text books, leaving Ms Macaulay exasperated.

Mr Brown has always eschewed questions about his relationship, allowing himself to be depicted as a bachelor devoid of romance and wedded to ambition. Those who know the couple well say the picture is false, and he relies on Ms Macaulay greatly for political and personal advice. She regularly attends his frequent parties at 11 Downing Street.

Ms Macaulay has worked in a public affairs consultancy with Julia Hobsbawm, the daughter of the Marxist historian, Eric Hobsbawm. Like Mr Brown she is a Scot, and lived in Falkirk. She is the eldest of three children and the daughter of an educational publisher. They have been dating each other since 1994, but news of their relationship did not surface until April 1995.

As long ago as 1997, it was claimed that the couple were secretly engaged and it was their intention to marry after the 1997 general election.

Mr Brown apparently delayed the announcement of the marriage until the summer recess to minimise publicity. He managed to keep it secret from the entire cabinet, just as he has managed to keep many of his colleagues in the dark about his plans for the budget.

According to Mr Whelan, "Gordon wanted to get married privately and he's going to do just that. He and Sarah are very much in love and very excited about tying the knot".

fields.headline: Dome snubbed in awards shortlist
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: There was a dome shaped hole in the shortlist announced yesterday for the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors' millennium awards.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
There was a dome shaped hole in the shortlist announced yesterday for the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors' millennium awards.

The capital's other landmark openings in the last year - the London Eye, Covent Garden opera house, and Tate Modern - were there, but the Millennium Dome was missing.

It had been nominated but, following a judges' inspection, it failed to make the short list. The snub is the more pointed because a Sainsbury's super store within sight of the dome on the Greenwich peninsula, has been shortlisted.

The awards are for urban regeneration and reclamation projects - the much vaunted end use for the peninsula's former blighted gasworks, which was the government's justification for locating the ill fated dome there - as well as for architecture. The shortlist includes the reconstruction of Manchester city centre after the IRA bomb, and a renovated crofter's cottage on Skye.

This year the awards have been expanded to cover international projects: on the list are the Sydney Olympic games site, the restoration of the colonial Commissioner's House in Bermuda, and the conversion of an old tea factory into a hotel in Sri Lanka.

A modest nursery school, in one of the most deprived parts of east London, was a surprise inclusion: the judges passed it by chance and stopped to investigate. The unit cost a mere £180,000 and was added to Downs Side primary school, in 1988 labelled the lowest achieving primary school in Hackney.

Simon Pott, chairman of the judges, praised the nursery, but was saddened to find it behind a high security fence in a sea of litter, burned out cars, boarded up shops, vandalism and graffiti. In his judge's note he challenged the council to tackle the palpable "air of menace" around the school.

The other surprise nomination is in startling contrast: Beaton's Cottage is a traditional thatched crofter's house and byre in Borneskitaig restored by the National Trust for Scotland using traditional techniques.

The awards will be presented in November by the Prince of Wales.

fields.headline: René Favaloro
fields.standfirst: Argentinian pioneer of the coronary bypass, he was frustrated by lack of support for his heart clinic
fields.trailText: The heart surgeon René Favaloro, who has committed suicide at the age of 77, changed the course of heart surgery by performing the first documented coronary bypass operation.
fields.body:
The heart surgeon René Favaloro, who has committed suicide at the age of 77, changed the course of heart surgery by performing the first documented coronary bypass operation.

He also performed the first successful heart transplant operations in his native Argentina, but his profound commitment to the provision of free but good health services there led to increasing frustration and financial desperation.

On November 30 1967, Favaloro operated at the Cleveland Clinic, Ohio, on a patient with a potentially deadly coronary artery blockage. Favaloro used a saphenous [superficial leg] vein taken from the patient's own leg to form a bypass for blood around blockages in the heart, a technique that now saves hundreds of thousands of lives a year.

The report of Favaloro's success brought him fame, but also prompted some thing of a professional spat. It seemed it was not the first time the procedure had been used. After his results were announced, two prominent surgeons said they had already followed the procedure: David Sabiston, of Duke University, claimed to have done so first, in 1962, and Edward Garrett to have done so again in 1965, at the DeBakey Medical Centre, Houston.

However, those were unplanned emergencies in deteriorating conditions on the operating table. Favaloro's surgery was planned. The procedure was also the first to be reported in a medical journal. Before the operation in 1967, doctors had few reliable tools to treat heart disease, and relied mainly on medication.

Although he could have had a brilliant medical career at one of the most prestigious and well-endowed medical centres in the United States - which would have made him very rich - Favaloro resigned. He preferred to return to Argentina to create a top-level teaching clinic.

Favaloro was born in La Plata, in the province of Buenos Aires, the son of a dressmaker and a carpenter. In 1948, he took a degree in medicine from La Plata University and became a doctor, following the example of an uncle who was the only other graduate in his family. He worked in La Plata for two years, and then agreed to fill in for several months for an ailing country surgeon in Jacinto Aráuz, an impoverished village 300 miles west of Buenos Aires; he stayed there for 12 years. The lessons of his rural practice were never lost on him, and he maintained that all doctors in Latin America should be required to work among the poor.

Gradually he was drawn to the idea of specialising in heart surgery. It was an enormous challenge. He was accepted for post-graduate training at the Cleveland Clinic in 1960, and became a staff member on completing it.

One of his mentors at Cleveland was Mason Sones, the cardiologist who in 1958 developed coronary angiography, which allowed doctors to view the moving heart and its vessels with x-rays: it was one of several key inventions that made bypass surgery possible.

After 10 years working in the US, Favaloro went back to Argentina in 1972 and set to work raising money for a $55m heart clinic. After it was completed in the early 1990s, he treated thousands of patients, often for no charge, and trained hundreds of surgeons.

A dedicated teacher, he received numerous honours; though in his view, his international reputation contrasted sadly with the lack of recognition - particularly in the form of practical support - he had at home. In addition to over 300 scientific papers, and articles of landmark importance, he wrote the study The Surgical Treatment of Arteriosclerosis (1970), and told his story in The Challenging Dream Of Heart Surgery: From The Pampas To Cleveland (1994). But he was at pains not to overstate his accomplishment and to recognise other people's work. In one interview he said, "Medical progress is a step-by-step process of evolution through innumerable contributions."

Favaloro had recently voiced worries that the cardiology surgical foundation that bears his name, the most important in Latin America, was facing serious financial problems. Argentina has been in an economic depression since 1998, and Favaloro disclosed in a letter to the editor of the newspaper La Nación that several hospitals and state-owned medical centres owed the foundation more than $18m: "I am going through the saddest period of my life," he wrote.

Favaloro's body was found by his secretary in the bathroom of his apartment. There was a wound to his chest, a gun was nearby, and the police attributed his death to suicide.

Favaloro's wife Maria died in 1998; they had no children, but brought up the four children of one of his brothers who had died young.

fields.headline: A word in edgeways
fields.standfirst:
Interviewers should expose, not harangue

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Interviewers as exposed as those on Radio 4's Today programme each morning tread a fine line. If they put on kid gloves, they are accused of favouritism and sell-out. Too tough and they sound like bullies, exploiting the privilege of their position and diminishing the BBC
fields.body:
Interviewers as exposed as those on Radio 4's Today programme each morning tread a fine line. If they put on kid gloves, they are accused of favouritism and sell-out. Too tough and they sound like bullies, exploiting the privilege of their position and diminishing the BBC, which is required by law to be even-handed. But they are well-paid for their pains. Celebrity comes with their pay and rations. They are invited to make after-dinner speeches (presumably only on those evenings when they do not have to get up at 4am the next morning). Some parlay their radio fame into newspapers and have their salaries bolstered by Rupert Murdoch.

It is inevitable that some of these quotidian inquisitors get swollen heads. Editing the Today programme when it was presented by, say, the former Guardian journalist Brian Redhead was, by all accounts, a protracted effort in ego control. Now, unusually, the BBC's governors are having a go at tying down the journalistic dirigible known as John Humphrys. Mr Humphrys, they said in adjudicating a complaint, went over the top in an interview with Lord Robertson. The secretary general of Nato is no shrinking violet, and as a general rule a politician incapable of giving John Humphrys as good as he or she gets is in the wrong job. fields.headline: Majrooh Sultanpuri
fields.trailText: The Hindi poet and film lyricist Majrooh Sultanpuri, who has died aged 80, was part of the 1950s golden era that established song as a significant idiom of Indian cinema.
fields.body:
The Hindi poet and film lyricist Majrooh Sultanpuri, who has died aged 80, was part of the 1950s golden era that established song as a significant idiom of Indian cinema.

He wrote more than 2,000 songs for more than 300 features, and his simple evocations of love, suffering and sacrifice transcended class and the era.

He was born Asrar Hasan Khan in Sultanpur, in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. He dabbled with becoming a hafiz (teacher) of the Koran, or a physician. But poetry was his key interest. He adopted his pen name, which meant "wounded soul of Sultanpur". He also joined the Communist party of India.

It was a chance meeting with film-maker AR Kardar at an assembly of Urdu poets which began his movie career. His first lyrics were for Kardar's Shahjahan (1946). By the 1950s he was working with film-makers like Zia Sarhadi, Bimal Roy and Vijay Anand. His work ranged from the romantic to the funny - and weird.

Sultanpuri was the only lyricist of his generation who remained in demand, and kept writing. Some critics charged that he composed songs which were below his best during the last decade, but his rejoinder was that a lyricist had to change with the times.

He wrote two major collections of Urdu poetry, and was the first film lyricist to be honoured, in 1993, with the Dada Saheb Phalke Award by the president of India.

He is survived by his wife, Firdaus Jahan Sultanpuri, three daughters and a son.

 Majrooh Sultanpuri (Asrar Hasan Khan), lyricist and poet, born October 1 1919; died May 24 2000

webTitle: Letters: MPs fall out over section 28 vote

fields.headline: Comrades fall out over section 28
fields.trailText: I am sure I am not the only Labour MP who is getting sick of being lectured at and insulted by Diane Abbott.
fields.body:
I am sure I am not the only Labour MP who is getting sick of being lectured at and insulted by Diane Abbott. Her latest outburst (Letters, July 28) even manages to smear the most prominent MP campaigners for gay rights, pointing out (modestly) that "only a handful of us held out".

What she might consider is the commitment of those MPs who are most fervent for gay rights and yet can see the overriding need to rescue a vast local government bill that otherwise would have gone down. Of course, Diane would not care one jot about that. She might also consider the reiterated promise, made by the prime minister, that the government will continue to pursue the repeal of section 28.

In parliament we only hear from Diane when she is insulting the government and her comrades. It would be salutary for her to stand as the Diane Abbott candidate at the next general election. Clearly she owes no loyalty to or liking for the Labour party or the PLP, so perhaps she ought to stand against it as we are monstrous in her eyes. But of course, the party is too useful a vehicle to be abandoned.

I will naturally be described as racist, sexist, rightwing and Blairist. I contend that I am none of these, but I can bear the accusations at the price of expressing my boiling resentment at the activities of a "comrade" with a large majority who does not care about her comrades nor about the result of the next general election.
Colin Pickthall MP

Ivan Massow seems to be completely out of sync with the rest of the gay community. He's only just realised that the Tories are irredeemably homophobic (Defector quits 'intolerant' Tories, August 2) and now he's joining Labour at a time when the rest of us are looking to the Liberal Democrats. Stick to selling insurance, Ivan.
Terry Sanderson
London
otherway@dircon.co.uk

"There are times when you just have to admit you got it wrong," says Ivan Massow as he defects over section 28. And this seven months after laying into Shaun Woodward in your pages for defecting over the issue.
Ben Coleman
London
bcoleman@apcouk.com

webTitle: Letters: News of the World's anti-child abuse campaign is right

fields.headline: NoW is right
fields.trailText: We agree with Roy Greenslade (Vigilance and vigilantes, Media, July 31) - it is very easy to be cynical about the motives behind the News of the World's anti-child abuse campaign.
fields.body:
We agree with Roy Greenslade (Vigilance and vigilantes, Media, July 31) - it is very easy to be cynical about the motives behind the News of the World's anti-child abuse campaign. Like it or not, the NoW has responded to public concern and forced child protection up the public and political agenda.

The important thing is for it to stay there and for the public to get quality information about how to protect children. Although the NoW's "naming and shaming" is not the way forward, we must take the issue of community notification seriously and should not rule out law reform. When an abuser poses a serious risk, it is in the interests of child protection to tell communities.
Phillip Noyes
Public policy director, NSPCC
Tsamphier@NSPCC.org.uk

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In our leading article, Dump the hype, about the campaign against high petrol prices, page 17, yesterday, we said that the motorist paid £37 of every £50 spent by the government. That should have said that the motorist paid £37 of every £50 spent on petrol to the government.

In an article headed Brake hard on motor costs, pages 20 and 21, Jobs & Money, July 22, we misquoted the AA as saying that the average household spends £70 a week on petrol. The £70 includes all costs of running a car - insurance, car tax, repairs and servicing, as well as petrol.

In a report headed GMC cleared of race bias charge, page 5, yesterday, we said that last year, 50% of overseas-qualified doctors were struck off the medical register. We should make it clear that that was 50% of overseas-qualified doctors who appeared before the professional conduct committee.

Mick Jagger, mentioned in our review of The Graduate, page 2, August 1, is not a sexagenarian. He is a quinquagenarian. He was 57 on July 26.

John Lill played for the Queen Mother and Prince Charles at King's Lynn, Norfolk (not Suffolk), page 1, yesterday.

In All Abroad, an article about holiday destinations, G2, page 2, yesterday, we misidentified Laurence Durrell as author of My Family and Other Animals. It was, of course, written by his brother Gerald. In any case Lawrence Durrell spelt his name with a w.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Letters: Consultants should give 100% commitment to the NHS

fields.headline: Pilot scheme for the NHS
fields.trailText: Andrew Collier, president of the British Orthopaedic Trainees Association, (Letters, July 31), criticises the proposal that on first appointment, consultants should be required to make a 100% commitment to the NHS for about seven years.
fields.body:
Andrew Collier, president of the British Orthopaedic Trainees Association, (Letters, July 31), criticises the proposal that on first appointment, consultants should be required to make a 100% commitment to the NHS for about seven years.

The public-private partnership for NHS consultants simply hasn't worked. The fundamental flaw is that moonlighting consultants have a financial interest in the NHS having long queues, as these are the main selling point for Bupa and the other commercial insurers. It is high time this perverse financial incentive was scrapped.

Mr Collier is giving an ill-advised lead to his members. Working all the hours God sends is not a good model for young or old doctors - just ask patients, colleagues or families. The model should be based on senior airline pilots, who are required to take proper rest and recreation, except in an emergency. The idea of pilots coming off duty to moonlight for a rival airline would be regarded as ludicrous, as well as a sacking matter.
Dr Peter Draper
London

Andrew Collier is coy about quoting figures. Currently, a consultant's salary starts at £48,905 and rises over four years to £63,640. Discretionary points provide the opportunity for further increases. As an NHS consultant who didn't do private practice, I still found that I earned more than almost anyone I knew outside medicine. Do doctors have any notion of how this sort of complaint is perceived?
Christine Cockshott
Cumbria

fields.headline: Joanna Constantinidis
fields.standfirst: Radical potter who went back to the wheel - and helped to reinvent the 'thrown' vessel
fields.trailText: Through her radical methods of clay manipulation, the potter Joanna Constantinidis, who has died aged 72, helped to reinvent the "thrown" vessel - one formed on the potter's wheel, rather than hand-constructed.
fields.body:
Through her radical methods of clay manipulation, the potter Joanna Constantinidis, who has died aged 72, helped to reinvent the "thrown" vessel - one formed on the potter's wheel, rather than hand-constructed.

The result was a language grounded in a complex appreciation of ceramic history, and informed by the abstract purity of ancient Greek art, and much of the architecture, sculpture and painting produced by the modern movement. Constantinidis distilled and concentrated form. Looking beyond her craft, she produced ceramics that coalesced with the space and spare language of modernism.

Born Joanna Connell in York, into a family of Scottish Celtic ancestry, she grew up in Sheffield and was educated at the local grammar school. At home she began to paint and draw, and though art was not on the school curriculum, she recalled the indelible impression made by her headmaster, talking persuasively about Picasso's The Three Musicians. This inspired her, as did the knowledge that her history teacher, Dorothy Kemp, was also a potter, who worked at the Leach pottery at St Ives.

In 1946 Constantinidis went to Sheffield College of Art, to study fine art, but she chose pottery for her intermediate exams and became enthralled. She was taught by the fondly-recalled ceramic sculptor HR Stone who, like Dorothy Kemp, was an enthusiast for slipware pottery. Constantinidis began to absorb the few useful texts available at that time, such as Bernard Leach's A Potter's Book. It was, she remembered, a period of trial and error at a time when knowledge was scarce.

From 1951 until her retirement in 1989, Constantinidis was a teacher at Chelmsford's technical college. Patient and inspiring, she developed her throwing skills in the spare hours.

Her work underwent remarkable changes. Initially she looked at Staffordshire slipware, early saltglaze and industrial wares for ideas, as well as modern oriental potters such as Shoji Hamada. Although her 1950s pots, exhibited at the British Crafts Centre, the Red Rose Guild and the Whitechapel Art Gallery, were distinctly Leach-influenced, Constantinidis had never forgotten the words of Eric Jones, her Sheffield drawing teacher, who had said that "one can do so much in a single line". In search of such economy, she became dissatisfied with glazes and decoration and worked towards a language that emphasised form and the material of the clay.

Impressed by a series of exhibitions by leading potters Hans Coper and Lucie Rie, held at the Berkeley Galleries in the 1950s, she reformulated her approach, concentrating, as they had, on a few elemental shapes. She focused on tall vessels and bowls, using broad fluting or incised decoration and matt glazes that emphasised the clay's surface. Pots were more "urban" in character, and clearly connected with much of the new architecture and design then being produced, though their roots lay in her great admiration for early Mediterranean pots.

By the early 1970s, she was altering her shapes through post-wheel modifications - folding and cutting to create unexpected articulations. These objects still preserved the rhythms of throwing, emphasised by the quiet pulse of rings left by the turning wheel. These gently corrugated surfaces, and the asymmetry she could instil in a vessel's profile, contributed to what she called "latent energy", a sense of movement preserved in a pot's apparent stasis. By finally eliminating glazes and concentrating on lustres, she could define the "bone" of the pot more effectively.

Through the 1980s and 1990s, her forms became simpler. Large, open, leaning pots and tall, tapering vessels explored and defined space with a sweeping concision, reminiscent of Richard Serra's steel sculptures or much industrial architecture. Yet, despite her obvious debt to the 20th century landscape, her aesthetic was just as much rooted in the natural world, whether it was the Greece of her husband, writer and film-maker Photis Constantinidis, or the windswept marshes of her beloved Essex coast.

Increasingly alone in the last years, she concentrated on stoneware and porcelain in alternation, in the spare functionality of her home near Chelmsford. Though a regular exhibitor, her essential austerity had little interest in self-promotion. Although she made ceramics for use - her porcelain tableware was particularly well designed - she disliked the reductive connotations of "craft pottery". She believed strongly that ceramics had sensory values that made it an independent language, going beyond the confines of both art and craft.

Very private, Joanna was extremely loyal to her friends, who experienced her self-deprecating wit and sense of fun, and wide cultural knowledge. Though her work was acquired by many public collections, and her contribution was marked by a major touring retrospective in 1995, Joanna felt there was still much to be learned from her material.

She recovered sufficiently from a stroke to complete work for a final poignant show at the Crafts Council shop at the Victoria and Albert Museum last May. The pots exhibited were small and simple, but with their resonant lustres and incisive angular forms, were objects of remarkable life - a distillation of 50 years' potting. They were the hallmark of an artist who strove for a structural and material essence, and the result was a highly disciplined and intelligent language that contributed much to modern life.

She is survived by her husband.

 Joanna Constantinidis, potter, born December 12 1927; died August 1 2000

fields.headline: Figures of speech
fields.trailText: The government wants to recalculate the crime figures (Leader, August 1).
fields.body:
The government wants to recalculate the crime figures (Leader, August 1). It should go further and publish them with statistics on poverty, unemployment, public health, road accidents, iatrogenesis, accidents at work, school exclusions and "miss-selling" of pensions. Crime can then be viewed more objectively alongside all the other physical and financial harms we suffer from cradle to grave.
Prof Paddy Hillyard
University of Ulster

Joan Ruddock (Comment, August 1) believes parliament "must be one of the few institutions where people regularly go to work not knowing when they will return home". Is this the postmodern irony I've been reading about?
Pete James
Bristol Business School

It now costs a £500 fine and a year's driving ban for killing a cyclist in broad daylight while talking on a mobile phone (In brief, August 1). No doubt the motoring lobby will be embarking on a public campaign to reduce such onerous penalties.
Philip Ashbourn
Milton Keynes, Bucks

It now costs me £24 to fill up with beer; £17.50 of this is going to smug Mr Brown (Letters, August 2). I intend to refrain from drinking on alternate Wednesdays and urge readers to do likewise.
Rob O'Brien
Farnham, Surrey

Canada did go metric many years ago (Letters, July 31), yet when in British Columbia recently, I noticed shops still using pounds and ounces. One owner simply said it is what the customers prefer.
Jack Griffiths
Ferring, W.Sussex

Richard Jago says in his Toronto tennis report (Sport, August 1) one of the players has "impeccable sexual credentials". He might at least have told us what these were.
Roland White
Bognor Regis, W Sussex

webTitle: Letters: Support for Catherine Searle who lost her house fighting developers

fields.headline: Legal aid
fields.trailText: I read of the position that Catherine Searle finds herself in (Campaign to stop builders may cost woman her home, July 31) with a rising sense of injustice.
fields.body:
I read of the position that Catherine Searle finds herself in (Campaign to stop builders may cost woman her home, July 31) with a rising sense of injustice. To end up losing your house to pay the costs for fighting developers and the local authority in order to save a historic house and garden is not a just reward.

I would like to make a contribution towards her legal costs. Others who also care that historic buildings should survive, and that the right of protest should not be swamped in self-serving bureaucracy, might also like to contribute.

Her solicitor, Christopher White, of Milne and Lyall, Bridport, has agreed to set up a fund to receive contributions. Cheques should be made payable to Milne & Lyall.
Jill Robson
Sheffield

webTitle: Ed Vaizey: Ivan Massaw was wrong to defect

fields.headline: Ivan, you are wrong
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: So farewell then, Ivan Massow. Another Tory defection to Labour will supposedly damage William Hague's hopes of capturing the centre ground of British politics. Ivan Massow, you may remember, was for a time a Tory pin-up.
fields.body:
So farewell then, Ivan Massow. Another Tory defection to Labour will supposedly damage William Hague's hopes of capturing the centre ground of British politics. Ivan Massow, you may remember, was for a time a Tory pin-up. He was a prototype 21st-century Tory. Gay but Thatcherite. Model good looks but a supporter of Hague. Chairman of London's Institute of Contemporary Arts, but a fanatical huntsman.

Now Ivan has gone over to Labour, with the requisite photocall with Mo Mowlam, who has become the quintessential comfort woman for Tories supposedly coming in from the cold. Massow has stated his reasons as the Tories' support for section 28, their hardline on asylum seekers and their plan to cut public spending by £16bn. According to Massow, the Tories "are just plain nasty".

I sympathise with Massow, but I in no way support his defection. While Ivan was having secret talks with Hague about his chances of becoming London mayor, I supported his nomination in a newspaper article, arguing that someone of his experience and counter-intuitive outlook had to be a refreshing dose of salts for traditional Tory stuffiness. Like Ivan, I have always opposed section 28 for what it is - a nasty, bigoted clause designed to enshrine discrimination against homosexuals. In this newspaper, I have recorded my concern at some of the Tory language used about asylum seekers, while recognising that there is an issue to debate. I certainly would not regard myself as being as rightwing as Jack Straw.

But while Ivan defects, I will stay in the Tory party. Indeed, my support for Conservative values and principles has grown stronger as the government has grown more authoritarian and profligate. If I didn't know Ivan better, I'd have put it down to a fit of pique (and a further spell in the limelight).

First, section 28. There are both honourable and dishonourable reasons for living with the Tories' decision to support section 28. The dishonourable reason is that in any political party and in any political system we are dealing in the language of priorities. Amid growing public squalor, with the health service and schools being brought to their knees, section 28 is not a do or die issue. To a certain extent, one must understand the Tories and the voters. I cannot bear intolerance or discrimination. But at the same time, one cannot run away from the fact that voters in Scotland voted in favour of section 28, as would most of the country if given the chance. If the voters can be misguided, so can a political party. The answer is not to run away but, to paraphrase, to educate, educate, educate and to fight for the soul of the party that you love. Turning one's back at this stage is not a sign of principled strength, but weakness.

But, talking of expediency, Ivan has turned just at the point when the Labour party has given up the ghost. No one commented on the ironic sight last week of Shaun Woodward going through the lobbies on the Labour whip, alongside his former Tory colleagues, to vote for a Labour procedural motion that curtailed any further moves to remove section 28 from the statute book. With all principle gone from the Labour party on this issue, why go over to them now?

Another difficulty for Ivan is the principles he has abandoned in order to salve his conscience. Ivan is a keen fox-hunter. Labour is the party that will ban fox-hunting. The move to make this country pursuit illegal is at least as immoral as the decision to support section 28. It is a measure being pushed through by a government with an overwhelming majority against a minority that they neither seek nor are able to understand. Anyone who visited last week's Game Fair in Oxfordshire would have met the farriers and others whose livelihoods are to be destroyed and would have seen that hunting is part of the very fabric of the countryside, a pastime open to people from all walks of life. In choosing to run with the hare, Ivan is destined never to run with his beloved hounds.

It seems that he is also keen to forget his principled stance on the euro. I have always understood that he is opposed to the euro, both for political and economic reasons. Yet he has signed up to a political party that is hell-bent on signing up to the single currency and determined to sacrifice the British economy at the altar of European cooperation.

I am very sad that Ivan Massow has chosen to defect. He is a delightful human being, thoughtful, charismatic and charming. But he is wrong, wrong, wrong.

 Ed Vaizey was a Conservative candidate at the last general election

fields.headline: Is it time to bust these sanctions?
fields.trailText: Peter Preston rightly raises the question of the efficacy of sanctions (Comment, July 31)
fields.body:
Peter Preston rightly raises the question of the efficacy of sanctions (Comment, July 31). Anyone who has visited countries subjected to international sanctions will know that a common factor of such isolation is the sense of hopelessness and abandonment that afflicts the ordinary people, who bear the brunt of them. Sanctions only entrench dictators. Normalised relations cannot be established by anything short of revolutionary change and progress is projected into the distant future, usually related to the mortality of the dictators.

In any event, we are highly selective about blanket sanctions. Countries such as China are perceived as too important economically and strategically to freeze out. In their case our policy is qualified normalisation. Why not apply the same approach to countries such as Iraq, Iran, Libya and Cuba? Give people hope and you empower them.
John Stone
Thames Ditton, Surrey

August 6 will be the 10th anniversary of the imposition of economic sanctions on Iraq. Over the past decade, literally hundreds of thousands of Iraqi children have died as a result of these sanctions. The BBC's John Simpson recently commented that "if people could hear and see what is being done in their names in Iraq, they would be outraged. But they don't, so it continues". We agree and fully endorse the protest on August 7 at the Foreign Office.
Benjamin Zephaniah
Caroline Lucas MEP
Rowan Williams,
Archbishop of Wales
and seven others
Voices in the Wilderness
voices@viwuk.freeserve.co.uk

On August 2 1990, Saddam's troops invaded Kuwait and wreaked havoc on our country (Saddam casts long shadow, August 2). Ten years on, Saddam represents as great a threat to the stability of Kuwait as he ever did. His political discourse has not changed. As far as he is concerned, August 2 is still a date to celebrate despite the subsequent misery inflicted on so many people. Saddam continues to deny access to hundreds of Kuwaitis and third-country nationals still unaccounted for. The whole world sympathises with the plight of ordinary Iraqis, except Iraq's own leader. He still refuses to avail himself of UN resolution 1284, which allows him to use the proceeds of oil sales to purchase food and medicines for all his people. Saddam claims he wants to end the suffering of his people. Yet by his own actions, he is ensuring the opposite.
Khaled Al-Duwaisan
Kuwaiti ambassador

In his analysis of the current political situation in Iraq (Targeting the tyrant, August 1), Said Aburish is right to claim that "on a popular level, the prospects for an uprising are all but non-existent". He fails, however, to acknowledge the real reason for this. Crushed by 10 years of sanctions which have killed 500,000 children under the age of five and destroyed the country's infrastructure, the Iraqi people are in no state to mount a serious opposition. The sanctions are not just morally corrupt, but strategically redundant.
Peter Pattisson
London
ppattisson@hotmail.com

Unicef figures of the mortality rates among the children in Iraq are a complete fabrication by the Iraqi regime. According to a UN report, Iraqi medical expenditure in the last three years totalled only $450m, although resolution 986 allocated $1.32bn every six months. While the humanitarian campaigners' concern over the people of Iraq is appreciated, their ill-informed efforts can equally be damaging. Democratisation of the Middle East won't just happen through wishful thinking.

The regime in Iraq crippled the economy by spending its oil wealth on its military ambitions, gassing the Kurds and invading other nations.

In 1994 a group of Baghdad merchants who tried to import cheap food in an attempt to lower the market prices were executed. Last year a group of farmers were arrested for their protest against regulations limiting rice planting. Do we really think lifting sanctions is going to help the oppressed?
Name and address supplied

Eighty-four countries are presently under sanctions. But, as Peter Preston points out, success stories are rare, not to say unknown. At last there does seem to be a growing recognition of this. As a member of the Nato parliamentary assembly, I recently attended a seminar in Macedonia on regional security and reconstruction. Speaker after speaker condemned the sanctions on Yugoslavia, which are devastating the whole area.

There is little confidence in the chances of success of the stability pact for south-east Europe, which seeks to exclude Yugoslavia. Serbia can't be ignored, it is one of the most important economies of the region. Those who can least cope are hardest hit by sanctions - refugees, children, the sick and elderly. The UN says poverty levels in Serbia almost doubled between July 1998 and September 1999 to 63% of the population.

The UN charter envisages sanctions as a means of averting a threat to international peace and security without resorting to military intervention - a means of resolving conflict, not a continuation of war by economic means. It's high time sanctions on Yugoslavia were lifted, so the process of rebuilding civil society can begin.
Alice Mahon MP

webTitle: Cancer warning halves deaths due to smoking

fields.headline: Cancer warning halves deaths due to smoking
fields.standfirst:
UK's success is example to world, say researchers
Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Britain has had the world's largest fall in premature deaths from lung cancer thanks to the drive to help smokers give up, according to a study reported yesterday in the British Medical Journal.
fields.body:
Britain has had the world's largest fall in premature deaths from lung cancer thanks to the drive to help smokers give up, according to a study reported yesterday in the British Medical Journal.

Lung cancer deaths have halved since 1965, mainly due to a reduction in the number who smoke. The findings come when, looking worldwide, deaths from tobacco related illnesses are increasing.

Researchers said the UK should be held up as an example to other countries, although they stressed that smoking was still Britain's biggest cause of premature death; half of all smokers would eventually be killed by their habit.

However, smokers who stopped, even in middle age, reduced significantly the risk of premature death; and those who stopped before middle age were at little higher risk than non-smokers.

The report was written by Sir Richard Doll, a professor emeritus of medicine at Oxford University, who 50 years ago was one of the first to link lung cancer with smoking, and by Sir Richard Peto of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund's Oxford unit, and also an Oxford professor. They studied rates of lung cancer and levels of smoking in the UK and in other countries.

Prof Doll said at a London press conference yesterday: "Our 1950 study showed that smoking was a cause of most of the lung cancer in Britain at that time, and our new study shows that widespread cessation of smoking has halved the number of lung cancer deaths that would otherwise be occurring in Britain in 2000."

In 1950, the UK had one of the worst rates in the world, 52 deaths per 100,000 men aged 35 to 54. From then on smoking rates, and levels of lung cancer, began falling, a trend not seen in the US until the 1970s.

Annual tobacco sales in real terms fell from £150bn in 1965 to £80bn in 1995 in the UK, the researchers found. By 1998, the death rate for men aged 35-54 had more than halved to 17.4.

Tobacco related deaths in middle age fell from 80,000 in 1965 to 40,000 in 1995, and were still rapidly decreasing.

Prof Doll's 1950 study compared the smoking habits of 1,465 people with lung cancer and 1,465 without the disease.

The new study compared the smoking habits of 982 people with lung cancer and 3,185 without. Because so many smokers have stopped, the new study could assess the effects of prolonged cessation.

It found that among men who continue to smoke, 16% would die from lung cancer before age 75 (unless they died of something else first). For those who stopped at age 50 this risk was 6%, and for those who stopped at age 30 it was less than 2%.

Smoking was still the biggest cause of premature death in Britain, with 6m tobacco related deaths over the last 50 years. And worldwide, it is predicted that in the 21st century 1bn will die from smoking.

Prof Peto said: "There are still 10m smokers in Britain, and about 5m will be killed by tobacco if they don't stop.

"Tobacco deaths over the next 50 years will be affected much more by the number of adults who manage to stop than by the number of adolescents who start smoking."

However, in many developing countries, smoking is on the increase.

Worldwide, there were 100m tobacco related deaths in the 20th century, but, if smoking trends continue, there will be 1bn in the 21st century.

Clive Bates, director of the anti-smoking charity Action on Smoking and Health, said: "The message from this is that no one should ever think it is too late to quit. Smoking isn't a one way street ending in an inevitable premature and agonising death. People can take control and reduce their risks very significantly and very quickly by giving up at any age."
