webTitle: Brazilian sect buys London radio station

fields.headline: Brazilian sect buys London radio station
fields.standfirst:
Evangelical group claims prayer can rid people of debt
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A Christian evangelical sect, which tells its followers that diseases are caused by demons and prayer can rid them of debt, has taken control of a London radio station from Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods.
fields.body:
A Christian evangelical sect, which tells its followers that diseases are caused by demons and prayer can rid them of debt, has taken control of a London radio station from Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods.

The Universal Church of the Kingdom of God is surrounded by controversy, with its Brazilian founder at the centre of corruption allegations, while the French authorities have branded it "dangerous".

Last night the church pledged not to use Liberty Radio, a speech and music station aimed at young women, to spread its unorthodox message.

But it admitted it would target people "in difficult situations" in late night broadcasts.

Liberty's new chief executive, 'Bishop' Renato Cardoso said: "We are not going to use lots of airtime to serve the church - but we do intend to provide a gateway for people in difficult situations.

"It will be in the very early morning hours and late at night when people in these difficult situations are looking for entertainment. They will find there a voice of hope and they will be able to contact a number in order to receive help."

Asked whether the church's number would be given to callers, Mr Cardoso said it would depend on the circumstances.

He denied they would be proselytising on air, which is forbidden by the radio authority's programme code.

The Universal Church hopes to boost listenership from 50,000 to 400,000, and plans to run Liberty as an effective commercial enterprise to add to its extensive international business interests.

The protestant evangelist movement in Brazil was founded by a lottery shop assistant, Edir Macedo, in 1977, and has a following of millions.

It has interests in TV and radio stations in Brazil, as well as owning a Rio de Janeiro second division football team.

Followers pledge 10% of their income to the church in the belief that God will return it later with interest.

In 1995, leaked videotapes broadcast on Brazilian national television showed its founder 'Bishop' Macedo grinning as he counted piles of dollars, and whooping it up in luxury hotels. The 'bishop' is shown exhorting his preachers to collect more from their flocks, saying: "If they don't pay, they can get out."

In Britain, an attempt to buy Brixton Academy as its national centre fell through in 1995, but it established a foothold when it acquired the Rainbow Theatre in London.

Leaflets circulated in Britain said the sect offered "strong prayer to destroy witchcraft, demon possession, bad luck, bad dreams, all spiritual problems" and said people would gain "prosperity and financial breakthrough".

In France, the church was described as "dangerous" in a recent parliamentary report.

French MP Jacques Yard claimed groups such as the Universal Church should not be allowed to operate because they "try to control people's minds". He accused them of extorting money from believers.

Senior members of the church have taken up management posts at Liberty Radio, including the new director, Paulo Monteiro, a minister, and the financial controller, Neila Akutu, who is married to a UK administrator.

The news was announced to Liberty staff in a memo circulated on Monday; the station director, John Ogden, and his deputy, Louise Wood, have both resigned in protest.

One senior staffer described the church members as "looking like the Osmonds - very good-looking, very smartly dressed, and they have to worship three times a day".

The staffer said a number of colleagues intended to leave, fearing Liberty would become a sect "mouthpiece".

A spokeswoman for the Cult Information Centre said: "There are very strict rules as to how religious groups advertise and how they fundraise on air. The rules in this country would prevent some of the things that cause concern in other countries. This church has always wanted to get a media platform, but I think they will find, if they have not done their research, that regulations in the UK are quite different from Brazil."

The sale of Liberty, valued at around £4m, was allowed by the radio authority on condition that the new owners keep to the existing format.

A spokeswoman said: "All the information we have on them meets the statutory requirements."

The 'bishop' is shown exhorting his preachers to collect more from their flocks, saying: "If they don't pay, they can get out." In Britain, an attempt to buy Brixton Academy as its national centre fell through in 1995, but it established a foothold when it acquired the Rainbow Theatre in London. Leaflets circulated in Britain said the sect offered "strong prayer to destroy witchcraft, demon possession, bad luck, bad dreams, all spiritual problems" and said people would gain "prosperity and financial breakthrough". In France, the church was described as "dangerous" in a recent parliamentary report. French MP Jacques Yard claimed groups such as the Universal Church should not be allowed to operate because they "try to control people's minds". He accused them of extorting money from believers. Senior members of the church have taken up management posts at Liberty Radio, including the new director, Paulo Monteiro, a minister, and the financial controller, Neila Akutu, who is married to a UK administrator. The news was announced to Liberty staff in a memo circulated on Monday; the station director, John Ogden, and his deputy, Louise Wood, have both resigned in protest. One senior staffer described the church members as "looking like the Osmonds - very good-looking, very smartly dressed, and they have to worship three times a day". The staffer said a number of colleagues intended to leave, fearing Liberty would become a sect "mouthpiece". A spokeswoman for the Cult Information Centre said: "There are very strict rules as to how religious groups advertise and how they fundraise on air. The rules in this country would prevent some of the things that cause concern in other countries. This church has always wanted to get a media platform, but I think they will find, if they have not done their research, that regulations in the UK are quite different from Brazil." The sale of Liberty, valued at around £4m, was allowed by the radio authority on condition that the new owners keep to the existing format. A spokeswoman said: "All the information we have on them meets the statutory requirements."

webTitle: Comment: Ivan Massow did not leave the Tory party, it left him

fields.headline: An innocent walks out
fields.standfirst:
The Massow defection: Did the Tories' favourite pin-up leave them - or did the party leave him?
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Massow defection: Did the Tories' favourite pin-up leave them - or did the party leave him?
fields.body:
A thread of quite startling naivety runs through the thoughts of the young millionaire businessman Ivan Massow, published yesterday upon his defection from what he called William Hague's "nasty" Conservative party. His recantation was absolute - indeed, so much so that the Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam, with characteristic directness, was moved to observe upon her surprise and incomprehension at the fact that he hadn't been in the Labour party in the first place.

Mr Massow could not have been more candid about the mistakes that he had made in not joining the nice "new" Labour party when Tony Blair was elected to lead it in 1994, nor about the misjudgments he now also recognised that he had similarly made about the political principles and pragmatism of Mr Hague. Yet it is nevertheless passingly bizarre that a man who has been on the inside track at Conservative Central Office since the last election, who was a potential runner as the Tory candidate to be the London mayor, who was on the official list of his former party's parliamentary seat-seekers until yesterday and who was apparently a personal and political adviser to the leader himself, could have got things quite so fundamentally wrong.

It is perhaps, in its way, a measure of the state of our party politics that this should be so. Defections are not, at present, as unusual as they have been during much of the postwar period. There were a few rightwing Labour MPs who understandably fell off the party bandwagon as it careered to the left in the 70s, and a few leftwing Tories became increasingly uncomfortable with Margaret Thatcher during the 80s, although not many actually left the party. The invention of the short-lived Social Democratic party helped redefine the centre left - and the Liberal party to redefine itself. It is only since the election of Mr Blair, first as Labour leader and then as prime minister, that the centre ground has become increasingly crowded. Mr Massow appears to be the latest victim of a lack of identifiable ideological commitment in either of the two major parties.

Even so, he presents himself as a figure of extraordinary political innocence. In his valedictory to the Tory party yesterday, he explained that he was sure, after the election in 1997, that he had made the right decision to stay with them because of Mr Hague's election to replace John Major and because of the new leader's expressions of inclusivity and tolerance. Yet any reading of the newspapers at that time or any conversation with a cross-section of Conservative MPs with a wider experience than Mr Massow of the world at Westminster would surely have told him then that precisely the opposite was the case.

In seeking the succession to Mr Major, Mr Hague was not the candidate who represented the ideas of a liberal, consensual Conservative party - nobody ever previously accused him of that. Given the views Mr Massow now expresses, the candidate he should have supported in that election was obviously Kenneth Clarke. Yet in fact it is quite hard to see how, for Mr Massow, anybody could have been an improvement on Mr Major. It would have been almost impossible to have found a single individual in any political party in the United Kingdom in the last century who was more inclusive and tolerant than the outgoing Mr Major. And poor John Major, how he suffered for it, too.

Ever since he succeeded to the leadership, Mr Hague has made it perfectly evident that he intended to reposition the Conservative party and he has set about doing exactly this. He has surrounded himself with a group of enthusiastic young advisers - Mr Massow, of course, being one of them - who seemed to know little about the practice of politics and understand less. The word in Tory circles is that Mr Hague actually consults nobody at all. An indication of this was given when a member of the shadow cabinet recently asked a former minister how the principle of collective cabinet responsibility applies in practice if nobody has been involved in any decisions. But Mr Hague's aim, presumably, has been to demonstrate firm leadership and thus establish the distinction between his policies and the wishy-washy, inclusive policies of Mr Major, who had tried so valiantly - and so unsuccessfully - to keep the party united. In pursuit of this objective, however, Mr Hague has been both exclusive and intolerant.

The result has been disastrous for the Conservative party, as most Tory MPs miserably concede in private. It will prove even more so in the months to come. Mr Hague has benefited from the government's difficulties and discomfiture in the past few weeks, but that has not been because of any positive leadership he has shown. He can better the prime minister at Question Time in the House of Commons but, surprisingly enough, that doesn't really seem to matter much any more. A small inroad has been made on Mr Blair's previously invincible poll ratings, but there is little doubt that this has happened because of the government's mistakes and failures rather than the perspicacity of the opposition's policies.

There are those within the Conservative party who say that, in reality, there are no policies at all. One very distinguished member of the last government told me in despair a few months ago that the party was suffering from a complete absence of any kind of strategy. In his view there were four areas on which the party needed a strategic approach: towards Mr Blair, the economy, social policy and Europe. "The only policy we have on anything is maintaining opposition to a single currency until the end of the next parliament - and what kind of policy is that?" he asked in exasperation. There is further considerable uneasiness at the fact that Conservative parliamentary candidates are being selected for seats, having committed themselves to complete opposition to a single currency not just until the end of the next parliament - but forever.

All of this makes the dispute within the party about its approach to tax-and-spend policies even more alarming for Mr Hague than the defection of one of his virtually unknown advisers. Whatever the protestations they make in public, the real threat to the Tory leader is called Michael Portillo. Since his re-election to parliament and subsequent appointment as shadow chancellor, Mr Portillo has been playing a wily game. He has been given a free hand to make economic policy in a manner that fits his own agenda as a chastened politician, a new, improved Portillo. But at last the Tory leader may have realised the mistake that he has made here. In what looked like a response to that, Mr Hague tried to conjure up his own image of a kinder and gentler Conservative party with his highly unspecific rhetoric on the fringes of the Republican convention this week about "compassionate Conservatism" - only to have Mr Massow give the lie to that. "I've never heard a more cynical use of words without meaning," he wrote yesterday. Ivan Massow may be a political innocent, but he does seem to have touched on something there.

webTitle: New all-girl group shakes up classical world

fields.headline: The Bond girls aiming to leave classical music world shaken and stirred
fields.trailText: Just when you thought it was safe to turn on the radio, the music industry is attempting to go one better than Baby, Posh and Scary by creating the Classical Spice Girls.
fields.body:
Just when you thought it was safe to turn on the radio, the music industry is attempting to go one better than Baby, Posh and Scary by creating the Classical Spice Girls.

They are young, they are beautiful and, if the hype is to be believed, they are about to "reinvent the classical string quartet", with a generous helping of sex appeal.

Their name is Bond - because of the strong bond that has apparently grown between them since promoter Mel Bush "inspired" them to come together - and all are products of the country's leading conservatoires.

Whether the Royal College of Music taught them to pout and play their instruments simultaneously is another matter, however.

"Bond are sassy, sexy, and they have lots to say," boasts Linda Valentine, of Universal Classics, which is launching the group next week with the kind of razzmatazz that usually accompanies a boy band.

"In fact, they are much better looking than the Spice Girls. But we don't welcome comparisons. The Bond girls are proper musicians; they have paid their dues."

Indeed, first violin Haylie Ecker, the group's brunette "who loves surfing", has a first-class degree from the Guildhall School, and two of the tracks on the band's debut album were composed by the girls themselves.

Less play has been made of the fact that Mike Batt, the veteran writer/producer behind the Wombles novelty hit in the 70s, also had a hand in the album.

According to their glossy promotional catalogue, which features the girls in a variety of alluring poses, "as early as 1980, at either ends of the earth, Bond had begun".

Ms Ecker and Tania Davis learned to play in their native Australia while "in Hull, Gay-Yee was eyeing up the piano, although as soon as she was big enough to hold it, she switched to her favoured cello".

Selling the girls as sirens may grate with traditionalists but it is a standard part of the promotional push which has been creeping into the classical world for several years now and has worked particularly well for German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter.

Bond's svengali, Mel Bush, has been down this road before, taking the pop and classical charts by storm with Vanessa-Mae, the teenage violinist he made a star by perching on top of a New York cab in kinky boots and mini-skirt

But the thinking behind Bond is far from shallow or calculating, their record company claims.

Unlike the Spice Girls, Ms Valentine insists that Bond are not just a manufactured pop group out to make a killing but evangelists on a mission to end the "Proms-style snobbery" surrounding classical music. "They are also providing glamorous role models that young people who might be interested in playing classical instruments can identify with," she said.

The tight leather trousers, bare midriffs and moody video, shot in deeply fashionable Cuba, are "just part of the image the public now expects," Ms Valentine added.

While the four tracks the Guardian has heard brought back memories of nightmare lift journeys, Universal is sure there is a gap in the market for poppy crossover classical music.

Even so, the new-look Radio 3, which has found a place in its schedules for Andy Kershaw's wild and funky world music, will not be rushing to play Bond's album, Born, when it is released next month.

"Sadly it doesn't matter what you look like on radio," a spokeswoman said. "We are all insanely jealous of anyone who can be both beautiful and talented enough to get a first at the Guildhall, but we do not decide on what we play by the cover of a CD.

"We will be delighted to play Bond's music if it matches the quality of performance we demand," she added.

String instrumentalists whose sex appeal sells

Vanessa-Mae

Vanessa-Mae Vanakorn Nicholson, to use her full name, has been compared to Paganini (mostly by her record company). The first classical musician to make an impact on MTV, this grand dame of glam classical - now all of 22 - made her debut with the Philharmonia, aged 12. Her career really took off when her image was "sexed up", complete with wet T-shirt, for her top-selling album, Red Hot.

Anne-Sophie Mutter

The beautiful, thirtysomething German violinist was a teen prodigy when discovered by Von Karajan in the Black Forest. Viewed as one of the greatest violin players, her life has been touched by tragedy. Her husband died of cancer four years ago.

The Mediaeval Baebes

Self styled "temptresses" - 12 of them - who caused a stir in the plainsong world with their album of mediaeval choral music. Now with a big following, they appear countrywide dressed in billowing white dresses to sing their madrigals. Despite a number of Baebes having little musical training, they have sparked a revival in Latin and Middle English hymns.

Nina Kotova

The 28-year-old Russian model turned concert star bought her first good cello from the proceeds of her catwalk work for Comme des Garcons, Chanel, Lagerfeld and Armani. For the last CD, she is pictured draped over her cello. "I'm proud of being a pin-up," she said.

Linda Brava

The Finnish-born, self-styled "princess of the violin" had a modest reputation on the international circuit before she unfurled herself in Playboy magazine. In a country with a surfeit of classical stars, she is now the biggest seller.

webTitle: Leader: Kashmir violence threatens hopes of peace

fields.headline: Kashmir's killing fields
fields.standfirst:
Atrocities must not stifle new peace hopes

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: The killers came as the sun was going down. They opened fire without warning on pilgrims who had gathered at the shrine of Amarnath, south-east of Srinagar. Thirty people died; 47 were wounded. But that was just the beginning.
fields.body:
The killers came as the sun was going down. They opened fire without warning on pilgrims who had gathered at the shrine of Amarnath, south-east of Srinagar. Thirty people died; 47 were wounded. But that was just the beginning. In the next few hours, seven more murderous attacks brought terror to villages and towns across Kashmir. Last night, the death toll stood at 91. Most of those killed were Hindus, but many Muslims were also caught up in the mayhem. As so often in the past in Kashmir, where an estimated 25,000 people have died in unchecked violence over the past decade, nobody claimed responsibility, nobody gave a reason. And nobody, in the world beyond this disputed land, seems to care very much one way or the other.

Yet Kashmir does matter, for a broad range of reasons reaching far beyond the human suffering on the blood-soaked ground of Kalaroos and Achabal. It is a country torn by the competing claims of India, Pakistan and China. It is a testing ground for the peaceful coexistence or otherwise of Hindus, Buddhists and Muslims, who form the majority. It is a hotbed of secession or, alternatively, the scene of a principled, Timorese-type battle for self-determination and independence. Kashmir is the place where nuclear-armed India and Pakistan, unconstrained by the comprehensive test ban treaty or other international regulation and informed by a deep and historical mutual distrust, confront each other and often come to proxy blows.

The struggle to end Indian rule in Kashmir has implications for the sovereign integrity of India as a whole, where other states like Tamil Nadu, Assam and Punjab wrestle with secessionist agitation. The extent to which General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's military leader, is able or willing to control militant in digenous and foreign-manned Islamic groups based in Pakistan-controlled Kashmir has a significant bearing not only on Kashmir's future but also on his own. Cast even more broadly, Kashmir potentially pits US-backed and US-armed India against a Pakistan which, in its post-coup isolation, increasingly turns to Russia and China for support. Kashmir does matter a lot. But what is to be done about it?

These latest atrocities appear intended to stifle the tentative beginnings of a Kashmir peace process after a long impasse. Under quiet American prompting, the Indian government recently approached Kashmir state's secessionist Hurriyat Conference opposition coalition. It also undertook some prisoner releases. In response, Kashmir's chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, alarmed that he was being outflanked, produced new autonomy proposals, modelled on the system in place in Kashmir before 1953. Although this plan initially caused a storm in Delhi, with much posturing from chauvinist members of the Hindu- dominated government, it was not rejected outright. Then last month, the leading Pakistan-linked Islamic group, the Hizbul Mojahedin, declared a ceasefire. Again, discreet US pressure on Gen Musharraf appears to have played a role. A multilateral dialogue was developing; talks with Delhi were imminent.

But other armed Islamic groups opposed the Hizbul Mojahedin ceasefire, denouncing it as treachery. Was it these factions, linked under the umbrella of the United Jihad Council from which Hizbul was expelled, which let loose the killers? They say not. As usual, everybody blames everybody else. Yet whatever the shameful truth, this inhuman rampage must not be allowed to kill new hope of peace in Kashmir. It matters too much.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Anyone planning to marry, and who shares my sane and rational friend Paul Johnson's religious tastes, is directed to the Brompton Oratory. That very posh church's nuptial instruction sheet is a classic, neatly rebutting traditional accusations that the Roman Catholic church is both keen on money and authoritarian. "Under no circumstances whatever will singers or other musicians other than those employed by the Fathers of the Oratory be permitted to sing or play," it says. As for photography and video recording, this is permitted, but "in the case of a video or sound recording an additional 50% is added to the fee." Quite right. "If wedding guests use video cameras or tape recorders," it continues, "YOU will be charged an additional 50% on the music fee." You're very kind. There's much more, but my favourite concerns the bride's traditional leeway regarding strict punctuality. "Where brides arrive at the church more than 15 minutes late, the Fathers of the Oratory reserve the right to vary or cancel the arrangements at their discretion." That's it then, she's 17 minutes late, everybody out. "FEES WILL NOT BE REFUNDED."

Particularly impressed at the scoop must be the Times and its news editor, Michael Gove. A likeable chap, Govey is building the most tremendous reputation for having the best nose for a cracking news story of his generation. It was Govey's biography of Michael Portillo that failed to mention his student homosexuality - and now he's done it again. "He's not sharing the flat any more," explains the old newshound when we call about Mr Massow. "He moved out a few weeks ago."

fields.headline: Pakistan to sell nuclear material
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: The military regime in Pakistan is to allow the export of radioactive material and equipment for nuclear reactors, in apparent breach of recently drafted guidelines.
fields.byline: Rory McCarthy in Islamabad and  Julian Borger in Philadelphia
fields.body:
The military regime in Pakistan is to allow the export of radioactive material and equipment for nuclear reactors, in apparent breach of recently drafted guidelines.

The news surprised and confused US officials, who said it appeared to undermine much of the recent progress made in talks on introducing greater controls on nuclear materials.

In a full-page newspaper advertisement the Pakistani commerce ministry has published an application form for the export of 11 radioactive substances, including depleted uranium, enriched uranium, plutonium and tritium, and 17 types of equipment, including nuclear power reactors, nuclear research reactors and reactor control systems.

It is the first time Pakistan has openly authorised the sale of nuclear materials since it became the world's newest acknowledged nuclear power in May 1998, when it conducted six bomb tests in direct response to tests in India.

Would-be exporters, who have to pay up to £1,400 in application fees, must declare that the sale is for peaceful purposes only and the material will not be re-exported.

They must reveal the source of the material or equipment, supply an end-user certificate, and obtain a "no-objection certificate" from the government. Although almost all nuclear material is held by the government, there are some private contractors.

"This is a fulfilment of our commitment to transparency," Javed Jabbar, the information minister, said yesterday. "There is absolutely no scope left for any kind of misuse or pilferage or illegal export of any substance. We are doing it only in order to be a good nuclear citizen."

He said Pakistan had exported no nuclear material in the past and had no immediate plans for exports now.

Ishfaq Ahmed, the head of the Pakistani atomic energy commission, said the export of fissionable material, including enriched uranium and plu tonium, was banned but other nuclear material exports would be considered. His statement contradicted the advertisment's suggestion that enriched uranium and plutonium could be exported.

"We made a commitment to the international community that we would put in a place a system to exercise controls on nuclear exports and that is what this is," he said.

A US state department official said: "This is not exactly what the US had in mind when we talked to them about nuclear controls."

Another, engaged in monitoring Pakistan's nuclear programme, said export control guidelines had been drawn up by Islamabad only two weeks ago, and the advertisement seemed to contradict them.

"Up to now the Pakistanis have not supported the idea of making money out of selling this stuff," the official said. "We're still trying to figure out what all this new stuff means."

Pakistan's newest nuclear reactor went operational last month. The 300Mw plant at Chasma, in Punjab, was built with Chinese help. Another on the same site should be ready within 10 years.

The country's first plant, a 125Mw reactor in Karachi, began operations in 1971. Pakistan also operates a research reactor at Khushab, near Lahore, also built with Chinese help. It produces enough weapons-grade plutonium for five nuclear warheads every year, according to the Federation of American Scientists.

It has at least two uranium enrichment plants and two plutonium reprocessing plants.

The decision to invite nuclear exports comes as the government struggles to revive the economy. With $38bn (£25.5bn) in foreign debt still to be paid, it must raise revenue quickly.

"The purpose of this is very clear: it is to earn much-needed money," a former army chief, General Mirza Aslam Beg, said. "It shows we have enough material to maintain our low-level nuclear deterrence and so much in surplus that we can sell it in the open market. It is a respectable way of earning money."

webTitle: MPs criticise RAF Tornados after problems on Iraq patrols

fields.headline: MPs criticise RAF Tornados after problems on Iraq patrols
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: British war planes patrolling no-fly zones over Iraq are unsuitable for the task, and the conditions in which their crews are living are inadequate, a cross-party committee of MPs said yesterday.
fields.body:
British war planes patrolling no-fly zones over Iraq are unsuitable for the task, and the conditions in which their crews are living are inadequate, a cross-party committee of MPs said yesterday.

High temperatures in the Gulf have a "significant effect" on the performance of F3 Tornados, which were designed for cold war air defence operations over the North Sea, said the Commons defence committee.

The aircraft, it added, could not fly as high as the US F-15 fighters.

"We understand the frustration of our air crew in undertaking difficult missions with aircraft that are not ideal for the task, particularly when they are operating alongside their US colleagues who have demonstrably superior equipment," said the committee.

The Ministry of Defence is upgrading the Tornados to give them advanced air to air missiles and enable pilots to identify planes flying nearby through electronic means rather than just on sight.

The committee also criticised the accommodation at the RAF's Ali Al Salem airbase in Kuwait, where, it said, personnel were required to live 20 to a room, with 40 having access to only one bathroom with "inadequate" air conditioning. The poor telephone system connecting RAF personnel with the UK meant staff lost as much as half their weekly 20 minutes of free calls.

The committee defended on "moral and humanitarian grounds" Britain's participation in what is sometimes called the "forgotten war", although it admitted the "precise legal basis" for the operations was controversial.

Figures released by the MoD last month showed that British pilots had dramatically increased their strikes on Iraq. An estimated 78 tonnes of bombs had been dropped on southern Iraq by British aircraft since December 1998. That compared with 2.5 tonnes over the previous six years. Some 95% of targets attacked were Iraqi ground-based air defence systems.

About 1,000 British service personnel are stationed in the Gulf region at an estimated cost of £30m a year.

In a separate report yesterday a Lords committee was sceptical about plans to create an EU rapid reaction force of up to 60,000 troops by 2003.

The force's task would include "peacemaking" that could amount to war, action unsuitable for the EU, the peers said.

Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, said yesterday the government's aim was "European defence which produces flexible, better equipped, armed forces across Europe... strengthening Europe's contribution to Nato."

webTitle: Tobacco companies pay scientists at WHO meetings

fields.headline: Tobacco 'spies' exposed
fields.trailText: Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette company, admitted yesterday that it had paid scientists to attend World Health Organisation meetings but said it had done nothing improper to influence the UN body.
fields.body:
Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette company, admitted yesterday that it had paid scientists to attend World Health Organisation meetings but said it had done nothing improper to influence the UN body.

The admission came after a report by the WHO accused tobacco companies of trying to subvert international attempts to control smoking over the past two decades through an "elaborate, well financed, sophisticated and usually invisible" campaign.

In the 247-page report, based on documents tobacco companies were forced to release during lawsuits in the US, four experts detailed evidence of "clandestine" methods that went beyond the usual lobbying. Consultants with covert tobacco links were put in key posts at international health agencies, raising "serious questions about whether the integrity of WHO decision-making has been compromised".

"The documents show that tobacco companies sought to divert attention from the public health issues raised by tobacco use, to reduce budgets for the scientific and policy activities carried out by WHO, to pit other UN agencies against the WHO, to convince developing countries that WHO's tobacco control programme was a 'First World' agenda carried out at the expense of the developing world, to distort the results of important scientific studies on tobacco and to discredit WHO as an institution."

David Davies, vice-president of the EU region of Philip Morris International, said yesterday: "It is true that we had scientists retained by us to secure information.

"But there is nothing in the document and nothing in the report to suggest there was anything improper that occurred in relation to those activities and certainly nothing which in any sense influenced or undermined the activities of the WHO."

Mr Davies said that during the late 1980s and early 1990s Philip Morris had paid "a handful" of scientists to go to "ordinary plenary meetings" of the WHO to which it as a company had been denied access.

Mr Davies said those people were known to be working with the tobacco industry.

"I'm aware of one individual who had been a delegate to the WHO. We subsequently entered into arrangements with this person where we assisted in disseminating his views that were critical of the WHO," Mr Davies said.

He denied that tobacco companies had sought to influence research into smoking, but said a toxicologist working with a joint committee of the WHO and the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) had also worked for a tobacco industry body. "As I understand it it was not known to a number of people that he had been separately retained by the tobacco industry."

At the end of the report the experts, led by Thomas Zeltner, the director of Switzerland's public health authority, conclude: "That top executives of tobacco companies sat together to design and set in motion elaborate strategies to subvert a public health organisation is unacceptable and must be condemned."

They recommended further investigation in the WHO's 189 member states, including Britain, as well as other UN agencies, including the FAO, because of "possible clandestine tobacco company influence" on policies and officials.

British American Tobacco said the experts had misrepresented "the tobacco industry's legitimate lobbying activity".

The WHO adopted rules earlier this year obliging its employees to declare any conflict of interest and has not ruled out further action after the report.

Dr Zeltner said: "The consequences of the tobacco industry's misconduct fall not on global institutions but on people - by undermining tobacco control activities, tobacco companies have increased the toll of lives damaged and lost."

The WHO estimates that about 4m deaths a year are caused by tobacco, rising to about 10m by 2020.

fields.headline: Car crash sparks Moluccas battles
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Inhabitants of Indonesia's eastern Molucca islands, weary after 18 months of sectarian conflict, yesterday braced themselves for another explosion of violence as clashes erupted in the capital, Ambon, following a two-week lull.
fields.body:
Inhabitants of Indonesia's eastern Molucca islands, weary after 18 months of sectarian conflict, yesterday braced themselves for another explosion of violence as clashes erupted in the capital, Ambon, following a two-week lull.

A spokesman for the regional governor meanwhile confirmed that 1,000 Muslim fighters had destroyed the Christian village of Waai, 25 miles outside the city, killing at least 23 people in the past three days.

Yesterday's fighting in Ambon was sparked by an accident at one of the few intersections that both groups use in the now segregated city.

"The car containing the Muslims overturned and the Christians tried to flee in panic," said Friets Kerlely, a local journalist who witnessed the incident. "Soldiers were forced to start shooting at the Christians and three passengers were injured."

Muslims started throwing grenades and home-made bombs into the Christian area, injuring at least six more people. The Muslim leader Malik Selang said three Muslims were hurt when police and marines opened fire to disperse the grenade-throwers.

It was a similarly minor road accident that triggered the first major clash in the conflict in January 1999 that has since claimed about 4,000 lives and created more than 500,000 refugees.

"Ambon is the barometer of the whole region," said Machfud Waliulu, the editor of the Muslim newspaper, Ambon Ekspres. "If the city explodes again, then it sets the tone for everywhere else. It is particularly worrying as some areas, such as in the south-east Moluccas, are no longer experiencing any fighting and [are] well on the way to reconciliation."

Major Marthen Djari of the Indonesian army said yesterday that the village of Waai was completely destroyed, despite the presence of 75 heavily armed soldiers who offered no resistance. "There are a few trees still standing but that's about it," he said. "Everything else has been burnt to the ground or demolished. It seems the Muslims who attacked are now chasing the Christians into the hills."

webTitle: Police reveal extent of organised crime

fields.headline: Police reveal extent of organised crime
fields.standfirst:
Crime gangs in the UK are 'networking', intelligence research finds
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: More than 900 crime families and other organised criminal groups in the UK, are dealing in activities ranging from drugs smuggling to trafficking endangered species of rare animals, a report revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 900 crime families and other organised criminal groups in the UK, are dealing in activities ranging from drugs smuggling to trafficking endangered species of rare animals, a report revealed yesterday.

With crime costing the country an estimated £50bn a year, the gangs pose a formidable threat to the economy and the justice system. They have started "networking" in a way that could make them more difficult to catch, the National Criminal Intelligence Service warned.

NCIS said 56% of gangs are involved in drug trafficking and nearly all are money laundering in the report The Threat from Serious and Organised Crime.

Yet NCIS found that few solicitors, accountants and estate agents had written "suspicious transaction reports". Investigators believe that many professionals turn a blind eye to criminal activity.

Rows between rival drug gangs accounted for an estimated 52 murders in the UK last year, the report said.

The increase in the number of kidnappings - from 41 in 1998 to 72 last year - was a reflection of the increase in illegal entrant traffic, particularly from the Fujian province in China. Many of those who pay criminals for passage into the UK are either forced into prostitution or imprisoned until their families pay ransom money.

While most of the crime gangs in the UK are British, NCIS identified significant activity by criminals from Albania, China, Colombia, the former Soviet Union, south Asia, Turkey, west Africa and the West Indies.

Albanian criminals were associated mainly with heroin trafficking, and prostitution. Chinese Triads, primarily the 14K and Wo Shing Wo groups, were linked to illegal immigration.

The Colombian cocaine cartels have been focusing particular attention on the UK because users here are prepared to pay up to 20% more for the drug than in other European countries.

The report said there were signs that crime gangs are beginning to diversify and collaborate in an unprecedented way.

"Thus, south Asian criminals appear to be involved in a wide spectrum of organised crime, including armed robbery, insurance fraud, credit card fraud, and vehicle theft, as well as crimes with which they were previously associated, such as heroin trafficking and illegal immigration."

The report added: "If a greater degree of collaboration occurs between criminals of different ethnicities, it will... make criminals more effective by introducing them to new criminal networks."

NCIS has compiled intelligence reports on 930 families and gangs working in the UK, though Roger Gaspar, the director of intelligence at NCIS, said they were not all major organisations.

Computer hacking, internet fraud and counterfeiting of the Euro were identified as key problems for the future.

The report said one high street bank, HSBC, came under regular attack from hackers, though security had never been breached. One hacker tried 150m passwords over two days before giving up.

The trafficking of endangered animals and plants was also highlighted. In 1997 and 1998, 2,999 live animals were seized.

The haul included 22 crocodiles, and scores of parrots, butterflies and poisonous frogs.

"The grip and influence of organised crime is far reaching," said John Abbott, director general of NCIS.

"There is nothing glamorous about organised crime, it brings with it many victims. The effects are increasingly felt in every local community throughout the UK."

 NCIS report in full

While most of the crime gangs in the UK are British, NCIS identified significant activity by criminals from Albania, China, Colombia, the former Soviet Union, south Asia, Turkey, west Africa and the West Indies. Albanian criminals were associated mainly with heroin trafficking, and prostitution. Chinese Triads, primarily the 14K and Wo Shing Wo groups, were linked to illegal immigration. The Colombian cocaine cartels have been focusing particular attention on the UK because users here are prepared to pay up to 20% more for the drug than in other European countries. The report said there were signs that crime gangs are beginning to diversify and collaborate in an unprecedented way. "Thus, south Asian criminals appear to be involved in a wide spectrum of organised crime, including armed robbery, insurance fraud, credit card fraud, and vehicle theft, as well as crimes with which they were previously associated, such as heroin trafficking and illegal immigration." The report added: "If a greater degree of collaboration occurs between criminals of different ethnicities, it will... make criminals more effective by introducing them to new criminal networks." NCIS has compiled intelligence reports on 930 families and gangs working in the UK, though Roger Gaspar, the director of intelligence at NCIS, said they were not all major organisations. Computer hacking, internet fraud and counterfeiting of the Euro were identified as key problems for the future. The report said one high street bank, HSBC, came under regular attack from hackers, though security had never been breached. One hacker tried 150m passwords over two days before giving up. The trafficking of endangered animals and plants was also highlighted. In 1997 and 1998, 2,999 live animals were seized. The haul included 22 crocodiles, and scores of parrots, butterflies and poisonous frogs. "The grip and influence of organised crime is far reaching," said John Abbott, director general of NCIS. "There is nothing glamorous about organised crime, it brings with it many victims. The effects are increasingly felt in every local community throughout the UK."  NCIS report in full

webTitle: Teachers frozen out of house market

fields.headline: Teachers frozen out of house market
fields.standfirst:
Homes trap as gap in wages and house prices widens
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers and nurses are so poorly paid they cannot afford to live in areas where they work, according to a study published yesterday.
fields.body:
Teachers and nurses are so poorly paid they cannot afford to live in areas where they work, according to a study published yesterday.

Service workers such as primary school teachers, nurses and hospital porters, have to commute long distances to work because their salaries do not match property and rent prices, according to the report by Britain's general trade union, the GMB.

The worst-hit areas are Kensington and Chelsea in London, Windsor and Maidenhead in Berkshire, and Hertfordshire and Dorset.

In the south-west, hospital porters earn £11,454 a year and are priced out of the property market completely. Only Plymouth offers accommodation affordable for bus drivers on £13,620.

Despite London salary weightings of around £2,000, nurses and teachers can only afford to buy properties in nine out of 32 London boroughs. According to the National Housing Federation, an income of £20,000 is needed to buy a small house in 75% of English counties.

The minimum income to buy a property in the London borough of Dagenham and Barking is £22,332. But the average salary for a newly trained teacher is £16,000 and a newly qualified nurse earns £14,890. As a result, unions said teachers and nurses faced a brick wall. They could not afford to buy in London, so they had to rent. But if they rented, they would never be able to save enough for the deposit to buy.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, said it was a scandal that such gaps in affordable housing existed.

"The announcement last week by the government that £500m is to be made available to house essential workers is a move in the right direction, but we are yet to be assured that it will be enough. The GMB would like to see a development in social housing too."

The Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions will this autumn announce proposals for the starter home initiative included in April's housing green paper.

This scheme would help low-paid service workers meet accommodation costs.

John Prescott has suggested the possibility of interest-free loans for nurses and teachers, as well as first time buyers on modest incomes.

A housing department spokeswoman said: "The government is accutely aware of the problem. It is imperative that key workers, who are essential to our society, should be able to afford to live close to their work."

Rory Taylor from St Bartholemew's and the London NHS trust said London recruitment of nurses was hin dered by the gap between salaries and house prices.

"We are one of many London trusts working with housing associations to build new staff accommodation and renovate our older properties.

We have been involved in this for a couple of years and our target is to create 1,000 new halls of residence-style flats."

The Peabody Unite housing association yesterday announced two accommodation projects with the St Bartholomew's trust worth £33m, including an office-block conversion in Forest Gate which will create 74 self-contained flats.

Olive Forsythe from the National Union of Teachers said: "There is a tradition in the health service of public-private partnerships to help nurses overcome the problem of housing.

"But there is no such tradition in teaching. The top income for a teacher, excluding performance related pay, which only one third can apply for, is £24,000. A two bedroom cottage in Southolt, Suffolk, costs £180,000."

'On what I get, I've no possibility of ever owning a London flat'

Anna O'Rawe has been a primary school teacher in north London for three years.

She works in North Finchley, where a two bedroom house can cost more than £250,000. She earns £19,000 a year. "I rent a shared house in [nearby] Crouch End for £360 a month plus bills, which is cheap because there is no tube station nearby," she said.

"I can't afford to raise a deposit but, if I did, I could get a mortgage for £80,000. Last year, a garage in my street sold for £70,000."

Ms O'Rawe, 26, said that she had discussed long term housing prospects with her deputy head teacher .

"We decided I could either go back home to Belfast where, for the cost of my London rent, I could buy a two bedroom house, or I could change career. I might become an educational psychologist.

"With a teacher's limited salary increases, I have no possibility of ever owning a flat in London."

Her journey to work takes one hour, using two buses. A bus pass costs £40 a month. Often she gets lifts to work with colleagues who also have to commute. Sometimes if she works late, she pays £12 for a taxi.

"Living far from the school is limiting because I am outside a community that I should be a part of," she said.

Jason Warriner is a staff nurse at Ealing hospital's HIV clinic in west London.

At 30, he has seven years' nursing experience and earns £17,000 a year. A one bedroom flat near his hospital costs between £130,000 and £200,000.

"I live in a 10ft by 14ft room that I rent for £294 a month from the hospital accommodation service.

"It contains a single bed, desk, wardrobe, wash basin and a chair. When people come round they have to sit on the bed. Four people on my corridor share a bathroom, but there is no sitting room," he said.

For the same price, he used to be able to rent a one bedroom flat in Leeds. Ealing hospital accommodation service requires one month's rent in advance, which many nurses are pushed to find.

"I'm trying to save for a deposit on an accommodation service flat," Mr Warriner said.

"To do this, I'm working extra shifts in coronary care at night and at weekends."

"I always thought that at my age I'd be living in my own house in a decent area. Instead I've got furniture stored all over the country because I can't afford a deposit on a flat.

"But I'm dedicated to my job and I would never give it up."

fields.headline: 93 dead in Kashmir massacres
fields.standfirst:
India blames Pakistan-based militants for 24 hours of carnage sparked by one faction's ceasefire

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: The disputed province of Kashmir was transformed into a bloody killing field yesterday when militants opposed to Indian rule carried out a succession of swift and organised massacres which left at least 93 people dead in 24 hours of frenzied carnage.
fields.byline: Luke Harding  in New Delhi and  Rory MaCarthy  in Islamabad
fields.body:
The disputed province of Kashmir was transformed into a bloody killing field yesterday when militants opposed to Indian rule carried out a succession of swift and organised massacres which left at least 93 people dead in 24 hours of frenzied carnage.

The attacks - which plunged relations between Indian and Pakistan into new turmoil - began hours after militant groups rejected a "treasonous" ceasefire announced last week by one rival faction, Hizbul Mojahedin. More massacres can now be expected, police chiefs in Kashmir warned last night.

India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, yesterday blamed separatist groups backed by Pakistan for the massacres and pledged that the peace process in Kashmir would continue. "It is clear that after Hizbul Mojahedin called for a ceasefire and talks, other militant groups have been instructed by Pakistan to step up their attacks on innocent and unarmed civilians," he said. "We will not bow to their threats."

Pakistan said the Indian army may have been responsible for the killings in an attempt to implicate Islamic militant groups. "Initial reports do not rule out the possibility of the killings resulting from firing by Indian forces," the Pakistan foreign ministry said in a statement.

Lashkar-e-Taiba, one of the hardline militant groups based in Pakistan, denied it was involved. "Islam does not permit us to kill innocent civilians," a Lashkar spokesman said.

The wave of massacres began on Tuesday night when Hindu pilgrims on a two-day pilgrimage to a holy cave in Kashmir were ambushed by gunmen at Pahlgam, 55 miles south of Srinagar, Kashmir's capital. Indian soldiers fired back. In the gunfight that followed 32 people were killed, including the two militants, and more than 50 injured. Many of the dead were Muslim porters. Some eye witnesses said the gunmen wore police uniforms.

Seven members of a family were gunned down in the village of Achchabal later that evening. And in Mir Bazar in Anantnag, 30 miles south of Srinagar, 19 migrant workers in a brick factory were shot dead when guerrillas swooped on their village and pulled the workers from their houses.

The carnage continued yesterday with two attacks on a remote village in the Doda region of Kashmir, where 15 people were killed. At roughly the same time, 13 people were gunned down at Banihal. A family of seven was executed at Kupwara. In total more than 70 people were injured in 24 hours of violence unprecedented in Kashmir's recent history. More than 50 people remained in hospital last night.

Jammu and Kashmir's Muslim chief minister, Farooq Abdullah, yesterday blamed the killings on Lashkar, which has condemned Hizbul Mojahedin's decision to lay down arms and talk to the Indian government. The attacks had been orchestrated from "across the border", he added. Jammu's chief of police, SP Vaid, said intelligence intercepts revealed the involvement of Lashkar.

In a stormy session of parliament in New Delhi yesterday, the Congress party opposition leader, Sonia Gandhi, accused the government of failing to act on intelligence reports which warned last week of possible attacks. The thousands of pilgrims heading to the shrine at Amarnath were "soft targets" and should have been better protected, she said. Pilgrims yesterday said they would continue their journey. "My family is scared but God has called us and we will go," one said.

In Pakistan, Hizbul Mojahedin's leader, Syed Salahuddin, warned that the group's unexpected ceasefire would not continue indefinitely. "We are looking for a positive response from India," he said. Hizbul was coming under increasing pressure from groups opposed to the peace talks, he added. "Ceasefire doesn't mean giving up jihad. I'm sorry to say it means a breathing space."

India is expected to begin negotiations with the militant group shortly but says talks will only be carried out within the framework of the Indian constitution, which maintains that Kashmir is part of India.

webTitle: Sour end to farmer's dream symbolises dairy crisis

fields.headline: Sour end to farmer's dream symbolises dairy crisis
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Reality finally caught up with Anthony Pattinson at 3.45am yesterday as he herded his prize Jerseys to the milking parlour for the last time. "I must confess I started feeling it," he lamented as the sun rose on the Pennines. "Some sadness, yes. I had reached the end of my working life."
fields.body:
Reality finally caught up with Anthony Pattinson at 3.45am yesterday as he herded his prize Jerseys to the milking parlour for the last time. "I must confess I started feeling it," he lamented as the sun rose on the Pennines. "Some sadness, yes. I had reached the end of my working life."

Two hours later, along deserted north Cumbrian roads, a small convoy of transporters ferried 538 cows, calves, heifers and bulls, with a variety of exotic names, to the auction mart in Penrith seven miles away.

The end had come for the family firm. One more dairy farm disappeared under the auctioneer's hammer, joining an estimated 4,000 which have gone out of business in four years.

But for many, the abrupt disposal of the Calthwaite Hall herd - along with three more farm workers - symbolised the deepening crisis in this sector of farming, fuelled by a 30% drop in milk prices in three years.

No one in the industry can recall such a large sale of pedigree cattle in prime condition - certainly not Andy Holiday, chairman of the Penrith auction company and a dairy farmer himself.

"Remember this was a 'closed' herd for 50 years, cloned without science. The Pattinson family were ahead of their time, diversifying 20 years ago into other milk products like yoghurt. But we are all hitting out heads against a brick wall trying to stay in business."

It was all so very different in the early spring of 1950 when Mr Pattinson's father, who owned a mill on the Cumbrian coast at Whitehaven, bought his first Jerseys at St Helier in the Channel Islands and brought them to Calthwaite by sea and rail.

The herd was expanded to its present size in the 1960s. By the 1970s 100 people were employed producing ice cream, cottage cheese, butter, fudge and much more. Turnover was approaching £1m annually.

Eventually, the workforce fell to three. With no sons, Mr Pattinson did not expect his two daughters, Kirsty, 23 and Sally, 21, to take over the 500-acre farm, most of which is tenanted. So he struggled on, hoping for better times, but fearing the worst.

This year he decided to pull the plug.

Yesterday, he went out in style. Hundreds of buyers, from around Britain and Ireland, crammed into the ring, eagerly studying the 150 page glossy catalogue which gave the family history of each animal, from Calthwaite Sparkling Gemstone to a bull named Calthwaite Red General.

As auctioneer Chris Dodds processed 60 cattle an hour - averaging £355 each - Mr Pattinson confessed he had one big regret. "The animals hopefully will go to good farms, but if I am sad about anything it is the fact that I am having to make three men redundant."

But some who had snapped up bargains were happier. Robert Graham, from Stirling, Scotland's biggest independent milk processor, was happy with the 10 cows he had bought to bolster a Jersey herd. "But I've never known things so bad in the industry," he said. "I just hope that those who decide to stay will benefit in the long run."

In London, the National Farmers' Union was not so sure. "This is a very grim time for dairying with the high pound," a spokesman said.

By the evening, Mr Pattinson headed home. But it will be two weeks before the curtain finally falls at Calthwaite Hall. A vast array of farm machinery awaits sale at another auction.

 Hill farmers may soon have pension contributions paid from EU subsidies under new moves to stop them eking out a fragile living well after normal retirement age, writes James Meikle.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, is even ready to consider whether the government could make regular direct debit payments to pension companies on farmers' behalf from the money approved in Brussels.

Mr Brown thinks too many among Britain's 60,000 hill farmers are relying on the capital value of their livestock and farms to tide them through to their old age. Many are carrying on into their 70s.

webTitle: Barak loses knesset vote and foreign minister but vows to find peace

fields.headline: Barak loses knesset vote and foreign minister but vows to find peace
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday took a double blow from a hostile parliament, as he suffered the resignation of his foreign minister, David Levy, and a vote granting preliminary approval to new elections.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday took a double blow from a hostile parliament, as he suffered the resignation of his foreign minister, David Levy, and a vote granting preliminary approval to new elections.

Most observers now believe early elections are inevitable for Mr Barak, whose coalition government is just 15 months old.

The parliamentary recess gives him a reprieve until late October but his only chance of survival rests on his ability to reach agreement with his old enemy Yasser Arafat before elections are called.

"Mr Barak now has precious time to try to close a deal with Mr Arafat and to bring it to the Israeli public and call for a general election," said Yaron Ezrahi, a fellow of the Israel Democracy Institute and a political science professor at Hebrew University. "This gives him the opportunity to go to the people over the heads of the parties and the parliament."

The Israeli prime minister may also try to restart secret talks with Syria.

However, Mr Ezrahi warned that the rightwing Likud party could try to wrongfoot Mr Barak by reconvening parliament early to push through the elections bill.

Mr Levy's resignation yesterday, in protest at the Israeli prime minister's concessions at Camp David, added to the pressure on the government.

After vowing never to divide Jerusalem, whose eastern half has been occupied illegally by Israel since 1967, Mr Barak offered the Palestinians control over some distant neighbourhoods of the city.

Mr Levy termed this a betrayal. He was also piqued by Mr Barak's decision to let another minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, lead the negotiations. Mr Ben Ami, and another senior negotiator, Dan Meridor, are among the candidates to replace him as foreign minister.

The knesset vote for fresh elections yesterday was won by 61 votes to 51. The bill must pass three further meetings, and could be bottled up in committee.

Mr Barak lost another vote earlier this week when the knesset conspired to defeat his choice for Israel's president, Shimon Peres.

In the face of his mounting troubles, Mr Barak was undaunted, and promised to astonish Israeli voters by succeeding in the weeks ahead where the 15 days at Camp David failed.

"The elections are much farther away than you think," he said. "We may have three months to try and consolidate either the peace negotiations or the government and this may be the 90 days of the most important period in the present Israeli agenda."

A more pressing deadline for Mr Barak is September 13, when Mr Arafat is pledged to declare an independent state.

The two sides have re-opened low-level negotiations. But Mr Arafat may not be able to make the compromises on Jerusalem and the rights of 3.6m registered Palestinian refugees that the Israelis and Americans are pressing him to.

At the weekend, the US president, Bill Clinton, hardened his criticism of Mr Arafat, and threatened to review $400m in US aid to the Palestinians, and consider moving Washington's embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem if he declares a state.

Yesterday, Mr Barak told Israeli television that the US could move its embassy by June 20, the day President Clinton leaves office.

Mr Ezrahi and others argue that Mr Barak, a highly decorated former army chief, is Mr Arafat's best hope for a just peace, and that future Israeli leaders will not be able to offer as much to the Palestinians.

However, it is far from certain that Mr Arafat can be frogmarched towards a deal, especially one that would involve concessions that his people, and the Muslim world at large, would find impossible to stomach.

"Arafat does not really have much room to manoeuvre," said Khalil Shikaki, a Palestinian analyst.

Most observers now believe early elections are inevitable for Mr Barak, whose coalition government is just 15 months old. The parliamentary recess gives him a reprieve until late October but his only chance of survival rests on his ability to reach agreement with his old enemy Yasser Arafat before elections are called. "Mr Barak now has precious time to try to close a deal with Mr Arafat and to bring it to the Israeli public and call for a general election," said Yaron Ezrahi, a fellow of the Israel Democracy Institute and a political science professor at Hebrew University. "This gives him the opportunity to go to the people over the heads of the parties and the parliament." The Israeli prime minister may also try to restart secret talks with Syria. Mr Levy's resignation yesterday, in protest at the Israeli prime minister's concessions at Camp David, added to the pressure on the government. After vowing never to divide Jerusalem, whose eastern half has been occupied illegally by Israel since 1967, Mr Barak offered the Palestinians control over some distant neighbourhoods of the city. webTitle: Strike brings Zimbabwe's cities to a halt

fields.headline: Strike brings Zimbabwe's cities to a halt
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: A general strike shut down all of Zimbabwe's major cities yesterday in protest at the government's arbitrary application of the rule of law as President Robert Mugabe insisted that he will press ahead with the wholesale confiscation of white-owned farms.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal  in Harare and  Andrew Meldrum in Norton
fields.body:
A general strike shut down all of Zimbabwe's major cities yesterday in protest at the government's arbitrary application of the rule of law as President Robert Mugabe insisted that he will press ahead with the wholesale confiscation of white-owned farms.

The widespread support for the strike called by Zimbabwe's trade union confederation, and backed by the main political opposition party and farmers, was a further demonstration of disillusionment with the government a day after a one-third devaluation of the national currency.

Zimbabwe is facing its worst economic crisis since independence 20 year ago.

Many township residents are also angered at the deployment of the army in poor neighbourhoods where soldiers regularly beat presumed opposition supporters.

South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, added to the pressure on Mr Mugabe at a summit in Harare yesterday. South Africa is deeply worried about the cross-border impact of its neighbour's crisis. Mr Mbeki said he rejected a request for a meeting from Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change.

The Zimbabwean government's decision this week to quadruple the amount of white-owned farm land targeted for redistribution, and the severe economic consequences if it happens, will do nothing to bolster international confidence in the region. The South African rand was driven down further yesterday by the devaluation of the Zimbabwean dollar.

Mr Mugabe said yesterday that his government would press ahead with the expropriations but said war veterans would be removed from any farms not on the list for confiscation.

"There is a process now going on of acquiring land in accordance with the law, and in the context of that acquisition we will then be resettling those in need of land _ we will be removing all war veterans from the rest of the farms," he said.

Riot police were deployed in many parts of Harare yesterday to prevent anti-government demonstrations but there were no reports of violence. Most people stayed at home as the strike closed almost all factories, banks and large businesses although some smaller establishments opened. Harare's streets were largely deserted but some people took advantage of the day off work to join the long queues for fuel. Even those who might have wanted to go to work could not because public transport shut down.

Many schools were shut. Where teachers did go to work, some parents kept their children at home for fear of violence. The university closed after lecturers and students joined the protest.

Hopewell Gumpo, president of the national students union, said: "We condemn the heavy-handedness of the police and the army in parts of Harare. We demand among other issues a transparent land redistribution programme to the landless in a peaceful and orderly manner."

Even some civil servants defied the implicit threat of dismissal and heeded the strike call, although one finance ministry worker enjoying the day in a Harare park said he intended to tell his boss he had tried to come to work but was threatened by strikers.

At least one white farmer who joined the strike had his property seized by war veterans as a punishment. But that did not discourage many others, including Jim Sinclair in Serui Source 45 miles south of Harare, from joining the protest and telling his labourers to take the day off.

"We must feed our pigs, because pigs don't know about strikes, but otherwise we have shut everything down. All the farmers have shut down to protest the lawlessness throughout the country.

"We need to get a message across that this country cannot go on like this. We are at one, my employees and myself. We have suffered work interruptions, invasions, threats of violence. We've had enough," he said.

The day before the strike, one of Mr Sinclair's neighbours was threatened by a group of armed supporters of Mr Mugabe.

They forced him to sign away his farm and told him to leave his home.

Mr Sinclair expects the Mugabe government will "take some form of action to punish us for participating in this strike. But I believe we still have to do it and we may have to do it again. We need to impress that violence cannot be used to run our country".

Zimbabwe's white farmers went to the supreme court yesterday to try to halt the seizure of more than 3,000 farms for redistribution.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: France seeks end to sanctions
fields.body:
France seeks end to sanctions

The French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, called yesterday for an end to the UN's "cruel, ineffective and dangerous" sanctions against Iraq.

He said they posed a risk to social cohesionand were a threat to regional stability. "They are cruel because they punish exclusively the Iraqi people and the weakest among them," he said.
Reuters, Paris

Hostage talks start in Nigeria

Royal Dutch/Shell said yesterday that it was discussing with community leaders in southern Nigeria the release of 165 oil workers, including 20 expatriates, taken hostage by local militants on two of its rigs in the Niger delta on Monday.

The company said five of the hostages were British. The other expatriates were Americans, Australians and Lebanese. All were unhurt after being kidnapped by about 60 armed Ijaw youths, demanding work for local young people.
Reuters, Lagos

Chinese set fire to HK office

At least 47 people were injured yesterday after a gang of mainland Chinese who had been refused local identity cards set fire to an office and stabbed officials at Hong Kong's immigration department.

About 20 mainlanders, who were trying to claim Hong Kong permanent residency rights, set the fire after dousing the 13th-floor office with an inflammable liquid.
Reuters, Hong Kong

UN kills two in East Timor

UN peacekeepers in East Timor killed two pro-Jakarta militiamen in a gun battle near the Indonesian border yesterday.

They were the first fatalities caused by the UN force in the territory, although the previous non-UN unit killed two militiamen in October.
AP, Dili

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Pocahontas/Une Histoire D'Eau/Close Encounters Of The Third Kind/Someone To Watch Over Me
fields.body:
Pocahontas

(Mike Gabriel, 1995)

7pm, Disney

Mel Gibson, aka Rocky the Rooster in Chicken Run, also lent his voice to this animated adventure, playing heroic but anaemic John Smith, the explorer who falls for feisty native American girl Pocahontas. An earnest account of native Americans defending their land against rapacious white invaders, it's no Disney classic, but makes colourful, action-packed school-holiday fare.

Une Histoire D'Eau

(Truffaut/Godard, 1961)

7.40pm, FilmFour

Brief collaboration between the two New Wave heavyweights. It's a fine example of how to craft something slick with virtually zero resources - a playful little tale of a woman given a lift by a handsome stranger when most of France is under flood. Truffaut allegedly shot the footage; Godard later (radically) reassembled it and added the mixed score and voice-over.

Close Encounters Of The Third Kind (Special Edition)

(Steven Spielberg, 1977)

12.25am, FilmFour

Featuring the aliens with the five-note musical calling-card. And curiously, since this is Spielberg's homage to 50s sci-fi, not a ray-gun in sight. He blew the $20m mega-budget on dazzling special effects - alien craft of astonishing size and power - and on clever smaller tricks too, like little Cary Guffey's toys going bonkers when the aliens arrive. An exercise in wide-eyed wonder, this special edition plays down Richard Dreyfuss's hammy exercise in obsession while zapping up the lightshow.

Someone To Watch Over Me

(Ridley Scott, 1987)

1am, Carlton Cinema

Class barriers tumble when lowly cop Tom Berenger is detailed to guard wealthy socialite and state's witness Mimi Rogers. The two become lovers, to the outrage of his wife (played by the excellent Lorraine Bracco). As you'd expect from Scott, the film is seductively shot, and the romantic drama works beautifully. But the thriller element is less plausible, despite a nervy stalking duel between cop and killer in Rogers' labyrinthine apartment.

webTitle: TV guide: Who will play Harry Potter in the film of the book?

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will play Harry Potter in the film of the book?
fields.trailText: Who will play Harry Potter in the film of the book?
fields.body:
An unknown .................4-6

Liam Aiken .................13-8

Haley Joel Osment ......11-4

Peter McNicholl ............4-1

Jake Lloyd ....................5-1

By now, at least half the world has read the new Harry Potter novel, so it's no surprise that Harry movie rumours have been swelling. The most striking news is that Warner Bros are considering an American actor as the child wizard. But when asked whether a US actor was in the running, the book's author, JK Rowling said: "Harry has still not been cast yet. And believe me, he's going to be British when he is!"

Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' analytical guru, thinks the Harry Potter movie is going to be magical. "But the story about who will play Harry is almost as good as any of the Potter storylines themselves. It makes fascinating reading."

At audition, children have five minutes to perform in front of director Chris Columbus and his daughter. Apparently, UK casting director Susie Figgis was so frustrated after seeing thousands of potential Potters that she left the project. Steven Spielberg allegedly pulled out of directing the picture after Rowling objected to his plans to cast The Sixth Sense star Haley Joel Osment in the lead. Some people are saying that Rowling signed a deal which gives her enormous control over the film. Others say that when the deal was cut, the issue of who plays Harry wasn't on the table.

"Haley Joel Osment's performance in The Sixth Sense was amazing," says Ed. "And Liam Aiken, from Stepmom, is in with a hell of a chance. Columbus likes him, and has worked with him before."

US casting director Janet Hirshenson has been seeing lots of other US children for the role - Jake Lloyd also comes into the reckoning. "A leading actor of his generation, but an outsider in my book," says Ed.

One English contender is Peter McNicholl (Vinnie Jones's son in Lock, Stock... ). "If he doesn't get the part, I'm told he's sending Vinnie round to sort them out," says Ed. "I wonder if Harry can make any inanimate object disappear!"
