fields.headline: Guys and dolls
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: The Family Guy/The Lipstick Years/Buffy The Vampire Slayer
fields.body:
The premise of The Family Guy (C4) may sound a teensy bit familiar. A cartoon (or animated series, if you think of "cartoon" as an insult, which makes you someone with very odd priorities) revolving round a typical - which is to say, dysfunctional - American family. There's the dumb dad, Peter, a long-suffering wife, Lois, a son, Chris, who puts the "oo" in stoopid, his wiser sister, Meg, a baby, Stewie, and a dog. That talks. And to whom the rest of the family chatter. In this opening episode, Peter lost his job due to incompetence, was presented with an accidentally huge welfare cheque, and much comedy ensued.

Ring any bells? Does Quasimodo? Admittedly, The Simpsons' dog, Santa's Little Helper, may not be the most articulate member of that particular all-American family, but the genealogy between Family Guy and those Springfielders is undeniable. Distant cousins they may be, but Family Guy has got its chromosomes in the wrong order. The humour, pathos and moments of genius that have marked out The Simpsons as one of the best ever TV programmes are conspicuous by their absence in Family Guy. And when I said "much comedy" just then, I lied. Family Guy makes King Of The Hill look hilarious. Which it isn't.

Not that they don't try. From the outset, when the family bemoans the lack of morally decent programmes on telly, to its pop culture references and outlandish scenarios, Family Guy attempts to be as ironic and on-the-edge as its ancestor. On every level, it is flawed, mistaking crass for risqué and failing to spot the difference between a stupid show and a stupid character.

Where The Simpsons seems effortless in its undermining of convention, Family Guy goes at it with a pneumatic drill, coming off as laboured, desperate and unfunny. Just like the sitcoms at which it takes supposed satirical aim. (Canned laughter would not be lowering Family Guy's tone.) Granted, it's probably the only cartoon which uses the words "cursed ovarian bastille" and "oestrogenical treachery" - and from a baby determined to take over the world, too - but for anyone familiar with Pinky And The Brain, the lab rats from The Animaniacs (The Brain is an Orson Wellesian megalo-maniac rat intent on world domination), baby Stewie is plain lame.

Hasn't Lowri Turner got a big mouth? Bet she can get a whole Magnum in there without biting it in two. And for some reason, she stresses syllables in words that don't matter. Most of us would merrily gambol through a word like "feminism" in one breath, but Lowri e-nun-ci-ates it ve-ry clear-ly . Get her reading Harry Potter on Jackanory and civilisations will rise and fall before she gets to the end of chapter one.

The Lipstick Years (BBC2), in which Lowri deftly skates over her involvement in the makeover fascism rife on daytime telly ("Elizabeth here was a terrible frump until we slapped a bit of make-up on her and brushed her hair!"), this week charted the rise and fall of the beauty queen. From its beginnings as an emancipatory pastime for Edwardian women through its tits-ass-dental-floss-bikinis heyday to today's it's-a-great-way-to-get-a-scholarship apologists, this was thought-provoking television. Thoughts provoked included: would I leave Eric Morley, Miss World supremo, alone with my pets?; how much do I hate someone who says, "I'm glad I respect myself enough to get up and go to the gym on a regular basis"?; and why do Miss Teen America, Miss USA and Miss Universe - who all live together in an apartment in Trump Tower - have so much frozen sweetcorn in their freezer?

"We eat so much," explained the suitably perky Miss America, Kimberley Pressler, giving a guided tour of her fridge in an attempt to dispel the myth that beauty queens don't eat anything. So dentally perfect and lusciously coiffed, you couldn't help but hate her guts, tiny and as full of sweetcorn as they were.

A genuinely admirable Miss America, Buffy The Vampire Slayer (BBC2), is heading for an explosive showdown with Mayor Wilkins as the tension inexorably builds down Sunnydale way. Bad but foxy Faith - who deflowered Xander a few weeks back and staked the deputy mayor - is heading for her doom with all the inevitability of Greek tragedy. Men should weep. Especially Xander.

webTitle: Matt Lucas, comedian, on his work.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Matt Lucas, comedian
fields.trailText: Matt Lucas, comedian.
fields.body:
As a precocious teenager, touring the comedy clubs, I was - how shall I put it - extremely "blue". Effing and blinding relentlessly, I notoriously and unapologetically bludgeoned my audiences into weary appreciation. Where there was a rude word, I used it. Where there wasn't, I invented it. In fact, I became known amongst my peers as "the c**t comedian" (although, in retrospect, I'm forced to concede that this may not have had anything to do with the language I used).

After trawling the circuit on my own for a couple of years, I joined forces with a strange, brilliant man called David Walliams and we were scarily blue together. We would defend our offensive brand of comedy to the hilt, gleefully mocking those so uptight as to recoil in horror at the merest hint of a rude word. Of course, our use of bad language was utterly fucking gratuitous, but it was liberating in the extreme. And fun . But when we worked on TV we were frequently outraged by reams of notes from beleaguered producers demanding a plethora of re-writes. I, in particular, would moan and groan vociferously at the idea of having to change "what works".

However, some years on, we've now grown out of being relentlessly blue. We try to write jokes instead. Which is why we were shocked and appalled last week, whilst scripting a forthcoming animation programme on Channel Four called Sick And Twisted, by the unremitting insistence of the producer that we come up with material that was "sicker and more twisted". When, at the end of a long day, we were asked to submit a stronger insult than "nana", we drily and rather half-heartedly suggested the C word. To our astonishment this proposal was greeted with wild enthusiasm, though personally I am disgusted by the word's inclusion in the programme and shall be writing a strong letter to my MP.

Matt Lucas appears on Little Britain (Radio 4, 11pm, tonight).

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: BBC Proms 2000/Bucket And The Whited Sepulchre
fields.body:
The late-night offering at the BBC Proms 2000 (10.0pm, Radio 3) takes the form of a Cuban Night, featuring two of the island's leading groups. The six members of Vocal Sampling (pictured) use their voices not only to sing their songs' lyrics but to imitate the accompanying instruments (they have even been known to adapt Strauss's Also Sprach Zarathustra). Los Van Van is one of the country's most famous instrumental groups, specialising in music drawn from local life and legends.

Inspector Bucket of the Metropolitan Detective Force was introduced towards the end of Dickens's Bleak House to solve the murder of the villain Tulkinghorn. Since he is now well out of copyright, James Hendrie has stolen him to star in his Afternoon Play Bucket And The Whited Sepulchre (2.15pm, Radio 4). He's a sort of prototype Columbo whose deceptively bumbling nature serves him well when the Bishop of Barnet apparently kills himself after losing his faith.

webTitle: TV guide: The Man Who Bought Mustique, tonight, 9pm, Channel 4.

fields.headline: Tantrums and tiaras
fields.standfirst: A C4 documentary finds playboy Colin Tennant in his element  - back on the Caribbean island he once owned, slagging off the natives and carousing with royalty.  Camilla Redmond meets its Oscar-winning producer Vikram Jihanti
fields.trailText: A C4 documentary finds playboy Colin Tennant in his element - back on the Caribbean island he once owned, slagging off the natives and carousing with royalty. Camilla Redmond meets its Oscar-winning producer Vikram Jihanti.
fields.body:
"Turn the fucking thing off! I'm frightfully angry!" Halfway through The Man Who Bought Mustique, its subject, Colin Tennant, Lord Glenconner, throws a spectacular tantrum. Producer Vikram Jihanti and director Joseph Bullman duck, as the peer of the realm launches a swingeing attack on anything and anyone in range of his shoulder-bag. The cause of his rage? It looks as though it's about to rain.

"Mmm, yes," says Jihanti carefully, "but to be fair, Colin was exhausted, we'd been filming him for days." It's the culmination of a series of scenes which show a petulant, increasingly impotent figure. Tennant is an exotic creature, familiar to many for his friendship with Princess Margaret and a lifetime's worth of gossip column appearances, but Jihanti - the Oscar-winning producer of When We Were Kings, his documentary about Muhammad Ali's mid-70s Rumble In The Jungle - and Bullman did not set out to make a film about him.

Commissioned by Channel 4 to contribute to the Caribbean Summer series, they headed for the islands to find themselves a story. An initial visit to Mustique yielded little of interest, but returning to St Vincent, they spotted an intriguing-looking elderly white man, tall and clad in flowing robes and high hat. "Do you think that might be Tennant?" asked Bullman. One direct approach from Jihanti, which established the answer to be yes, and they were hooked.

"When we'd been in Mustique, everyone had talked about Colin, even though he hasn't lived there for years", explains Jihanti. Tennant bought the entire island, three miles long and a mile wide, in 1958 as a wedding gift for his wife. It cost him £45,000. Alan Whicker made an oleaginous programme about Mustique in 1970, celebrating its A-list celebrity pulling power, as the likes of Mick Jagger and David Bowie came there to party. But by the mid 70s Tennant was gone, forced to sell up by financial necessity. He has rarely been back since, so for the film-makers to persuade him to revisit the island with them was something of a coup.

"Colin told us about the Whicker documentary, and was obviously hoping we'd make something similar", says Jihanti. If so, his hopes were in vain. The film benefits hugely from the inclusion of mischievous out-takes - Tennant demanding that he be allowed to shoot links again, and maligning his perceived tormentors. Of some local labourers he says, "They're all so frightfully slow and stupid." His biographer, a hapless figure called Nicholas Courtney, is screeched at for wanting to hog the limelight and told to get out of camera-shot, while a polite American couple, house-owners on Mustique, are labelled "social-climbing worms". Tennant himself is profoundly class-conscious, and Princess Margaret is just about the only person in the film to get unbroken charm from him. "And Patrick Lichfield," notes Jihanti drily, "after all, he's an Earl, so he's more grand than Colin. I'm an American, but if you spend time with Colin you soon get to know your Debrett's Peerage."

The chief purpose of Tennant's trip to Mustique is to set up his own tent and entertain Princess Margaret to lunch in front of the cameras. To be allowed to do this, he must be granted permission by the private island's central bookings service to pitch his tent - a state of affairs he clearly has difficulty accepting as anything other than a great impertinence. By contrast, in a scene where native islanders hold a church service to thank him for all that he has done for Mustique in the past, Tennant radiates goodwill, safely back in his preferred role of gracious patriarch. Jihanti says that he sees parallels with Tennant, unwanted on Mustique, and the exiled King Lear. As Tennant flaps around in his white robes, berating all and sundry in fluting, Brian Sewell-esque tones, the comparison doesn't seem too fanciful.

When Tennant achieves his aim of receiving Princess Margaret in his lavishly appointed tent, the film-makers gain remarkable access to a member of the royal family at a private event. Confronted by the vivid Kamasutra-style illustrations with which Tennant has decorated the walls, HRH can do little except express her astonishment, while Tennant valiantly fills in all the gaps in the conversation. Jihanti sees this sequence as evidence of his subject's sense of humour. "All the negatives about Colin are on screen," he concedes, "but there's so much more to him than that. He agreed to the film because he's desperate to prove that he's not just a fool who squandered his inheritance and threw away the greatest investment - Mustique - of his life."

Despite his sympathy for Tennant, Jihanti is aware that, with its bizarre cast of British nobles, The Man Who Bought Mustique can most easily be read as an argument for republicanism. The film is a character study of an British aristocrat struggling - and failing - to adapt to the changing world around him. Its idyllic Caribbean setting is almost irrelevant. What's fascinating are the flaws of the man revealed on screen. Jihanti and Bullman have accomplished the unusual feat of capturing a living, breathing dinosaur on film.

The Man Who Bought Mustique, tonight, 9pm, Channel 4.

webTitle: How to write, the Zinnie Harris way

fields.headline: How to write, the Zinnie Harris way
fields.trailText: Walter Mosley started his article about writing in last Wednesday's Guardian with the words: 'If you want to be a writer, you have to write every day.'
fields.body:
Walter Mosley started his article about writing in last Wednesday's Guardian with the words: 'If you want to be a writer, you have to write every day.' I wish to start mine with: 'If you want to be a writer, the last thing you should do is write.' I don't mean to be flippant and am not suggesting there isn't a place for huge amounts of discipline and dedication in writing, merely that creativity cannot be forced.

If nothing else, my own experience of writing plays has taught me that it will come in its own time, but unfortunately also on its own terms. No amount of pencil-sharpening, toe-tapping, or switching the computer on and off will quicken the process.

If Mosley finds his muse to be a softly spoken woman whispering possibilities that must be revisited every day like a well, I find mine more of a temperamental avalanche. I can stand at the bottom of the mountain and yell, shout and scream all I like but it will yield nothing but a few flakes of snow. If that.

However, when my back is turned, normally after I have given up, decided it is all over, the rumbling starts. The only commitment I can make beforehand is that when it comes, I will be ready. No matter where. Or what. From that point, not writing is no longer a possibility.

I used to worry about this rather erratic work pattern. To the outside world it seems like long periods of inactivity, then sudden mania. Now I see it as a necessary part of the process. The subconscious needs time and space to gestate the work.

To return to Mosley, he suggests that the only way not to lose ideas is to work on them constantly. He regrets the days he turns to his journal, only to discover the entry from several days before no longer seems exciting. It seems to me that this is part of the magic. The fleetingness is part of the strength, and self-editing a vital component of the work. Trust the voice that comes to you two days later and says the idea is no good. It is probably speaking the truth. The day that you come back to something two weeks, two months, even two years later and realise there is something in it, rejoice. The good ideas survive; the bad ones get edited out by the inability of the subconscious to stay inspired by something it is not engaged with.

I teach a playwriting course in Edinburgh. At the start of term I ask participants to put three ideas into an envelope, seal it and not think about them again. Meanwhile we concentrate on skills, dialogue etc. Ten weeks later they open the envelopes. They are constantly amazed - time and time again one of the ideas has taken root and started to grow. Characters, plot and scenes have formed. But the lack of daily pestering is vital.

What I am describing will only ring true for some. There are countless tales of great writers who sit down and write 500 words a day, every day. But whatever the approach, possibly the most difficult challenge for a writer is to trust - either the process or their creativity. Unlike other aspects of your life, writing isn't always something that can be controlled.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText: Quotes in the media.
fields.body:
"Whereas women's books in this genre are dismissed as a good beach read or whatever, I'm judged more harshly because I'm a man"

Mike Gayle on his "relationship-fiction" writing, Evening Standard

"Penny Lancaster is a tall, leggy blonde and Rod Stewart's girlfriend. 'Rod tells me,' she says, 'that I'm different from the other women he's dated.' Nice to know the old rocker is still using the reliable age-old chat-up lines. The one thing you can be sure about any elderly philanderer is that all his seduction dialogue will have been used before. In fact, it's something you can be sure of with any chap"

Lynda Lee-Potter tells it like it is, Daily Mail

"It should come as no surprise to women that men have a biological clock. Men have never been shy about co-opting female conditions when it suits them: male menopause replaced the mid-life crisis a few years back, making it seem as if running off with a receptionist was some kind of hormonal inevitability. Increasing numbers of men are suffering from post-natal depression these days, after the arrival of a demanding new-born leads to issues of unresolved selfishness. Of course, men have always had a sort of biological clock as well, with the countdown starting at 30 and the alarm set for 'Dead'. Its insistent ticking was the justification for all sorts of irresponsible 'you only live once' behaviour, as well as the spur for panicky bouts of exercise and half-hearted attempts to limit cholesterol intake"

Tim Dowling on the news that men have a biological clock when it comes to fertility, Daily Telegraph

"If you want to appear irresistible to younger men - and everyone else - hang on to their every word and smile or say encouraging phrases such as: 'Tell me more.' Corny, antediluvian but, alas, still true"

Tips on how to seduce younger men from new women's magazine Eve

webTitle: William Leith on how the penis has entered the public arena.

fields.headline: Privates on parade
fields.standfirst: Young men won't wear condoms, old men are less fertile. Size matters. (Or is it what you do with it that counts?)  William Leith  reports on how the penis has entered the public arena
fields.trailText: Young men won't wear condoms, old men are less fertile. Size matters. (Or is it what you do with it that counts?)  William Leith  reports on how the penis has entered the public arena.
fields.body:
It has been a mixed week for the male sexual organ. The penises of heterosexual men, it has been reported, contracted 31% more gonorrhoea last year than they had the year before, with young men particularly at risk. It has also been shown that the fertility of older men, as we always suspected, declines with age - 15% of men over 35 take more than a year to make their partners pregnant, say research teams from Bristol and Brunel universities. And according to Spice Girl Mel C, the former children's television presenter Jamie Theakston, who now presents Top of the Pops, has got "the biggest cock in the business".

On Tuesday, newspapers speculated about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases, about why the young men were taking such risks. Why these guys were plunging in, without making the effort to protect themselves with condoms. Kevin Fenton, a consultant epidemiologist, noted: "Young people are particularly vulnerable, as many are unaware of sexually transmitted diseases and their symptoms."

The lessening of fear of Aids is, of course, a factor. "We can't lose vigilance," Fenton says. But vigilance is, in some ways, increasing. On Wednesday, a tabloid reported that the comedian Mark Lamarr, who had been seen emerging from Tara Palmer-Tomkinson's hotel room, "has got a bit of a 'Theakston' on his hands - or rather Tara's hands".

What do I know about the penises of famous people? Quite a lot, it turns out. Theakston's was last week reported by an ex-girlfriend to be small, but apparently it has grown. Lamarr's "isn't in the same ballpark" (the Sun) as that of Tara Palmer-Tomkinson's previous boyfriend, Michael "Skinny" Power. Errol Flynn's was big but not as big as he tried to make out. That of poor Keith Chegwin, who recently stripped for a nudist gameshow on Channel 5, is not big but might be bigger than other people have tried to make out.

The question is: why do I know all this stuff? I know it because, as censorship recedes, we find ourselves being free to talk about male sexual organs - not just between ourselves, as we did in Errol Flynn's time, but in national newspapers and on television. Not just in a general sense but in a personal sense. Again, poor Keith Chegwin. In cultural terms, another borderline is being crossed.

This, of course - another layer of prudishness being stripped away, another set of taboos being dumped - is a good thing. It is also hilarious. Penises are great things to joke about. Did you see the episode of Seinfeld in which Jason Alexander goes swimming in cold water? As he's slipping out of his trunks, the woman he fancies opens the door. He is horrified. Shaken, he asks Jerry the question: "Do women understand about shrinkage?"

Men don't mind - they can take it. Men like to laugh at themselves. The American comedian Drew Carey tells penis jokes. "My dick is so big," he says, "it's got an opening act."

The penis can be laughed at because, as we can see from the gonorrhoea figures, it is a predatory organ. The penis does not belong to a minority group. It is a vector of misery; it can be an agent of damage and shame. We are comfortable when we see a television advert in which a French model holds a tape-measure to her crotch and says: "Size matters." We laugh - and we snigger again when the man in the ad says, rather pathetically: "It's what you do with it that counts."

What are we supposed to do with it? As a boy, I knew what I had to do - I had to score. My sexual desire would only be acceptable, in the fullest sense, when I had properly consummated it, when I had gone through the proper channels. As a male in our culture, I learned that to have sexual desire that is not sanctified in this way, by actually having sex with an actual woman, was demeaning. It was unbecoming.

How did I feel? I felt like the 15,572 guys who contracted gonorrhoea in 1999. It's not that I hated condoms, it's that I didn't give them very much thought. Venereal disease and pregnancy seemed like distant consequences of having risky sex, in the same way that champagne poisoning might seem like a distant consequence of winning the lottery. It doesn't stop you entering the draw.

No wonder we make fun of male sexual organs. And no wonder their female counterparts are celebrated. I was reading an article in Cosmopolitan's Real Life Stories, in which women talked about their sexual exploits. One woman said: "Some of the best orgasms I've had were with a camel!" It was the movement of the "magnificent beast" beneath her crotch that did it. "I decided to use the shower head as a vibrator," said another. These were not women who had failed to score but women who had succeeded in being self-sufficient. Can you imagine what we'd say to men who talked in a similar vein? We'd laugh at them, the wankers.

We may have equality of the sexes but we do not have equality of sexual organs. One cannot imagine an ad in which a guy smugly purrs "Firmness counts" or "Tightness matters". This would definitely be below the belt.

Female sexual organs carry a powerful taboo. I can print the words prick, cock and dick as much as I like but I know I have to be careful with the c-word. I can smirk at an ad in which a man compares himself with another man in a urinal but there is, of course, no female equivalent. When Gore Vidal reported Cecil Beaton's remark to Greta Garbo that, with age, his genitals were becoming smaller, and Garbo's sad reply: "I wish that I could say the same," it was her words that seemed the more shocking - or, in any case, the less palatable.

Is our inequality when it comes to sexual organs a good thing? Not necessarily. It's a phase we're going through. We laugh at male organs because we truly believe they are, in general, less vulnerable than female ones. But men - heterosexual men, at least - still define themselves, still seek their identity, in phallic terms; they still feel the need to score. This is why they catch gonorrhoea; this is why city traders talk about "getting your cock in the custard" when they are making a risky trade. This is why, even if men feel the ticking of the biological clock, they won't feel it in the same way as women. This is why Drew Carey says: "My dick is so big it's got a dick of its own! And even my dick's dick is bigger than your dick."
fields.bodyText: It has been a mixed week for the male sexual organ. The penises of heterosexual men, it has been reported, contracted 31% more gonorrhoea last year than they had the year before, with young men particularly at risk. It has also been shown that the fertility of older men, as we always suspected, declines with age - 15% of men over 35 take more than a year to make their partners pregnant, say research teams from Bristol and Brunel universities. And according to Spice Girl Mel C, the former children's television presenter Jamie Theakston, who now presents Top of the Pops, has got "the biggest cock in the business". On Tuesday, newspapers speculated about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases, about why the young men were taking such risks. Why these guys were plunging in, without making the effort to protect themselves with condoms. Kevin Fenton, a consultant epidemiologist, noted: "Young people are particularly vulnerable, as many are unaware of sexually transmitted diseases and their symptoms." The lessening of fear of Aids is, of course, a factor. "We can't lose vigilance," Fenton says. But vigilance is, in some ways, increasing. On Wednesday, a tabloid reported that the comedian Mark Lamarr, who had been seen emerging from Tara Palmer-Tomkinson's hotel room, "has got a bit of a 'Theakston' on his hands - or rather Tara's hands". What do I know about the penises of famous people? Quite a lot, it turns out. Theakston's was last week reported by an ex-girlfriend to be small, but apparently it has grown. Lamarr's "isn't in the same ballpark" (the Sun) as that of Tara Palmer-Tomkinson's previous boyfriend, Michael "Skinny" Power. Errol Flynn's was big but not as big as he tried to make out. That of poor Keith Chegwin, who recently stripped for a nudist gameshow on Channel 5, is not big but might be bigger than other people have tried to make out. The question is: why do I know all this stuff? I know it because, as censorship recedes, we find ourselves being free to talk about male sexual organs - not just between ourselves, as we did in Errol Flynn's time, but in national newspapers and on television. Not just in a general sense but in a personal sense. Again, poor Keith Chegwin. In cultural terms, another borderline is being crossed. This, of course - another layer of prudishness being stripped away, another set of taboos being dumped - is a good thing. It is also hilarious. Penises are great things to joke about. Did you see the episode of Seinfeld in which Jason Alexander goes swimming in cold water? As he's slipping out of his trunks, the woman he fancies opens the door. He is horrified. Shaken, he asks Jerry the question: "Do women understand about shrinkage?" Men don't mind - they can take it. Men like to laugh at themselves. The American comedian Drew Carey tells penis jokes. "My dick is so big," he says, "it's got an opening act." The penis can be laughed at because, as we can see from the gonorrhoea figures, it is a predatory organ. The penis does not belong to a minority group. It is a vector of misery; it can be an agent of damage and shame. We are comfortable when we see a television advert in which a French model holds a tape-measure to her crotch and says: "Size matters." We laugh - and we snigger again when the man in the ad says, rather pathetically: "It's what you do with it that counts." What are we supposed to do with it? As a boy, I knew what I had to do - I had to score. My sexual desire would only be acceptable, in the fullest sense, when I had properly consummated it, when I had gone through the proper channels. As a male in our culture, I learned that to have sexual desire that is not sanctified in this way, by actually having sex with an actual woman, was demeaning. It was unbecoming. How did I feel? I felt like the 15,572 guys who contracted gonorrhoea in 1999. It's not that I hated condoms, it's that I didn't give them very much thought. Venereal disease and pregnancy seemed like distant consequences of having risky sex, in the same way that champagne poisoning might seem like a distant consequence of winning the lottery. It doesn't stop you entering the draw. No wonder we make fun of male sexual organs. And no wonder their female counterparts are celebrated. I was reading an article in Cosmopolitan's Real Life Stories, in which women talked about their sexual exploits. One woman said: "Some of the best orgasms I've had were with a camel!" It was the movement of the "magnificent beast" beneath her crotch that did it. "I decided to use the shower head as a vibrator," said another. These were not women who had failed to score but women who had succeeded in being self-sufficient. Can you imagine what we'd say to men who talked in a similar vein? We'd laugh at them, the wankers. We may have equality of the sexes but we do not have equality of sexual organs. One cannot imagine an ad in which a guy smugly purrs "Firmness counts" or "Tightness matters". This would definitely be below the belt. Female sexual organs carry a powerful taboo. I can print the words prick, cock and dick as much as I like but I know I have to be careful with the c-word. I can smirk at an ad in which a man compares himself with another man in a urinal but there is, of course, no female equivalent. When Gore Vidal reported Cecil Beaton's remark to Greta Garbo that, with age, his genitals were becoming smaller, and Garbo's sad reply: "I wish that I could say the same," it was her words that seemed the more shocking - or, in any case, the less palatable. Is our inequality when it comes to sexual organs a good thing? Not necessarily. It's a phase we're going through. We laugh at male organs because we truly believe they are, in general, less vulnerable than female ones. But men - heterosexual men, at least - still define themselves, still seek their identity, in phallic terms; they still feel the need to score. This is why they catch gonorrhoea; this is why city traders talk about "getting your cock in the custard" when they are making a risky trade. This is why, even if men feel the ticking of the biological clock, they won't feel it in the same way as women. This is why Drew Carey says: "My dick is so big it's got a dick of its own! And even my dick's dick is bigger than your dick."

webTitle: Arts: Zinnie Harris, the prizewinning playwright talks to Tanya Wilson.

fields.headline: Treasure island
fields.standfirst: Zinnie Harris took her family's tales of the South Atlantic and created a work of dark poetry. As she prepares for opening night in Edinburgh, the prizewinning playwright talks to  Tanya Wilson
fields.trailText: Zinnie Harris took her family's tales of the South Atlantic and created a work of dark poetry. As she prepares for opening night in Edinburgh, the prizewinning playwright talks to Tanya Wilson.
fields.body:
Shortly after the second world war, the Reverend Dennis Wilkinson was posted to the remote South Atlantic islands of Tristan da Cunha. He took with him a young wife and two daughters, aged one and five. Their four years of living on Tristan, and the culture shock they experienced, became the stuff of family legend. "We all grew up on tales of this magical place," recalls Zinnie Harris, Wilkinson's granddaughter, who was born long after the island adventure. "We spent evenings poring over hazy photographs of men with strangely serious faces; we were told about long boats, penguin eggs, black volcanic sand and places that were called things like the Patches or the Ugly Road."

These tales - unreliable, fantastical childhood memories with "fuzzy edges and missing bits" - inspired Further Than the Furthest Thing, a darkly poetic play that last year won Harris the prestigious Peggy Ramsay Award for new writing. Harris, 27, has since become playwright in residence for the Royal Shakespeare Company, and is tipped for great things as a writer. But her childhood also instilled in her a love of directing. "I had a whole working set of puppets as a child, and I would save up for each new one," she recalls. "I had an old man, a girl and a boy. And then I got a nurse, and that changed the plot. I remember saving for a year for a skeleton puppet."

Harris would direct her puppets, and script them, and is, to this day, determined to maintain both activities. "There are two sides to me: the writer who has to have an intimate relationship with the work and the other half that loves directing, loves working with people."

After an unlikely education - a degree in zoology from Oxford and a year's postgraduate work - Harris drifted into professional theatre via the Edinburgh Fringe, where she directed M'Lady Malade True Bel leck, which she also wrote, and the medieval morality play Mankind. This year she staged Edward Bond's Saved at Glasgow's Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama. She has also been heavily involved in community projects, running writers' workshops for women prisoners in Askham Grange prison in York and HIV-positive patients at Edinburgh's Milestone House.

It is the work for Milestone that touched Harris most deeply. She has already written about it in her play By Many Wounds, but now believes this may have been too quick a response to such a moving experience, and that she will come back to it.

Helping people to write about what was happening to them, or to compose letters to be left behind after they died, Harris was working at the hospice when combination therapy came in. "I used to come home and howl: the work feeds you emotionally but also drains you emotionally. And when combination therapy came along, people who had been planning for an imminent death suddenly got a new lease of life. Although this was a very positive thing for some people, there wasn't necessarily any life to go back to. For instance, one woman who had thought she was dying had made the heartbreaking decision to give up her child. When given a new lease of life, there was a lot of grief and anger over that decision to work through."

The stories Harris heard about Tristan da Cunha as a child also had this powerfully emotional quality. The idea of a remote community originating from seven shipwrecked sailors washed up on the island (they sent for women from neighbouring St Helena), visited by a supplies boat only every six months is the stuff of bedtime stories. She describes the play as 10% fact, the rest fiction, but still loves the details and the telling of the tale.

"When my grandfather was there, the place was like something from the previous century, with almost Napoleonic elements. They lived on what the boat brought and crayfish and potatoes. My mother had no sweets. That was the thing I remember finding amazing as a child - she would eat raw potato instead."

Further Than the Furthest Thing is about this geographic remoteness, but is also a more universal story about insiders and outsiders, staying and leaving. Picking up on the islanders' evacuation to Southampton in the 60s after Tristan's volcano erupted, the play also tackles issues of colonial power. Once the islanders were in Britain, it was made as difficult as possible for them to return home. It was too expensive to maintain, the government thought, and would make a perfect site for nuclear testing.

"They were told the island had been destroyed," Harris explains, "but they saved enough money to send some men back to see what was left. Meanwhile, they got used to having central heating, healthcare, and so on, so that by the time a cinefilm came back from Tristan showing that everything was fine, they had to have a very real debate about whether to go back."

In the end they did. "The way they signalled this was rather wonderful. They wore these thick white socks when they were on the island, but not in Britain. On the morning they decided to return, they all put their white socks back on and boarded the ship." Typically, through this tiny detail, Harris brings a historically and geographically remote reality to us, closer than the closest thing.

Further Than the Furthest Thing is at the Traverse Theatre, Edinburgh (0131-228 1404), from August 6-26, the Tron Theatre, Glasgow (0141-552 4267), from September 6-23 and the National Theatre, London SE1 (020-7452 3000), in October.

webTitle: What is it with women and diamonds?

fields.headline: Rock tactics
fields.standfirst: As record-breaking runner Marion Jones wins one and Germaine Greer laments the loss of hers,  Caroline Sullivan asks what is it with women and diamonds?
fields.trailText: As record-breaking runner Marion Jones wins one and Germaine Greer laments the loss of hers,  Caroline Sullivan asks what is it with women and diamonds?
fields.body:
'Clock the rock!' Sarah Ferguson supposedly squawked to friends back in 1986, waving the ruby-encrusted ring Prince Andrew gave her for their engagement. Admittedly, it was some rock - a glimmery red sparkler set in gold, costing in the neighbourhood of £10,000 and chosen by HRH himself from a selection brought to the palace by the crown jewellers, Garrard.

Once Fergie was married and began acquiring bejewelled booty on a regular basis, such as the necklace/ bracelet/earrings trinities poshly known as "suites", presumably her reaction became less reminiscent of a seal at feeding time. But there can be few women who don't feel that same primal rush of pleasure, flattery and greed on being presented with some sparkly bauble.

Even Germaine Greer, who speaks of her relief at detaching from the sexual side of herself, post menopause, isn't immune to the seduction of a few ounces of sculpted glass and metal. Her whole collection, including a pair of diamond earrings that cost over £2,500, was stolen last week. Greer dismissed the items as "trinkets" but it's a good bet the insurance money won't make up for the wrench of losing them.

Likewise the sprinter Marion Jones, who received a one-carat diamond on Tuesday for breaking a record in the Swedish athletics grand prix, will undoubtedly keep it safe, not because of its intrinsic value but because of the symbolism.

Unless you're a royal and receive the stuff all the time, jewellery tends to be given to mark life events. The 18th-birthday earrings, engagement ring, will-you-ever-forgive-me Elsa Peretti "bean" necklace (so popular at Christmas that Tiffany keeps ready-wrapped stacks).

As this implies, women are still likely to have their jewellery bought for them and usually by men. "Most of our customers are men buying for women," confirms Gina Moore of Garrard (now Asprey & Garrard). "We're traditional - and our biggest sellers are engagement rings."

Tradition: jewellery is steeped in it, from the ancient meanings of gemstones to its role as class signifier. Wear a discreet touch of silver and you're posh; load yourself with gold and you're Posh Spice - or a rapper whose "ghetto fabulous" style incorporates the flashiest stuff you can afford to prove you've made it. Or Madonna, who draped herself in diamonds in the Material Girl video, semaphoring the come-on: "You can buy me for the price of a necklace."

Material Girl confirmed jewellery's transactional value between men and women. Supposedly men give and we receive, enacting an age-old ritual in which jewels are the quickest way to a girl's favours. We are meant to be compulsively acquisitive when it comes to these little tokens and to swoon at the merest glimpse of a sexy suite. Visions of old goats and their trophy babes come to mind.

There is no denying that most of us love adorning ourselves and that a jewellery gift from a significant other will find its way on to a finger or neck and remain there, intimate and precious. "It becomes part of a girl by her wearing it, which makes it the most personal gift you can give," says my friend Richard, who often gives jewellery for special occasions.

But there is a growing tendency to skip the middleman and buy for ourselves what Fergie would call rocks. A current radio ad suggests a cure for depression is a diamond necklace, chosen and paid for by you, Ms Empowered.

It's an idea female rappers have espoused all along. "None of them wants to feel as if they are being bought and it's empowering to know you have the benjamins to buy your own diamonds," says Jools Stephenson, former publicist for Li'l Kim and Missy Elliott, who wear their stones and platinum (currently the trendiest precious metal) in the knowledge that every eye-popping carat was charged to their own platinum (what else?) Amex.

It is probably just as well because male counterparts such as Puff Daddy are too busy acquiring their own Fort Knox-worth of rings and chains to buy for ladies, too. Saying that, the idea of men and jewellery still doesn't sit well and one can only hope that David Beckham and his diamond-studded crucifixes don't catch on. Still, if they do, at least Posh will, as ever, be wearing one, too.

webTitle: Eurocrats' union threatens action over job for Prodi aide

fields.headline: Eurocrats' union threatens action over job for Prodi aide
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, is facing legal action by staff furious at a senior appointment which they say flouts agreed procedures.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, is facing legal action by staff furious at a senior appointment which they say flouts agreed procedures.

Signalling the start of a long hot autumn when Brussels returns from its normally sleepy summer break, the European Civil Service Federation (FFPE) said yesterday that it would pursue its complaint to the court of justice if necessary.

Commission employees are up in arms over Mr Prodi's decision to appoint his former spokesman, Ricardo Levi, to run a directorate dealing with forward planning.

Tensions are already mounting over far-reaching internal reform plans being overseen by Neil Kinnock, Mr Prodi's British deputy.

Mr Levi, a journalist and long-time confidant of the former Italian prime minister, performed badly during his stint in the hot seat and was replaced by a professional British eurocrat who it is hoped will prove a more effective spin doctor.

Commission officials insisted yesterday that proper procedures were followed, but the union complained that the Levi appointment "flies in the face of Mr Prodi's own undertakings and seriously undermines the credibility of civil service structures".

Privately, some commission officials call the six staff unions "dinosaurs" bent on disrupting work and inflating their membership figures, said to constitute no more than 20% of the 18,500 employees.

The FFPE noted that Mr Prodi was appointed after the mass resignation of Jacques Santer's commission.

It claimed that Mr Levi's appointment was made without the advertisement of a detailed job description or proper interviews. This was "illegal and flies in the face of the very rules drawn up by the commission", the union said.

The move comes against a background of unhappiness over Mr Kinnock's reform plans, aimed at creating what he has called the "best multinational administration in the world". The former Labour party leader said last week that his plans were making progress, with new financial management rules in place and an unprecedented bid for extra staff.

Critics argue that his main achievement so far has been in avoiding industrial action, and trouble is possible in the autumn when management and staff start discussing core personnel and career issues.

Staff also complained at the decision to close the notorious Economat food shop, long a symbol of a "fat cat" lifestyle in the Eurosceptic media.

Mr Prodi has had a rocky ride since taking over from Mr Santer last September, and the union action seems likely to cast a shadow over his first anniversary next month.

The weakness of the commission has allowed the EU's big governments, especially France and Germany, to ignore it, even as the European parliament has seemed to be stronger since playing a high-profile role in Mr Santer's dramatic downfall.

fields.headline: Chaos imminent as Mugabe ups the ante
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Perhaps it was desperation at the continued harassment, or perhaps it was a misplaced confidence after the stinging rebuke Zimbabwe's voters delivered to their desperate president. But three weeks ago a few dozen white farmers hit back against the government and went on strike.
fields.body:
Perhaps it was desperation at the continued harassment, or perhaps it was a misplaced confidence after the stinging rebuke Zimbabwe's voters delivered to their desperate president. But three weeks ago a few dozen white farmers hit back against the government and went on strike.

Even before their protest culminated in yesterday's widely respected nationwide general strike to demand the restoration of the rule of law, many farmers had cause for regret. Robert Mugabe responded to the defiance in his favoured manner - he focussed his ire on the whites and greatly raised the stakes.

The government's announcement that it will now seize about two-thirds of all white-owned farmland threatens to bring Zimbabwe's burgeoning crisis to a head within weeks.

Just a few days ago, Zimbabweans were debating whether Mr Mugabe would run for another term as president in two years or step aside for a younger candidate in the hope of reviving Zanu-PF's popularity. Now the debate is over whether Zimbabwe's economy can survive Mr Mugabe's rule, however short it might be.

The original core of a few dozen white farmers went on strike last month in protest at the continued occupation of their land by "war veterans" and escalating violence. Even the government said the occupations should stop in favour of a more orderly distribution.

Dozens of other farmers across the country joined the protest which forced the hand of the unions and the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change. They were not only bound to support the strike but had to be seen to organise it.

But the evident role of whites in promoting the protest further angered Mr Mugabe, whose government hit back by quadrupling the number of farms facing confiscation to 3,000. While the farm seizures might strengthen Mr Mugabe's political control in the short term, ultimately they look disastrous for his country's economy and damaging for the government.

The earmarked land produces a good proportion of the country's agricultural exports. Tobacco earned Zimbabwe about £250m last year but revenues are expected to drop by at least one-fifth this year. Manufacturers are warning of large scale redundancies. Already there is talk of a looming food shortage.

Neither will the chaos of the land distribution help Mr Mugabe. Whether there are 500,000 families who want to move, as the government says, is a moot point.

While Zimbabwean farms are large - the 3,000 earmarked for redistribution cover nearly 20,000 square miles - much of the land is of poor quality or barren. If the farms are subdivided into hundreds of thousands of small plots, some are going to be left with the scraps.

And, although the recent changes to the constitution permit the confiscation of farms without compensation, there is still an established process of notification and appeal to be followed.

The government has already completed the procedure for the original 804 farms but if, as it says, it wants to seize the additional land before the rains in a few weeks it will have to ride roughshod over its own regulations and defy the courts.

fields.headline: BBC warned against dumbing down
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: MPs have delivered a strong warning to the BBC not to reduce the amount of serious programming on BBC1 as it moves towards a radical overhaul of its television services.
fields.body:
MPs have delivered a strong warning to the BBC not to reduce the amount of serious programming on BBC1 as it moves towards a radical overhaul of its television services.

The culture, media and sport select committee said yesterday that the licence fee could no longer be justified if the BBC were to abandon the idea of "mixed scheduling" - providing a broad range of programmes on one channel.

Responding to a plan raised by the BBC's director of television, Mark Thompson, the committee warned the corporation that it could not expect to launch new channels that duplicated what the commercial sector already provided.

In a recent speech, Mr Thompson suggested that at a time when ITV was spending £100m more a year on drama BBC1 needed to catch up by investing in popular shows.

"That gap limits BBC1 creatively and leaves it relying too much on factual programmes; documentaries are one of the glories of BBC production but it is possible to have too much of a good thing," he said.

BBC executives are considering plans to focus BBC1 more on entertainment, BBC2 on current affairs, to turn the digital channel BBC Choice into a youth and comedy service and BBC Knowledge into a channel for culture, arts and classical music.

In its report, the committee expressed serious reservations about the vision. "If BBC1 were to become ITV without the commercials and BBC2 were to become Channel 4 without the controversy, then this would affect the justification for the BBC as at present constituted and funded."

Mr Dyke is expected to use his speech to the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival later this month to outline firm proposals for his vision.

There have been signs recently that the BBC is drawing back from the position adopted by Mr Thompson.

A spokesman for the corporation said yesterday: "The BBC agrees that it must continue to be a distinctive service offering high-quality, innovative programmes which are not available elsewhere. We have no firm proposals to change either channel."

However, he said that the BBC could be expected to examine the impact of new technology on its services "to ensure they continue to serve all parts of the nation and keep their place at the heart of the nation's life."

At a hearing last month, the select committee questioned the BBC about the performance of Radio 3.

But the corporation had not sent anyone representing radio to the meeting - a decision which was roundly criticised in the report.

The report also said that the governors' decision to lump together the viewing figures for BBC News 24 on cable and digital services with the ratings for overnight broadcasts on BBC1 was "misguided and misleading".

Without the extra figures from terrestrial broadcasts, the BBC could not claim that News 24 was the most watched UK news channel.

 The report in full

webTitle: Watchdog seeks end to lottery bias

fields.headline: Watchdog seeks end to lottery bias
fields.trailText: Bewildering over-long forms, a lack of feedback, and an inconsistent appeals system have prevented poorer communities from benefiting from the national lottery, a government report has found.
fields.body:
Bewildering over-long forms, a lack of feedback, and an inconsistent appeals system have prevented poorer communities from benefiting from the national lottery, a government report has found.

The report, written by the culture sector's official watchdog, Quest, proposes a single national helpline to give basic information about lottery funding programmes. It also suggests that unsuccessful lottery applicants be told why their applications have failed or not met the criteria.

Government studies in the past have found a bias against funding for poorer areas, such as around Britain's coalfields. The discrimination in part appears to arise from the complexity of the application process. And applicants typically wait for between three and six months to find out if they have managed to get support.

The Quest report, covering applications for lottery grants of £100,000 or less, reveals that the form can stretch to 16 pages and 74 questions.

It proposes simplified forms, especially for groups seeking grants of £20,000 or less. It suggests applicants be told early on if their project has very little chance of getting funds.

The report also finds that "the distributors use different definitions of the term 'appeal' and have different procedures for dealing with them". Only 10 of the 58 different schemes reviewed stated that they had an appeals process.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has been trying to shift the focus of the lottery away from big buildings and projects to smaller, "people centred" ideas.

Mr Smith said: "Potential applicants should not be deterred by needlessly complicated forms, unnecessary demands for information and lengthy delays in decision making. It is vitally important all parts of the country share in the benefits [of] the lottery."

So far £7.8bn has been raised by the national lottery for good causes. In the past 15 months almost 21,000 small grants, in total worth £200m, were paid out, compared with just over 30,000 small grants, worth £629m, over the previous five years.

webTitle: Childcarer job leaflet is 'invitation to paedophiles'

fields.headline: Childcarer job leaflet is 'invitation to paedophiles'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A government recruitment drive to sign up more than 80,000 extra childcare workers could prove a magnet for paedophiles and other child abusers, nursery nurses warned yesterday.
fields.body:
A government recruitment drive to sign up more than 80,000 extra childcare workers could prove a magnet for paedophiles and other child abusers, nursery nurses warned yesterday.

The Professional Association of Nursery Nurses (Pann) - the nursery branch of the Professional Association of Teachers - criticised ministers' refusal to introduce regulations for all types of childcare, including nannies working in private homes.

It warned that a planned television advertising campaign and brochure would appeal at best to inexperienced people and at worst to child abusers. A likely influx would follow of tens of thousands of untrained workers into nurseries, playgroups and the expanding network of breakfast and after-school clubs.

The campaign of the Department for Education and Employment, in support of the national childcare strategy, aims to recruit 83,000 workers over the next two years via TV advertising backed by a 12-page brochure. The idea is to recruit nannies, as well as helpers in more organised settings such as playgroups, clubs and nurseries.

Pann said the brochure made no mention of training or careers. It simply stated: "We want people who like children, enjoy spending time and learning with them." It went on: "If you have had some experience of looking after children, so much the better, but it's not essential. A lot of people choose childcare because the work is flexible and fits in with looking after their own children, but you certainly don't need to be a parent."

Tricia Pritchard, head of Pann, said at the organisation's annual conference in Cheltenham: "As we have pointed out to the government, paedophiles love being with kids."

She said the jobs might well attract abusers who had been forced out of children's homes and more tightly regulated nurseries. Childminders and staff working in nurseries are checked by local authorities and by Ofsted, the schools' watchdog. Pann has been campaigning for nannies working in private homes to be brought into line, with compulsory checks by the police and their inclusion on a national childcare register. An estimated 110,000 nannies form the largest single group of childcare workers, many working up to 12 hours a day in sole charge of a baby or infant.

The government is unwilling to go further than agreeing to introduce a kite marking scheme for nanny and recruitment agencies. It believes that a nanny register would give parents "false comfort".

Yesterday Pann warned that the government's recruitment drive, coupled with its failure to introduce blanket childcare regulations, had put back its campaign to raise standards by as much as 15 years. Ms Pritchard said: "The move will further downgrade a sector which is already notorious for poor pay and bad working conditions."

Cases like the paedophile in the West Midlands who had befriended a nanny to get access to young children, she said, showed children in their own homes were particularly vulnerable. Women as well as men were capable of abusing and assaulting, as shown by a number of cases.

Yesterday, Margaret Hodge, the education and employment minister, accused Pann of scaremongering. "It is complete nonsense for any organisation that claims to represent the interests of children to criticise the government for trying to recruit new people to work in childcare.

"Of course, recruits will be thoroughly checked and vetted to ensure they are appropriate to work with children - there has been absolutely no suggestion by the government or any other organisation they will not be.

"To run a scaremongering campaign suggesting that we are dropping our recruitment standards is plainly wrong."

fields.headline: Choleragenetic makeup found
fields.trailText: US scientists have deciphered the entire genetic makeup of the cholera microbe - one of humanity's cruellest enemies.
fields.body:
US scientists have deciphered the entire genetic makeup of the cholera microbe - one of humanity's cruellest enemies.

The research could trigger drugs or vaccines to control the disease which can kill its victim in a day.

The genetic sequence was unravelled by the Institute for Genomic Research, a non-profit laboratory in Maryland founded by the scientist and entrepreneur Craig Venter and headed by his wife, Claire Fraser.

The microbe Vibrio cholerae has two chromosomes with a total of 3,885 genes, spelled out in more than 4m letters of DNA.

It has been a scourge in south Asia for at least 1,000 years, but moved worldwide in 1817, in the first of a series of seven pandemics. Strains of the bacterium live harmlessly in brackish estuaries and coastal waters; some infect fish and shellfish while others are dangerous to humans. In refugee camps, city slums and places where sanitation is poor, cholera can kill up to half of its victims.

Cholera joins other dangerous microbes - including tuberculosis, meningitis and syphilis in having been sequenced.

webTitle: German minister calls for ban on rightwing parties

fields.headline: German minister calls for ban on rightwing parties
fields.trailText: A senior minister in Germany yesterday said that the time had come to consider banning extreme rightwing parties in the country.
fields.body:
A senior minister in Germany yesterday said that the time had come to consider banning extreme rightwing parties in the country.

The environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, made his proposal amid a rapidly growing crusade by the government against the far right.

The campaign was given huge additional impetus last Thursday when a bomb, thought to have been planted by ultra rightwingers, exploded at a Düsseldorf railway station injuring nine immigrants, including six Jews.

Mr Trittin's remarks nevertheless planted the seeds of a potentially troublesome crop for the government. The only parties that can be outlawed in Germany are those proved to be undermining the constitution. A ban would need to be reviewed by the constitutional court and the process of scrutiny could take years.

Doubts were also expressed about the effectiveness of such a ban, even if it were approved. The interior minister of Germany's most populous region, North Rhine-Westphalia, said that when the authorities there outlawed a far-right group, it only succeeded in driving it underground and making surveillance of its members more difficult.

"It actually led to the opposite of what we wanted," said Fritz Behrens.

The family minister, Christine Bergmann, hinted at divisions within the ruling centre-left coalition over the issue. She agreed that a ban could be discussed, but added that it would not "take the problem off the table".

Though figures have been produced to suggest that neo-Nazi violence is again on the rise, they are far from conclusive. Sources close to the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, say the authorities have been prompted to tackle the far right essentially for economic and diplomatic reasons.

On Monday, the government handed out the first of 20,000 work permits allowing skilled foreigners to enter Germany to work in its computer industry. Ministers accept that substantial immigration from outside the European Union is required, not just to bridge a technological skills gap, but to keep a balance between Germany's active and non-active sectors of the population and keep its creaking pensions system from ruin. Pension reform is the key political issue on Mr Schröder's autumn agenda.

The other factor prompting official concern is the prospect of EU enlargement to the east, which could bring large numbers of Poles, Czechs and Hungarians into Germany.

They risk encountering a level of xenophobia which prompted Wolfgang Thierse, the speaker of the lower house of the German parliament, to say at the weekend: "I am ashamed of this country."

Statistics point to a level of anti-immigrant violence proportionately similar to that in Britain. The daily Frankfurter Allegemeine Zeitung yesterday quoted police and security officials as saying that more than 30 people had been killed by rightwing extremists in the past 10 years - in a country of some 80m.

The Home Office in London said that in the four years from 1996 to 1999, there were 10 reported racially motivated homicides, in a country with a population less than three-quarters the size of Germany's.

The problem is that Germany's far-right violence is overwhelmingly concentrated in the economically depressed east, which was under communist rule and, until the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989, had an uninterrupted experience of dictatorship stretching back to the foundation of the Third Reich. There was far less re-examination of the Nazi past in the east than in the capitalist west.

A report issued earlier this year by the BVD, Germany's equivalent of MI5, showed that the five regions with the highest incidence of suspected or proven rightwing violence were all in east Germany.

Yet this is the area most in need of foreign expertise and likely to see the biggest influx of outsiders when the EU expands.

webTitle: British man determined to finish round-the-world run

fields.headline: Keep on running, one fine day I'm gonna lap the world
fields.trailText: A British man who has run three quarters of the way around the world has said that he will not stop jogging despite being attacked and robbed in so many countries he now expects such crime daily.
fields.body:
A British man who has run three quarters of the way around the world has said that he will not stop jogging despite being attacked and robbed in so many countries he now expects such crime daily.

Robert Garside, 33, from Stockport, Greater Manchester, set out from Piccadilly Circus, London, almost four years ago with just £20 in his pocket. He has run an average of 40 miles a day and the journey has taken him through Europe, China and Japan, and, last year, across Australia.

His goal is to have run the equivalent length of all the continents (42,000 miles) by the time he gets back to London, sometime in 2002.

But, coming to the end of his tortuous route through Latin America, starting at Cape Horn and now heading towards Tijuana, Mexico, Mr Garside's morale is beginning to slide. The road has not always been easy and last month the former police officer's confidence was severely shaken when, again, he was robbed at gunpoint.

"Just outside Acapulco there was this long dark corner and I imagined it'd be a great place to rob people. Next minute, one guy was running at me with a gun and two others with knives. I thought, oh dear, here we go again," he said.

In a rare moment of pessimism, Mr Garside said being mugged was now becoming something he was getting used to; he has been shot at in Russia, robbed in Pakistan, and had guns pointed at him in Panama, and now Mexico.

He insisted, though, that while the attacks were starting to make him angry and depressed he was still mentally strong. "When someone runs at you with an axe or spits at you or throws stones at you, you have to try and stay positive," he said.

Mr Garside's website logs the highs and lows he experiences and is regularly updated from his palmtop computer - when it has not been stolen. "I just love running and the physical and psychological benefits it provides," he writes. "I could run around a track, but I want to explore the world. But I do try to avoid danger as much as possible. I guess I prefer geographical challenges."

Muggings and mental struggles aside, Mr Garside is doing rather well for himself. Having long since spent the first £20, he has acquired £60,000 or so to fund his trip, made through selling his story to television companies and newspapers in the 30 countries he has so far visited. As well as his palmtop, he has been able to afford 26 pairs of trainers and a digital video camera.

The only other possessions he carries with him are a map, a toothbrush, a change of clothes and a hat. With no water bottle - they would weigh him down - he drinks, along the way, from rivers and even occasionally puddles.

Wherever he goes, people are fascinated to hear about his adventures. He has been imprisoned in China. He broke the world long-distance running record in Australia. He went without food in India and he jogged through civil war in Afghanistan.

In December he met the train robber, Ronnie Biggs, in Rio de Janeiro, who warned him against getting married and settling down. "Keep on running," advised Biggs, citing his own motto.

He has a number of television interviews lined up in San Diego and elsewhere in the States, which could fund the rest of his odyssey. The US media are fascinated by the British exploring spirit and have been drawing parallels with their own favourite jogger, the fictional Hollywood film character Forrest Gump who ran across America.

But Mr Garside said that to make it to the Mexican border by August 10, as promised the US networks, he should step up the pace to 60 miles a day and perhaps start running at night. "When the sun goes down and I have not arrived at a town, I must run in the dark," he writes on his website. "The dark doesn't actually change anything, but it does depend where you are. Sometimes I feel like I am torturing myself and the run is crucifying and I know I am in an altered state, but I have to keep going and sometimes I don't even notice I am running, it's like being in cruise control."

Last year Mr Garside told the Guardian how he had transformed jogging from his hobby into a way of making a living. "The original idea was just to see the world. But as I was going through with it I realised I could make myself a future. I have learned how to make money out of what I do. I'm its only practitioner, so I have a monopoly on it."

Robert Garside, 33, from Stockport, Greater Manchester, set out from Piccadilly Circus, London, almost four years ago with just £20 in his pocket. He has run an average of 40 miles a day and the journey has taken him through Europe, China and Japan, and, last year, across Australia. His goal is to have run the equivalent length of all the continents (42,000 miles) by the time he gets back to London, sometime in 2002. But, coming to the end of his tortuous route through Latin America, starting at Cape Horn and now heading towards Tijuana, Mexico, Mr Garside's morale is beginning to slide. The road has not always been easy and last month the former police officer's confidence was severely shaken when, again, he was robbed at gunpoint. "Just outside Acapulco there was this long dark corner and I imagined it'd be a great place to rob people. Next minute, one guy was running at me with a gun and two others with knives. I thought, oh dear, here we go again," he said. In a rare moment of pessimism, Mr Garside said being mugged was now becoming something he was getting used to; he has been shot at in Russia, robbed in Pakistan, and had guns pointed at him in Panama, and now Mexico. He insisted, though, that while the attacks were starting to make him angry and depressed he was still mentally strong. "When someone runs at you with an axe or spits at you or throws stones at you, you have to try and stay positive," he said. Mr Garside's website logs the highs and lows he experiences and is regularly updated from his palmtop computer - when it has not been stolen. "I just love running and the physical and psychological benefits it provides," he writes. "I could run around a track, but I want to explore the world. But I do try to avoid danger as much as possible. I guess I prefer geographical challenges." Muggings and mental struggles aside, Mr Garside is doing rather well for himself. Having long since spent the first £20, he has acquired £60,000 or so to fund his trip, made through selling his story to television companies and newspapers in the 30 countries he has so far visited. As well as his palmtop, he has been able to afford 26 pairs of trainers and a digital video camera. The only other possessions he carries with him are a map, a toothbrush, a change of clothes and a hat. With no water bottle - they would weigh him down - he drinks, along the way, from rivers and even occasionally puddles. Wherever he goes, people are fascinated to hear about his adventures. He has been imprisoned in China. He broke the world long-distance running record in Australia. He went without food in India and he jogged through civil war in Afghanistan. In December he met the train robber, Ronnie Biggs, in Rio de Janeiro, who warned him against getting married and settling down. "Keep on running," advised Biggs, citing his own motto. He has a number of television interviews lined up in San Diego and elsewhere in the States, which could fund the rest of his odyssey. The US media are fascinated by the British exploring spirit and have been drawing parallels with their own favourite jogger, the fictional Hollywood film character Forrest Gump who ran across America. But Mr Garside said that to make it to the Mexican border by August 10, as promised the US networks, he should step up the pace to 60 miles a day and perhaps start running at night. "When the sun goes down and I have not arrived at a town, I must run in the dark," he writes on his website. "The dark doesn't actually change anything, but it does depend where you are. webTitle: Doctors to be sued over surgery refusal

fields.headline: Doctors to be sued over surgery refusal
fields.trailText: The parents of a baby girl whose life was saved when a hospital agreed to go ahead with surgery after she had been turned down by another, are planning to sue the hospital which refused her treatment.
fields.body:
The parents of a baby girl whose life was saved when a hospital agreed to go ahead with surgery after she had been turned down by another, are planning to sue the hospital which refused her treatment.

Heart specialists may face legal action over the clinical decision not operate on a mentally and physically disabled toddler.

The parents of Hannah Harkness, who is now three, said yesterday they were planning to sue Leeds United Teaching Hospitals trust, to make the point that vulnerable children could die if parents failed to press for second opinions in life threatening cases.

Staff at Leeds general infirmary are preparing to search files for notes of the case in January last year, when two senior doctors turned Hannah down for surgery after assessing her survival chances as too poor. The child had two holes and an open duct in her heart but also suffered other severe medical problems since birth.

She has a rare chromosome disorder, a deficient immune system, and speech and phsyical development diagnosed as slow. Her parents, Karen and Colin Harkness, of Selby, North Yorkshire, said they were concerned that her other problems had affected the decision and had insisted on a second opinion.

Hannah was referred to cardiologists at the Freeman hospital in Newcastle upon Tyne, who cleared her for surgery and operated successfully in May last year. Both holes were repaired and the duct plugged and the girl has since made a full recovery.

"She is a completely different child now and a joy to be with," said Mrs Harkness, 33, who has seven other children. "The change since the operation has been wonderful."

Hannah's father Colin, 36, a security consultant, said: "We just felt that the first doctors wrote her life off - that if we hadn't gone for a second opinion, Hannah would now be dead. Other parents must realise that they don't need to take a consultant or doctor's word as the be all and end all."

A spokesman for the hospital trust said clinical decisions were often difficult and involved a balance of opinion. The reversal of the Leeds refusal did not mean the doctors had acted wrongly. "In January 1999 the functioning of Hannah's heart was very poor and a joint clinical decision was taken by a consultant cardiologist and a cardiac surgeon not to operate because it was felt the risks associated with the surgery were too high."

fields.headline: Weblife: expert sites
fields.standfirst:
Ideas rather than big bucks make your website a winner, writes Alexander Campbell
Net news
fields.trailText: Ideas rather than big bucks make your website a winner, writes Alexander Campbell
fields.body:
I could be making my name on the internet right now. All I need is a bright idea and I can live the Great Internet Dream - that my startup website becomes the best in the field and millions will surf a path to my door. Kudos, fame, interviews in Time magazine, profiles in the FT... all around the corner, just as soon as I have a brilliant idea.

While awaiting inspiration, I had a look for other sites that have done the same. There are quite a few. Although the corporate giants such as Microsoft, the BBC, CNN and AOL Time Warner have a massive web presence, some of the smaller non-profit sites have the reputation that is infinitely more powerful on the net.

Best known is the Drudge Report, which reached international prominence when it broke the story of President Clinton's affair with Monica Lewinsky. Matt Drudge started by relaying anonymous Hollywood gossip, and, as his reputation and contacts list grew, he moved into all types of news - his was the first US news source to publish the story of Princess Diana's death. It is unpleasant to read and often strident, but it does get the news out.

Many other sites have achieved success in the same way, although not to the same government-shaking extent. Ain't It Cool News is simply one person's website consisting mainly of film reviews not very well presented - but, like the Drudge Report, it has access. Its reputation has brought it prominence in a continual virtuous circle. The more people you reach, the more people contribute rumours, gossip, reviews or whatever to your site; as your site gets better content, its reputation grows and more people visit. Reputation is all: David Lisk of Northern Ireland has, for some reason, built an amateur list at www.airdisasters.co.uk of every civilian air crash in history. Such is its deserved popularity that after last week's Concorde crash in Paris it almost collapsed under the visitor load.

Oddly, although the internet started life as a network connecting research institutions, very little independent science information is available. Oddly, because science depends on the full and free exchange of information: the isolated scientist is rare beyond the shores of Doctor Moreau's Island or the grounds of Castle Frankenstein. But publication in a peer-reviewed journal is the scientific mark of quality, and publishing on the internet rather than in the scientific mainstream is viewed as unnatural, the province of fringe scientists, charlatans and flat-earthers (see the Flat Earth Society at www.flat-earth.org ; but possibly they are not entirely serious).

Non-specialist independent sites do exist, generally run in the authors' spare time. One exmple is How Stuff Works, whose author was forced by sheer pressure of readership to transform it into a commercial company. ScienceNet, a charity devoted to answering science questions from the public - it has a telephone equivalent, Science Line - and aPieceOfUs www.apieceofus.org.uk are still non-commercial, probably thanks to large pools of volunteer authors.

The contrast between scientists and technologists couldn't be greater. The net was created mainly for scientists, but largely by first-generation computer hackers. The first bulletin board services (a means of posting messages and replies for a selected readership) were set up by programmers for programmers. They exchanged technical hints, clever shortcuts, jokes that only a hacker could find funny and the first Frequently Asked Questions lists.

Everyone profits from a well-maintained FAQ list; and, more often than not, programmers, like any other profession - doctors, lawyers, politicians, soldiers, even journalists - feel more in common with their competing opposite numbers than with their distant employers. Thus there are whole libraries of shareware and freeware: programs that are open for anyone to use (try www.freewarefiles.com). There are many websites that exist solely to provide tips on constructing websites, such as Webmonkey, and, of course, numberless FAQ sites on everything from the care and feeding of your pet African clawed frogs to building your own telescope.

Every hobby, however obscure, has a home somewhere in cyberspace: the Eddie Stobart lorry spotters' club is at www.lorryspotting.com - and compared with some of the other hobby sites out there, lorry spotting is mainstream.

Although it makes no commercial sense, the co-operative culture of the internet has survived the explosive dotcommercialisation of the 1990s - better, in fact, as some veteran Net users remark, than many of the dotcoms themselves. Will it last? It is still growing as the internet grows, and showing few signs of dying out. New co-operative projects are announced all the time, and attract thousands of volunteers. So perhaps it will survive after all.
